review:
Basically Fallout (original) in a fantasy, steampunk setting. There are even two particular regions which pay homage to Fallout with a "junktown" in one and two-headed cattle in the other.

You can play as human, dwarf, gnome, elf, halfling, half-elf, half-orc, or half-ogre.

You can build up your character with melee, ranged (bows, crossbows, thrown), steamworks (firearms, clockwork weapons), and arcana. Arcana and steamworks work against each other; if you put skills in one, it makes the other less effective.

Character stats make a huge difference in available dialogue options (create a low intelligence character for an especially interesting playthrough).

The game is pretty big, so expect it to take a long time to finish.
7 Magick out of 10 Magick. Magick is just better than tech.

Arcanum is a brilliant RPG, and one that I would argue is in contender for the best in it's genre. What it lacks in some mechanics and controls features (which is mostly a testament to its age) it makes up for with the most compelling open world setting I think I've played in a game.

The controls and general gameplay mechanics feel weird at first, but are quite intuitive once you've actually learnt them. Its biggest flaw is that most things are explained in the manual, meaning you sort of learn the controls as you go along, discovering features like how to use the quick bar or deploy a mechanical spider on the fly. Once you're past that difficulty spike, the mechanics of the game are quite fleshed out. The schematic system is extensive, the items and craftables feel near limitless. Overall its a very mechanically dense game.

The worlds story feels wasted on the game its found itself in, and im honestly amazed its never been adapted into a show or sequels after it released. Its concept is such unique ground to set a DND world in that most interactions and story beats are so unpredictable compared to your average RPG. The characters are all very fleshed out, the world and its environments are incredibly complex, and overall the way that NPCs and books talk about the world builds such a vivid picture compared to others in the genre.

The combat leaves much to be desired. Where i think they fucked up was in making the spells and high-end weapons too easy to aquire and too powerful. This means that many monsters lategame will kill a party member in 2-3 hits before you can even prevent it. I would much rather feel less overpowered and have less spiky combats than the state its in now, especially given the setting. The combat options intensify this, the turn based combat is pretty good but the initiative still feels random and causes you to suffer the same issues but slower. The real time on the other hand is a complete gamble of chaos mostly determined by how you're characters do damage. For example, playing as a summoner I could easily agro enemies, and have my monsters kill them before they even change attacker. This meant my strategy was to pull enemies, then run until they die. This is stopped when the enemy has a bow, in which I die to 10 arrows before I can even enter turn based mode.

The appeal of this game is mostly in the story and the world. And as someone who didn't play 90s RPGs I can safely say the graphics do not pull you away from that feeling. Its still just as interesting to explore as the day it released, and I can honestly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of narrative games. You can hate the combat, the gameplay, the leveling system and most mechanics with it and still come out of this game feeling like you enjoyed it more than you didn't just off the strength of the world. The world really is just that good and its why someone like me is even recommended it in the first place.

My original favorite game! Recommend 10000000%
No classes, assign skill points from level up however you wish, you can even dump points directly into health and fatigue if you want.
No railroading, ignore the main quest for as long as you want while you explore a truly open world map. Once you get out of the starter town, you can go almost anywhere.
End cutscenes: see what impact you've had on the world, good or bad

One of the only games that I have absolutely zero complaints about

I do not recommend this game on Steam.  It's much easier to tweak, finetune, and otherwise modify (which you will need to do) from GOG Galaxy. Great game if you can get it working, just some tips to get it running. Install unofficial patch, set the ini to 1920x1080 and run the install bat, then rename ddraw to 000, then set monitor to 60hz or lower and 1920x1080, restart PC then try to run it, that's the only way I've been able to get this game to run consistently, also turn off G-sync on your monitor if it's on.

I played with UAP, only enabling the patches, not the mods or additions. I'm going to make myself very clear: do not play this dogshit meme of a game. It is an idea for an unrealized game, not a game in it's own right. It is a cool idea, I admit, and I would welcome a competent developer, one who have completed a game this century, like Whalenought or ATOM, taking a stab at realizing a true Arcanum, but I will not blow smoke up your ass. Playing this game will prove whether you are a Man, or a witless cultist.

The game released in beta, I'm well aware. Its nigh a quarter century old, but unlike Planescape, IWD, Fallout, Baldur's Gate, this isn't a game worth finishing. It isn't difficult, in fact if you want a difficult game, make yourself ugly and don't save the dog. However, it is unfathomably tedious. My second character, the default dwarf, has aged five years simply walking to his objectives. Where's the pacing? Developers who can't control themselves need a main quest timer, as in Fallout, or they will scatter the story all over the board and dilute it with nonsense errands and fluff better left to another game. Its insane that civilized locations aren't depicted on the map, in a setting with choo choo trains and dirigibles. Come on! If you want me to stay on course, so I don't over-level and destroy "the balance" - a theme in this game - then write a worthy story. Send me to interesting locations.

Locations are important, but not as important as characters. Arcanum's got quite the cast of characters, so you'd think a game praised for reactivity and choices and consequences, good writing and such, would have outstanding companions. Yes, the dog. The dog is so good at killing your enemies, that you will form an emotional bond with it. Its howls are somber, you can only imagine what its been through. Who was its real previous owner? An ill-fated mariner? A kind old lady? An orphan sacrificed in secret to the god of the gnomes? Now consider Virgil, "Is that you, GOD?" we all love the time he said "err, I, ummm... Joachim will know." and who could forget "Sorry, but I walk a lonely road now. Don't you dare follow me!" YOU were following ME! Kick rocks, ya Green Day song about teenage angst. You bet I left him for dead. Mechanically, companions needed scripts in real time mode, or the player should have been given control of the party in tb mode, because of course they're retards. You're better off crafting or summoning followers than keeping companions, though you will need to keep one to resurrect you.

Arcanum is a character sheet in a dumb as rocks RPG system. The level cap is 50 - UH OH! You know what that means? It means that the system is 100% slop. When you level, you spend 1 character point, or every five levels 2, on raising abilities... or your skills... or your hp/vitality... or toward your tech degree... OR YOUR MAGIC DEGREES! WTF is this!? Just blend it all together, why don't you! You can spend character points directly on vitality and hp? The same character points are spent on both abilities and skills? XDD

I've got a time machine, come on, let's go ask Troika what the fuck they were even thinking. Us: Hello, is this cult classic Troika? Troika: Yes.
Us: What were you thinking?
Troika: Well, uh, we're making a very epic game. Yes, Arcanum is so epic. I hear its the most epic. People tell me all the time how epic Arcanum is. That means we need a high level cap.
Us: Is the game epic? Is there an epic quest in this game, or is it loaded with trash encounters and "reactivity" shit tests for buildfags obsessed with playing RPGs from a character sheet?!

Look, I hate this stupid cult classic crap, but I'm a stubborn retard. Its always gnawed at me that I quit my first time in Tarant, every time I tried to play. "Maybe I'm not being fair." I thought. "Maybe this cultish slobbering over the game is justified." No, it isn't justified. Don't play it. If you must play Arcanum, and you don't want to buildfag, make a Charismatic Harm Mage. Your choice of good or evil. Get the dog. Look up the quest to become God, do the Siamese Twins quest, and try to have fun.

Arcanum is a bit rough around the edges due to it's old age and limited budget, but it's still a masterclass in immersive world design and player freedom that still hasn't been matched to this day. It might take a while to get into it, but reading the manual before you start the game will help a lot. 

Definitely give this a try if you like roleplaying games for the actual roleplaying aspect.

Arcanum is a really nice CRPG game if you are looking to experience and try out the old fashions, or simply wish to bring back childhood memory. But do keep in mind that this game is as old as a Glacialisaurus, bugs are still there like they've been frozen in time. If you do end up trying this game, do yourself a favor and get the Unofficial Arcanum Patch. Enjoy!
yes

Utterly massive and versatile. Any build or playstyle is viable if you play it right, and the game will accommodate it. Despite some dated elements (for instance, items that should be stackable like potions take up their own inventory slots) , the game holds up very well and in many ways excels where so many modern RPGs fail. The world feels alive and vibrant, and your efforts actually feel like they have weight and purpose. Random little sidequests you do can have massive implications on future quests and the ending you get. The dialogue is superbly written, every character feels alive. I felt like talking to everyone I saw just in case I got some interesting unique dialogue. There are some characters who serve no purpose to the overall plot but whose stories are deeply moving. And the world is sprawling and intricate, and most of all fun. Arcanum is chaotic, but there's too much order these days anyway. With the UAP patch it runs like a dream and the controls and UI aren't that difficult to understand (I had to look up the keyboard shortcuts, but that's about it) . Arcanum is truly one of a kind and more RPGs should take inspiration from it.

An amazing CRPG .. a true underrated gem that I simply adore. Past its jank,  badly aged combat, and not impressive graphics lies an RPG fan's dream come true. It is a great sin that this is the only game set in the world of Arcanum, the city of Tarant is perhaps my favorite town in any roleplaying game I ever played given how content packed it is. Also, this game has some of my favorite quests, "Half Orc Island" and "Negotiations with Caladon". This game deserves more love and praise than it gets. Play it (with an unofficial patch of course ) and get ready to be completely immersed in it until you are done.

Aside from all the hassles i can tell the story, lore, and the worldbuilding is gonna be fenomenal judging from the first couple hours of gameplay. it's a charming game for sure and worth the try for people who have the extra patiences lmao.

Troika might be dead, but their legacy lives. A great RPG with great lore and setting that combines the histories of our colonial era timespace mixed with fantasy elements. If you do play till the end of this RPG and not treat it as an immersive sim, you get to experience a very good conspiracy-esque thriller story and how you get to make choices in your run despite the unraveling of the plot towards the end of the game. However, the UI and the combat (spam Harm spell) was underwhelming. Certainly a flawed masterpiece!

This game gave me one of the greatest gaming memories of my childhood. I never actually finished it myself, but i watched my dad complete it multiple times. That didn‚Äôt matter to me - I got so much enjoyment simply from exploring and LIVING in its world. I remember being on a family vacation and, instead of enjoying it, i was DAYDREAMING about all the things i‚Äôd do in Arcanum once I got back home. And don‚Äôt even get me started on what i truly believe is one of the GREATEST gaming soundtracks ever composed. It adds so much to the atmosphere and immersion of the world.

I‚Äôm not sure how easy it would be to get into this game nowadays, especially if you don‚Äôt have the nostalgia for it. But if you‚Äôve enjoyed any classic CRPGs from that era and haven‚Äôt tried Arcanum, you definitely should. It‚Äôs a hidden gem -overshadowed by more popular titles like Fallout or Baldur‚Äôs Gate, but no less important because of that.

Also, it runs great on the Steam Deck. It just requires a bit of tinkering at first, but after that, it‚Äôs smooth sailing.

P.S. The fact that you can just exit the borders of one location and seamlessly (albeit slowly) travel into another without using map travel is as insane today as it was back then. Unnecessary but cool details like that are one of the reasons I keep revisiting older games

Arcanum is one of the best RPGs and one of the greatest game ever made. 
For those of us with refined tastes who can appreciate its wonders, it remains a defining experience and a work of exquisite art, created with heart, love, and a vision. 
The loss of Troika Games is a tragedy. They were among the greatest studios to ever exist, and though their works were not without flaws, bugs, or clunkiness, they were all exceptional in their own way, brimming with character and a real soul, that is missing from the vast majority of games made nowdays. 
The menu music is eternally etched into my memories and I will forever praise this game because of all the good memories and emotions it gifted me in my teenage years. 
(Even tho I need the unofficial patch to run it properly now, I am still grateful for Troika for their great work.)

Recommend using mod to run the game other wise it won't run well on modern PC and don't be ashamed of easy mode, this game has a lot of thing to praise but combat difficulty is definitely not one of them.

Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura ‚Äì A Flawed Masterpiece

A unique blend of steampunk and magic, Arcanum offers one of the most ambitious RPG experiences ever. With deep world-building, reactive storytelling, and an incredibly flexible character system, it‚Äôs a dream come true for hardcore CRPG fans. Dialogue and quest design allow for unparalleled freedom‚Äîwhether you outsmart enemies, use brute force, or literally talk to the dead.

However, technical issues hold it back. Even for its time, the graphics and animations were outdated, and without fan patches, the game is nearly unplayable due to bugs. The combat system is clunky, and exploration can feel tedious without fast travel.

Would I recommend it to modern players? Only to those willing to embrace its flaws. Despite its rough edges, Arcanum remains a cult classic and one of the most ambitious RPGs ever made. If there‚Äôs any justice, Microsoft will someday give it the remake it deserves.

One of my favourite games ever; one that i still own on CD just in case Steam/the internet ever implodes and i need something to occupy myself.

Play as a technological genius or a 'old-school' magic user and the game takes on an entirely different spin, from the attitudes of the people you meet to the way you overcome challenges and encounters.

The skills and crafting feels rich and worthwhile (you will be crafting the gear you use throughout) especially bin-diving in every new town/area to feed my grenade addiction......

For me the story often plays second fiddle to the gameplay but here is was an integral part of my enjoyment. Simply a great game.

The interface is pretty good once you figure it out, though it is not at all intuitive, and the lore and story are great.  My biggest piece of advice to is save, often.  I've only played for about 4 hours, and have died like 96789089779898 times. This is partly from me over-estimating my abilities as a veteran RPG gamer, and partly from the not at all intuitive interface, which has me just kind of pressing buttons randomly to figure it out. Despite all of this, I remain engaged with the story and recommend giving it a go!

Please ignore my steam playtime. 
This is...my favorite game of all time. I played it the most, with replays that couldn't be counted on both hands...from the begging till end, I played this, over and over again..and always with someone new, with a background, path, a different way to solve quests that would fit them...I once played a slight bad guy who kept going back to the punishing prostitute in the main city after each bad deed...i had a drunk character bed a sheep...an evil, proud, dark elf who'd obliterate anyone with her magic, just for looking at her wrong on the wrong leg day...an idiot savant was also fun. So was being sent to charm school or starting as a soon to be penniless orphan..and oh the music, the steampunk setting..there is NO game quite like Arcanum. Some that come close are the old fallout games which are gems of their own but...Arcanum, now, always, first in my heart, game wise. 

Wish Troika was still kicking...but if it was, would it still stick to their magnificent roots? We'll never know.
-----
An attempt to be less bias: It's not perfect. I have to use either the unofficial patch or download the multiverse edition for the bug fixes. The ending is not so satisfying compared to the rest of the masterpiece. 

There's atmospheric violin music throughout the game, among which you might find some best soundtracks you've heard in a game or otherwise, depending on taste.

Some might find the artstyle out of date but i'm 100% honest when I say it's my favourite. It fits the theme, isn't goofy, is beautiful in a unique way.

The replay value, as I mentioned, is HUGE. Lots of ways to solve the same quests, an alignment system, background, races and reactions to your race, beauty, intelligence etc.

The world itself is also large, brimming with people and quests.

The story is, in a lot of ways, what you make it. Same as with your character. 

It's up to you my friend...It's all up to you...

One of the best RPG's of it's early isometric era, Arcanum feels like it's often overlooked during a time when online gaming was starting to take over, and the major focus was on console modernization.
For it's time, Arcanum had a lot to offer. 

Pro's
-Well written dialogue accompanied by stellar voice acting. 
-Fulfilling map travel stuffed with secrets and lore.
-Excellent soundtrack, to this day it still gives me a heavy dose of nostalgia
-Solid Character build diversity directly effecting NPC dialogue and, to a lesser extent, questing and storyline.
-Gritty, dark,  steampunk and magic landscapes that only the early 2000's managed to pull off with it's art models.
-Replayability. Each different character style opens up different interactions, solutions, and rewards.

Con's
-Dated content, a 200 hour single player campaign, this is not.
-Early 2000's graphics, no remaster here.
-Glitches, there will be. Some of which are exploitive. This can benefit you, if you're into that kind of thing.
-Compatibility issues, some assembly may be required.

If you don't mind the feel of the early 2000's vibe this is sure to give you, I put this up there neatly beside Baldurs Gate, and Fallout 1-2.

A heavily flawed masterpiece, this highly experimental CRPG set in a fantasy world undergoing an industrial revolution fortunately hits more often than it misses. Arcanum has one of the most exotic and well-crafted settings in any CRPG, and is accompanied with a fantastic story rich in adventure and philosophy. It also has one of the best levelling up systems in any video game ever, as the 16 spells colleges, 8 technological trees, and 16 regular skills facilitate a near limitless number of different builds/roleplays. However, there are major problems. The combat is borderline unplayable, and pretty much everyone uses exploits/cheese strategies to get past the fighting. Much of the loot is also terrible (see also: Hexed Items), which seriously hurts exploration, and the inventory management is just abominable, especially if you have companions. While I think the story is excellent overall, at least half of it is spent searching for the Black Mountain Clan (BMC) and hitting constant dead ends. You will also need to install mods (UAP in my case) and you will likely have to consult the wiki every 5 minutes. Overall still a fantastic game, but one that I can only recommend to serious CRPG enthusiasts.

I love this game! Honestly one of the best CRPGs I've played so far. The voice acting is great, the characters are well written, the plot is clever and the mechanics are appropriately challenging. I definitely recommend this game for anyone who is fond of classic heroic-fantasy RPGs but also is hoping to get some originality

Arcanum Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura, the real Fallout 3. This extraordinary game was created by many of the same devs who created Fallout and worked at Interplay. Set in a world that was once ruled by magick, that was run and controlled by magick, is now being opposed and replaced by technology and industrialization. Technology and Magick are polar opposites in this world, so greatly so, that people that become greatly attuned to one, become entirely separated and even allergic to the other. This creates a major rift in society on Arcanum with some cities being ruled by technology, others by Magick. This also has a major effect on the player and in the gameplay mechanics as well. For if you are too Technology attuned, then spells will not affect you, neither can you cast them yourself. You even can not enter a Magick equipment selling shop, as the shop keeper will yell at you to get out, because your Technology attunement is interfering with their magickal equipment. The opposite of all of this is true for a Magickally attuned character when interacting with Technology as well of course. 
This also adds an extra layer to the character creation process, by having to decide if you want to be highly Magick aligned, Technology aligned, or stay in the middle. This attunement will change over the course of the game depending on your choices on your character sheet. If you want to learn a new spell, that will shift you toward Magick, you want to learn a new skill like crafting or lockpicking, that will shift you toward technology. While you can stay in the middle and use both types of attunement, it is advised to stick with one, because the power of your skills in either Technology or Magick, scales with your level of aptitude. So if you have low Magick, your spells won't be as effective, for example.
The world building and lore of Arcanum is also outstanding and very fun to read. Unlike some games, you aren‚Äôt given lore dumps or massive walls of text from NPCs unless you specifically ask about it, and even then I found it incredibly rare. Most of the worldbuilding is told to you organically as you talk to people and complete quests. You'll get involved with political struggles, and talk to rulers and kings, hear gossip and rumors on the streets. You can see the varying architecture from each city and location. This will all convey the background and lore to you in an interesting way that feels natural and doesn‚Äôt bog down the pacing. There are also plenty of books, altars, and other literature to read that give you much more in depth writings on the history of Arcanum that you can read if you are interested. The story as well, while a little tropey, is really good because of all the interesting characters you meet, and locations you‚Äôll go to, and just the way you interact with the story based on the character you build, and the choices you make. I don‚Äôt want to go into spoilers, but I found it very enjoyable and much better than some other RPGs like Pillars of Eternity 2, or Fallout 2.

The game however, is not all perfect. Arcanum released in a very buggy state so you will probably have to install the unofficial patch which will fix most of the bugs. I played with the unofficial patch and didn‚Äôt run into any bugs personally. Then there is the combat. It is split between two different modes, real-time and turn-based, that you can switch between when you want with the space bar. It is best to stay in turn-based mode most of the time however, because the combat can get very fast and chaotic. It is clear that the game was designed around turn-based, and real-time was added after because the balance becomes broken in real-time mode. For example if you play as a mage, you can cast spells as fast as you can click the mouse button with no cool down or anything to stop you other than your fatigue which really trivializes combat encounters. I do appreciate being able to switch between the two modes, however, because there can be a lot of trash mob fights such as when you're traveling the world map or just in general, so being able to switch over to real-time and quickly clear out the enemies is nice. A better solution however, would be to only have turn-based combat, and add an option to speed up the animations so each turn goes by quicker. That way you don‚Äôt break the balancing of the game and can also speed through fights. The combat itself however, even in turn based mode is not as fun as it could be. For perspective, I played as a mage type character. So I only used spells in combat and had a party of 5 companions with me, 6 by the end, to keep the enemies away from me and to dish out most of the damage. The combat as a mage, really just boiled down to casting the harm spell over and over because the damage it does scales up really high with your magickal aptitude and remains powerful all the way to the end of the game. There are a lot of other utility and buffing spells to use as well but aside from the occasional healing spell, I didn‚Äôt have to do anything else in combat really. I played on the moderate difficulty setting and found that after a certain point, when my companions had decent gear and my magickal aptitude reached about the halfway point, the game really wasn't a challenge anymore. The only thing stopping my mage from ultimate destruction was my fatigue, which despite it reaching around 160 by the end, still managed to drain fast in combat. Fatigue is one of the most important resources in combat. Fatigue is used to cast spells, attack enemies, and is sometimes drained when enemies hit you. If your fatigue reaches zero or below, then you pass out. It is an interesting mechanic and I wouldn‚Äôt mind it, however the one annoyance I have is the only way to regain fatigue is to either use a consumable, rest, or stand there and wait for it to slowly refill. So if your in the middle of a long dungeon, and you run out of fatigue, and you don‚Äôt have any consumables, then you either stand there and wait for like 5 mins or you trek all the way back out of the dungeon so you can rest, then make your way all the way back to where you left off in the dungeon, to continue on. It does get a little annoying, however if you are playing as a Technology attuned character that can craft fatigue refilling consumables then you probably won‚Äôt run into this problem. As a mage character however, it happens frequently.
Despite these problems, Arcanum is still an outstanding game and one of the best RPGs. The level of depth that the character creation has and the choices that you can make that will dramatically affect your playthrough is matched by almost no other, except for Troika‚Äôs Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines. The world of Arcanum they made is so fascinating and there is so much more to explore, it's a shame there will never be an Arcanum 2. Still this game is an amazing experience that feels like a proper continuation to Fallout in gameplay systems, progression, choice, and rich world building.

Classic!

Okay so this is a game that I remember one of my friends going on about back in the 2000's, but I never got around to playing it.

Bought it on Steam in 2020 for pence but never got around to playing it.

Saw a random Youtube video praising the socks off it and thought "ah screw it, aint played a CRPG for a long ass time, lets gooo!"

Game is jank, but with the community patch (UAP in my case) it works wonderfully at 1920x1080 res (though needed a new DDwrapper or whatever the file was called, Google it if you get stuttering).

I like summoner classes, and this game is very generous when it comes to conjuring monsters. In fact, I got so powerful, when I stumbled across a really messed up quest involving tiny people and breeding farms, I was able to lay low the capital city with just my legion of undead and hell spawn. None were spared, it was not a good ending but it was better than letting the tiny people get away with it.

You can really out level the game quickly if you do a lot of fighting on the world map, so watch out for that, because I was pretty much OP from level 1 and never really ran into a challenge. I'd only die if the a.i of my spawned monsters would fail (sometimes they teleport to you and go docile mid-fight for absoloutely no reason, allowing the bad guys to stab a pitch fork in your necormancer face).

Story is so-so, I guess I liked it more than BG1, but I think the game shows its age most of all in this area. So much exposition and red herrings, but its not awful and there were moments where I was genuinely engaged.

However the meat of the fun for me was just exploring and doing random side quests, really immersing myself in the world of Arcanum. Its a shame the game doesn't really favour this style of play, with areas being locked behind main quest progression, but its fine.

Oh also it kinda plays like Fallout 1 and 2, especially world map travel, leading me to wonder if there were some fallout devs involved but I haven't looked into it.

Took me about 30ish hours to complete, had to use a guide at times because this game doesn't hold your hand and often expects you to grid-search a town to track down a single individual, and you have to speak to people first to reveal their names - this gets very tiring. Someone for example asks you to speak to an archer, but there are 10 archer guards in the town, so its just - yeah this is where the game shows its age and jank.

Would recommend at full price, overall I think its fun, the world is unique, the game is quite easy but there is some challenge and to be fair I think the summoner class might just be op as all hell. If you like CRPGs and have played Fallout 1/2 or Baldurs Gate 1/2, you'll probably like this.

This is a first entry in what feels like what was meant to be a multi-entry series. It is at its core just a story about an unknowing Chosen One who must save the continent from an evil deity while helping (or hindering) folks around the lands. That is a barebones description of this game and it does it no justice to describe it solely as that. 

This is a game about steampunk vs magic and an evolving landscape where the two are diametrically opposed. There are fantasy races with their idiosyncrasies and stereotypes but it doesn't detract from the experience. The magic system is what you'd expect from a first-entry: underbaked but exciting to use. The melee/firearms system is the same. There are numerous companions scattered about. Navigation is what you would see in similar CRPGs from this era, which means it's a little dated. 

However, this is one of my favorite games of all time. It's worth investing time into and getting lost in the lore. All of the shortcomings of this game are the shortcomings of a first entry in a series, meaning they'd be ironed out or tuned or refined in some way. This game never had the luck to get a second entry, unfortunately. It still shines bright, though. 

I give it a solid 8/10. If I could have a sequel to any game in history, I'd want this. It deserves a chance to grow and maybe even flourish.

i quite enjoyed this game. because i have previously play this game decades ago. yes this game is over 20 years ago. the problem with this game is the incompatibility with new computers which i personally do not like; it gives issues when alt-tabbing. but the game itself is still playable-ish. for a game so long, it has a nice bgm with an array of abilities one can learn. from skills to magic to creation. this game blurs the lines where magic and technology comes together. maybe in today's games, that is a common theme/space to have. but know that this game feels like the introduction of such opposing themes to come together in a steampunk game. yes, it is one that is beyond its years. also, anyone who indulge in turn based combat with rich writing akin to Baldur's Gate and the likes, will enjoy the game. if they can overlook the aged graphics/game mechanics and tech compatibility. do not expect support to be granted for games like these.

I massively admire many of the things this game does. It's truly reactive in your character choices & dialogue, it has tons of potential build variety, the story & setting both seem really interesting and it's overall pretty unique. But personally I just cannot get past how un-fun the minute-to-minute gameplay is.

The combat is really simple and unenjoyable even compared to other RPGs of the time. I think the most fun one would get here is from breaking it or trying the weird options available but things like that don't appeal to me, I want the core combat to actually feel good to engage with. You can play it turn-based or real-time and neither feel good to me. There's so much running around, and even simple things like the way the camera pans around feel janky and annoying, like you can barely move your camera away from where your character is. I persisted for a good few hours getting through several quests and exploring different locations, only to realise I hadn't really enjoyed any of it except for the dialogue/build choice reactivity, so I guess I can't recommend this game even though I highly admire some of the things it does.

Best writing in a game I've experienced in a while. Extremely rich and deep lore, story, characters, and mechanics. The quests were a treat. The slower pace forces you to breathe in and enjoy the dynamic world the game takes place in. Decisions made in the earliest parts of the game can have pay-off years down the road in game. 

Just be sure to patch it before setting off. Waiting until the end game for a game breaking glitch isn't the move and not an uncommon happening.

This was one of my very first favorite RPG's and still is today. I had all of the important features a good RPG should have. character creation, free roam, great story/plot, and it was the first in a Steampunk setting. You also have early percussion firearms which is very cool and you can craft. all of this in the very early 2000's. It's 2024 and this is one of the best games I've ever played. 

The unofficial patch is apparently a must (haven't tried it without) but is easy to download and there is a guide on steam. If you like Tides of Numera, Torment, Baldur's Gate 1+2 (clearly superior to 3) and like quests with a variety of solutions many of them not obvious or things you'd not expect to work for a game over 20 years old then I highly recommend. The combat is much much easier on turn-based but it's also not really why you should play the game. Save often because autosave is not a thing and the early game is arguably harder. The quests are really inventive, a surprising number of starting races and backgrounds but you can also easily pivot into other builds. I found the whole tech v magick lore interesting and every town was a new adventure. Oh and I think Steam didn't record my hours on this game correctly, I got at least 60 hours out of it. Not sure I'll play again soon but an evil run will be a possibility if the lack of good games in the 2020s continues. They simply don't make them like they used to.

And by the way the soundtrack to this game is probably top 5 of all time if you're into that.  I hope you enjoy this game as much as I have over many years.

Steam wants me to recommend this game to you, so I will.

What is Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magic Obscura? A classic, that's what.
Made in a different time, perhaps not fully baked, but a classic nonetheless.
It's an RPG which asks itself the question: What if the industrial revolution came to a world of elves, swords and wizardry.
We are talking the the whole lot: steam engines, electricity, inventors and scientists.

A lot of the things you now consider staples of an RPG experience, Arcanum was the first game to do
and there are some where it remains unbeaten to this day. 
Freedom to approach the quests in a number of ways. 
Seeing the gameworld acknowledge what you do and what your character is.
Yeah, it's an older game and can get clunky at times, especially working the inventory can
be a bit of an ordeal, yet its scope and influence is hard to deny.

A few tips to enjoy the game A.D.2024:
<>Read the manual. It's there, freely available to all. 
Puts you right in the mood and introduces the key terms you will be needing.
Also comes with a banana bread recipe.

<>Get the Unofficial Patch. This is essential, fixing a bunch of stuff,
most importantly the screen resolution. Don't play without it.

<>Think of a character you'd like to make which makes sense in the setting and enjoy yourself.
The game is quite accommodating to all sorts of different approaches, though some may 
be more tedious than others. Speaking from experience, a gunslinger might not be the best first pick.
yeah, i think it's pretty good.... i think

[h1] [ENG/PTBR] [/h1]

The company that originally made the game (Troika Games) no longer exists, their publisher, Sierra, is now a part of Activision Blizzard, thus, when you buy the game, your money goes to them, and since the game is pretty old, doesn't have any achievements and you need to patch it manually to run properly (both ballance and resolution fixes), there isn't any reason to acquire it on steam, besides counting your playtime (mine is bugged at the time of this review, since i've been running the game directly trought it's .exe file)

With that out of the way, well, there's no sugarcoating on this: this game is old, both on the good and bad way.

This game is absurdly well written and it's setting is one of the best, most unique options out there. But some game mechanics might aswell be esotheric knowledge before you get the hang of it, the game features a game manual (like many games of it's time) and i really recommend that you read it before playing, not only for the ingame tips, keybinds and etc, the manual has some really neat sessions explaning the lore, setting, races and such, it even has a halfling "banana bread" recipe near the end.

I've played as a Dwarf Technologist on my first run, and it's safe to say that, aleast to me, that way of playing seems like one of the """canon""" ones, which severely boosted my immersion on the setting and main plot. 
And speaking of immersion, arcanum isn't afraid to pack a punch.

Since i was playing as a dwarf, most of arcanum citizens weren't too fond of me initally (unless i was wearing some rich man's suit & tophat) and they weren't afraid to let me know, they even charged me extra on some inns, saying that the extra gold was due to the work that they would have cleaning the fleas and lice from the room after i was done with it.

Since i was playing as a Tech expert, i've spent a lot of time with the crafting system, and it was a lot of fun, specially when crafting silly little things like the mustard gas grenade and the flamethrower.

The setting is pretty unique, and i've enjoyed it quite a lot. Seeing the rivalry between magick and tech was a tease every time, because i couldn't stop thinking about my next run, and how i would pursue magick that time around.

To me, the only lackluster aspect of the game was it's companion system. I have no issue with companion slots being "locked" behind you charisma and persuasion stats, but i've felt that the individual companions were way too silent for my taste, besides some minor things like magnus saying "hey, gimme that" when you take his book or gloves, or any of the companions congratulating you for a critical hit.

With all that said, i definetly recommend Arcanum, in fact, it has become one of my all-time favorites.
But beware, the game is indeed very old and dated, you'll have to do some tinkering with the files for it to run smootly. 
And being a old game, it isn't afraid to beat you senseless for lack of knowledge or preparation.

Dito isto, vamos falar do elefante na sala: o jogo √© velho, do jeito bom e do jeito ruim.

Este jogo √© absurdamente bem escrito e seu cen√°rio √© um dos melhores, mais √∫nicos e mais criativos por ai, mas algumas mec√¢nicas do jogo s√£o praticamente conhecimento esot√©rico. Eu joguei de an√£o tecnologista na minha primeira vez, e eu sinto que esse √© uma das maneiras """can√¥nicas""" de jogar, o que aumentou muito minha imers√£o e interesse no plot principal, e falando de imers√£o, arcanum n√£o tem medo de realmente enfatizar algumas coisas. 

Como eu estava jogando de an√£o, boa parte dos cidad√£o de Arcanum n√£o iam muito com a minha cara (a n√£o ser que eu estivesse usando uma cartola e terno caro, pra parecer rico) e eles n√£o tinham medo de demonstrar isso, chegaram at√© a me cobrar um extra quando fui alugar um quarto em uma estalagem, falando que esse ouro era pra pagar o tempo de limpar o quarto, j√° que eu ia encher tudo de pulga e piolho.

O cen√°rio √© realmente √∫nico, e ver a constante rivalidade entre magia e tecnologia me fez pensar em minha pr√≥xima jogatina, onde iria focar em magia para ver a diferen√ßa

Pra mim, o √∫nico aspecto paia do jogo s√£o os companions, n√£o tenho problema com as "vagas" de companion serem desbloqueadas quando voc√™ upa seu carisma e persuas√£o, mas eu achei eles muito silenciosos pro meu gosto, tirando algumas ocasi√µes menores, tipo o magnus falando "ei, me devolve isso" quando voc√™ pega o livro ou luvas dele, ou algum dos companions te parabenizando depois de um ataque cr√≠tico.

This game is one of my all time most loved games. A true classic GEM! 

I will preface the review with a short note. This game being from the old days comes with some good and some bad things. And most of this is biased but thats how it goes with reviews I guess.

The good - 
1) Atmosphere / Music - really gets you immersed into the game.
2) LOADS of sidequests - even after years of playing the game I still havent done all of them.
3) Interesting game mechanics like Magic vs Tech and Good vs Evil.
4) Story/lore is well made - Character development is good, companions are interesting and you start to care about them.
5) Art style - it just clicks with my tastes 

Bad (in some sense) - 
1) No tutorial (forces you to read and explore)  - Means that the new players can have struggles with some mechanics, builds, quests. Some things in game just requires you to either know how to do things OR reading manual / google.  On the good side - there are good resources out there with walktroughs and overall I consider its a sort of benefit that the game forces you to explore and not rush trough it. And I would encourage ppl going in blind and just do things for first few playtroughs without trying to "finish" the game.

2) Dated graphics / Gliches - not much to be said about this - just old game will be old game. If you dig the retro feel / art style - then its not gonna bother you.


Overall I highly recommed giving this game a try. Yes it has quirks and occasional headscraching moment. BUT if you vibe with it - this game will be well worth the money.

I still have the original disks in storage. I bought this game new in 2001 on release and I loved it then as I do now. The setting was intriguing, the mechanics amazing and the possibilities endless! I used to sit with a notebook and work out the optimum leveling schemes for different characters. 

However that was 23 years ago, and while the setting, story, systems and characters are still amazing there are some things that need addressing:

Cons:
- The game is Janky as all hell, expect bugs, crashes, glitches etc. it was janky on release and while a lot of work has been done under the hood over the years performance remains sub optimal, there is some tweaking and compatibility settings to futz with in order to get the game running smooth, but thankfully the guides to do so are easily findable here on steam.

- Music is moody and atmospheric, but there isn't a great amount of variety, by the end you will hear violins when you close your eyes.

Neutral observations:
-+ The game does not hold your hand, if you are not paying attention you can screw up quests or build an unworkable character. This isn't a drawback to me but, I have been playing this game for almost 2 decades so please do read the manual before playing.

Pros:
+ The world is your oyster: The amount of customization and character builds available to you is staggering, everything from a Gunslinging Diplomat to a Mage who can teleport across continents and disintegrate foes with a flick of a wrist, to a neutral Melee build.

+ Characters and Quests are unique and well fleshed out, a lot of the dialogue is funny but be prepared to read as very few characters are voiced.

+ Setting: Fantasy world brought kicking and screaming into the industrial age, Magick vs. technology is a major theme in the game, in addition there are many philosophical ideas discussed and expounded by the various characters and very few are one dimensional, even the BBEG who you are fighting makes a compelling case for his actions!

+ You can recruit a dog and he is a good boy.

In conclusion:

If you enjoyed the original Fallout games (Same creator) there is a lot of their DNA in this game and it is a really great time, but please do be prepared for a certain amount of jank, I know there are fan patches but IDK how compatible they are with the steam version and now that I have done the main campaign after installing I will start screwing around with mods/patches. I bought this game on sale and paid like 1$ if it goes on sale again buy it! I highly recommend it regardless but I also have a great deal of nostalgia for the title so YMMV.
One of the best RPG's of all time.
Game amazing. Bought on PC as a child. Bought on GOG as an adult. Not sure when I bought it on steam. Excellent game, do recommend. Play for story, not for graphics.

The roleplay options here are excellent. Playing as a character with low intelligence or beauty make for hilarious encounters. I think this game might have been a turning point in my life where I decided to expand my vocabulary so I could insult someone in the manner of a 19th century gentleman attempting to induce his interlocutor into a duel. The kill animations can be extremely gory too. Nothing like being an ugly but intelligent half-ogre cutting a racist constable in half with an axe after calling him a simpering fool whose wife is of questionable fidelity to him.
best crpg made to date, and desperately needs a remake on new platforms.
the game that made me fall in love with games as a kid.

If you are one of those players who prefer Morrowind over Skyrim for its superior worldbuilding and plot, while being able to enjoy it despite its aged graphics, this will be right up your alley. This game, at least to me, feels more like you are playing a great TTRPG than the early Baldurs Gate titles. One of my all time favourite games.

Amazing, but repetitive soundtrack. Prerendered graphics have aged ok. Game mechanics work well as long as you activate turn based combat in the options.

Some reviews mention the game being unplayable. This is easily fixed by Drogs Unofficial Arcanum Patch. You can even increase the games resolution by editing the "config.ini" in the "HighRes" folder. After that, you need to run the "_install.bat".

This game is great.

An additional specific issue for the increasing number of Linux players like myself: it takes a lot of effort to get this running well on Linux, especially if you want to use the unofficial patch. I'd like the Steam release to come with settings that actually work out of the box, patch or not.

Amazing game with a very unique setting and mechanics as far as tech vs magic. You will most likely need mods to get it running on a modern computer but it isn't too complex. Despite its age you can tell they put allot of detail into the world and the decisions you can make and how they will impact the story. They tried doing things even modern games don't to and some of it works (being able to use charisma and speech for almost any situation even big battles/ random events that you wouldn't expect. Or how people will speak differently to you depending on your race/ intelligence) and some of it is kinda janky (being able to cycle between real time and turn based combat mid fight) but all in all I would say it still stands up in many ways in 2024 especially if you're looking for a good story with a very unique setting

I've played this game long before Steam was a thing, and it's been a blast. Recently re-played it and amazingly enough, barring some technical complications, (mostly compatibility due to its venerable age) the game aged very well, as well made story-based games tend to. Troika Games was founded by the key figures involved at the roots of Fallout series and you can see the same irreverent humor freely mingling with deep introspection on nature of humanity and reality under its flashy veneer of technomagic conflict.
God-tier game, probably timeless.

Old but Gold!

Once you get past the interface's general clunkiness, the game actually offers a lot more to its player base than it would first appear, and actually accomplishes something that many games do not: properly balance its different combat systems. Furthermore, the overarching themes of the story are very much ahead of their time, dipping very frequently into characters that were simply dealt a bad hand in life, and had to make the most of their circumstances in this gritty steampunk fantasy world. 

If I had only two complaints, they are that the game does not offer nearly enough to its more economically savy nor charismatic players, and that the gendered structure of the game means it failed to be ahead of its time in a different sense of the term.

I played this a lot in my childhood. Together with BG3 this is my favorite CRPG. You can do so much in the game, it's open world and you have freedom to go wherever you want. There are so many different builds and playstyles you can do a lot of completely different playthroughs. You can be megic, technology, fighter, talker, good, evil, dumb, smart, and much more. And they are all fun in their own ways, and most importantly they are very different.

Steampunk setting is fun. There is a lot of in game racism that adds another dimension to the game. Your race matters, your beauty, intelligence matters. It matters if you prefer technology or magic. It matters if you are good or evil. Everything matters and this makes it so fun.

Make sure to right away go to settings and switch to turn based combat. Real time just doesn't work well for this type of game. 

While I didn't play much on Steam, I have to say it worked perfectly for me with the unofficial patch on windows 11. I probably had like 500 hours on this game back in the day.

You might be looking at this thinking ‚Äòhuh, I like old school RPGs and somehow I never heard of this one, maybe it‚Äôs worth a shot‚Äô.

And you can be forgiven for thinking that, because Arcanum has a unique setting, a striking visual art style, and an amazing soundtrack. There‚Äôs a lot of really cool stuff on display here, and for 2001, it was incredibly ambitious. Heck, the manual that comes with the game [i]alone[/i] is a work of art. 

Unfortunately, there‚Äôs a reason that Troika went bankrupt. The execution is utterly abysmal. Arcanum is buggy and janky, with terrible balance and linear gameplay. The unofficial patch fixes literally hundreds of bugs, but it can‚Äôt save you from poor design. Combat, world navigation, character building, inventory management - it's all bad, underwhelming at best and actively annoying at worst.

To make matters worse, the Steam port appears to be a janky port of a janky game. Windowed mode is not on the table, and the game glitches or crashes at the drop of a hat. Again, you can spend a few hours modding your way out of some of these issues if you‚Äôre determined, but who wants to do that? Products you have to spend hours making work are bad products.

Though it has a small cohort of die-hard fans, Arcanum faded into obscurity for a reason. The game has issues, and those issues have only grown more obvious with age. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it.
Oh my god, this is probably one of the best CRPGs I've ever played, and I've just started. Not that I've played many, but still. I'm comparing it to OG Fallout and Baldur's Gate 3.

I used UAP and Universal setup off Nexus and was able to get in about 50 hours of playtime on windows 11 with only a single crash, mainly from alt+tabbing so much.

Highly recommend a playthrough. Might be tough to get into at first, especially if you haven't played Fallout 1 or 2, if you have you'll be right at home.

you will find that the majority of negative reviews for Arcanum grasp at things such as inventory design or combat without any mention of the characters, quest design or quality of world-building, which in my opinion overpower the negative aspects. the game world feels richer and more alive to me than newer RPG worlds in 1080p with full voice acting. 
it's true that the combat is ass but you don't play Arcanum for the gameplay, you play it for the writing and atmosphere :-)

Arcanum is a flawed yet incredibly fun rpg. The over arching story and in depth world really sucks you in and allows you to explore an interesting place with many possibilities. The game feels like a mix of DND, lord of the rings, and steam punk, in the body of the OG fallouts. It really cant be overstated how interesting the dynamics of the world are, the conflict of technology vs magic and the slow uncovering of a grand conspiracy. 

How ever there is a lot to not like about the game. To start, the game doesn't work out the box and you have to add a unofficial patch to get it to work.(look up 2 Headed Hero on youtube for how to get everything set up) Even then i experienced intermediate crashing and bugs here and there but i cant imagine how it would run without the patch. Next the game looks kinda ugly and feels dated, even for 2001. I wish it had some of the charming look for characters that fallout 1 and 2 has. The combat can be pretty intimidating at first but once you learn to switch between normal and turn based combat it feels better. Lastly my biggest criticism is the leveling and quests. We are spoiled now a days with rerollable characters and quest markers, this game has neither. You MUST play one type of character and one only otherwise when you get to the end your not gonna have a fun time. Quests also DONT have markers, so your gonna have to read everything and remember clues you may have picked up on to complete quests, no mindless running around to complete tasks here.

Over all, Arcanum IS worth playing if your not a zoomer with a 5 sec attention span and can get past old ass computer game jank.

the story line still holds up, the problem is the software has not been updated to run on modern machines and the current mods (almost like a mage trying to use a pistol) or process is too involved to me to invest the time.  I would love to see one of the larger companies pick this game up and either give it an overhaul for an anniversary edition or move on to create Arcanum 2.  it is a shame, like I mentioned the story line and style were fun, back in the day.

DISCLAIMER: DO NOT PAY ATTENTION TO MY PLAY TIME WITH STEAM. AS WITH EVERYONE ELSE, I, TOO, HAVE UTILIZED THE UAP. 
This game is very enjoyable. The world feels so alive. Decisions you make with building your character impacts how people interact with you. Although interaction in general is rather limited due to the game being made a while back, the interactions present themselves in a way that at least feels tangible. Where in Skyrim, the game's NPCs may look at your gear or race (or things you did in your playthrough as seen in the ending) and make some remark on those traits, the character choices you make in Arcanum will make everyone react to you differently. If you choose to be an ogre, not only will everyone look down upon you in general due to the reduction in Beauty that ogres get at a base by bringing it up immediately in a derogatory way, but also you will be limited to large armor sets, which may become a case where you must go on a hunt for armor that fits you. Speaking of gear, there are mainly 5 different ways of attacking in this game, with those being Melee, Bows, Guns, Throwing, and Magic. There is also some things you can do with tech to place traps and mechanical creatures, but, although I have not tried it yet, it is likely similar to the summoning tree with magic, so I will look upon it as such. Though I have not tried Throwing much yet, I can speak on all of the other ones in saying that although Bows are the most powerful, each of the others can be fun to play too. Rather than explain any of this, it would be  better if you played for yourself to determine how you want to play. That is the fun of the game; the large amount of different styles you can play held within a seemingly small interface. This game has some jank that will be cause for making the player reload a previous save, so remember to save. I have had several encounters where either my companion or an enemy will just walk off the screen and even through walls. Also, do take care in not pushing Del + Enter in an instantaneous fashion while in the load screen. Though it may be a stupid thing for me to remark on, I did it twice when trying to load saves, and there is no back up unless you make one. Still kept playing the game though.

This game is not just a game, it's a brilliant artistic masterpiece, rich and full of depth. We rarely see games like this anymore. It's truly a classic, worth it all the way. Just make sure you download the unofficial patch that makes it playable in modern times. There's a reason this game has a cult following. One day we will see a sequel, I hope.

It's a good game but most builds aren't viable at the start of the game which is a huge limiting factor. You can make whatever character you want but whatever character you make might not last for very long so the game only gives an illusion of many options to choose from. A lot of spells aren't as useful as they're described to be. For example, Flash doesn't do much to stop an attacker even though it blinds them. They can still hit you easily. How is that realistic or fair? But even with the limited viable builds, you can still play two or three runs without getting too bored. Just maybe do some research first on what works and what doesn't.

Played this game a lot back when I was younger, the gameplay hasn't aged all that well, but I honestly just bought and downloaded this to hear that music naively one more time. This game has one of the greatest themes of all time and the atmosphere is just top-notch. If you're cool with some old-school RPG gameplay that has some insane role-play to it but slower than modern stuff that's come out in the last decade, then this will be a real treat for you.

The story, writing, characters and world-building in the game are very good, but not the best I've ever seen. However the combat is so bad, so unbalanced and so frequent that it overwrites anything other concern, making it impossible for me to recommend. Also it does not run natively in modern resolutions, making it functionally unplayable without unofficial patches.

Arcanum is an old RPG game with a completely unique world - if you know "the dark eye/das schwarze Auge" or other well designed tabletop games, then you understand the depth you can expect. The journey will lead you all over the world finding a lot of adventures, stories and hidden secrets on the way, while the main plot is always what drives you forward (at the first playthrough) with a good deal of tension and creativity.

My recommendation (after more then hundred hours over two decades):  An amazing world that is enthralling, with a atmosphere you will find no where else - but the game is not for everyone, even RPG players may not like it, and that is because of some pain points, The old and suboptimal pathfinding and other Userinterface issues, especially the rather bad version presented here in steam does carry on what the community already fixed - more about that at the end, as well as some notes for anyone who want to give this game a try. Arcanum is old, but you can see that this game has a won the hearts of people as the community has a lot of enthusiastic fans.

Details (steam version without community patch): 
Arcanum is a unique game because of its complete worldsetting, including religion and magic theories a compley story, a melancholic atmosphere and beautiful cello music. Content wise the game is a gem! But the tools to go through the story are a bit rough, i mean the game controls, fighting system, not smooth pathfinding (or getting blocked by something) and default options. Especially the battles that feel like lightningspeed while heavy to control are sometimes frustrating if you forgot to save for a while. And you get not much information about the game systems within the game, so planning out your character is hard unless you read the manual (you should!). The complexity of the game is a challange at first - though it is what makes the game brilliant.
If you get through the start issues, keeping your belief in the game alive, you will find a game world like no other. If you think about how good this game may have felt 20 years ago (or earlier) you may understand the Arcanum fans still holding strong for this game. 
-> The complex skill system, 
-> complex character building aside from just skills, including good/evil 
-> the choices if you become mage or technician, 
-> the struggles every choice brings you in terms of not having access to other skills or not beeing liked by others for those choices - that are what makes Arcanum special. Aside from a 
-> elaborated and consistent story, worldsetting, missions, mythology and more.

Sample choices for playstyles:
-> Using Charisma as a leader - having your group members do the fights
-> Lockpicking, the way of the thief - getting good things without the need to risk your life in battle
-> Fighter, just crush everyone
-> Persuade instead of fighting
....

there are so many ways to play this game ...and of course mess up. So always do a lot of saves! And for the start make sure you play the game on easy mode (switch it in the options menu, by default it seems to be medium).

Especially if you play a smart vs. a dumb charackter you will notice a lot of different dialogue options which are fun - if you like reading.

If you are a game developer, think about getting this game to study it. Otherwise, think about if you want to have fun or a challange - if it is the latter and you enjoy melancholy and a world full of troubles, go for it. I wish you good luck and have fun.

You got the game? 
1) Then adjust the game to new standards first! Change the "SierraLauncher.ini" content in the SteamLibrary Arcanum Folder on your harddrive. Edit the line with Game1Cmd= to: "Game1Cmd= -no3d -doublebuffer" The keywords -scrolldist:0 and -scrollfps:30 may upgrade your experience further - thanks to Bluebreak for this hints (see the Arcanum Community Hub).
2) So if you want to enjoy Arcanum, think about getting the inofficial community patch which solves a good deal of problems - though this will mean, you need a shortcut and can not start it via steam directly. A well worth sacrifice in my opinion. Maybe you can skip step 1 as well.

Have fun trying out a lot of things in the game and/or join the community.

Arcanum: of Steamworks and Magick Obsucra is a late 90s isometric computer role playing game (crpg).  What set this game apart is the duality of magic and technology along with an actual 1:1 play area of the much quicker to travel map.  As well as the ability to toggle between real-time and turn based combat. 

While I haven't played much of this here on Steam, I played a few hundred hours on the original disk way back when it came out.  The game starts like most rpgs with you building a character.  The game is technically with out classes in the rpg sense, but I found not following a theme leads to a character that will struggle, if not outright preventing seeing very far in the game.

Concerning magick and technology, these are diametrically opposed.  The more of your character to sink into one the less the other can be used.  And the game doesn't like half measures.  So it's recommend go all in tech or all in magick.  I feel magick is much easier at the beginning of the game but wanes and often becomes inconvenient as power magick users disrupt tech and are barred from aspects of the game.  Likewise tech is tough to start as the player needs crafting materials and plans to make their inventions.  But as the plans and tech stack up, tech becomes much easier.

Of course the player can for go magick and tech, going for a more tradition fighter or rogue type.  But even there, the player is going to  want to make early tough choices on going melee or ranged focused.  I suppose a social character is possible, but I find that secondary to being able to handle combat as it is pretty unavoidable at some point.  

The actual game is a little hand-holdy (but no less challenging) as it restricts the player to a relatively small area to get them familiar with the game and managing NPC party members.  This includes a power check to get out of this area to experience the wider game.  Like other rpgs of the time, it can be slow going to scrape together tools and skills needed to progress.  If a player is not prepared for combat, it can and will go south on them very quickly.

However, if the player can get past that initial slow, rough spot; it becomes far more enjoyable.  The mysteries to solve, lands to explore, people to meet and tons of tasks to accomplish.  I will admit for as many hours that I've put into this game, I never did finish it. Don't know if I ever will as Arcanum is more involved than most games I want to sink my teeth into these days.

But it is an excellent game for anyone looking to spend tens of hours in a classic crpg.

Fantasy equivalent of Fallout 1 or Fallout 2. Very well done. Lots of cool hidden functions and alternative ways to solve problems. Good sandbox adventure style RPG. Good, evil, and neutral sandbox options well explored. Open world without lots of loading screens. Has options for real time and turn based combat. Classless character design with lots of customization. Great game, lots to explore. 

That said, if you've never played old PC RPGs before, and want a modern understanding: This game is equal in quality to a very well done RPG maker game. Yes, it very pre-dates those, but treating it as if it were made recently, that is what it is.

Of minor concern, game has pretty major compatibility issues with win 10, so need to install 3rd party patches to make it run. Once installed, works really great. No problems at all. 

Beyond that, game is unusual when compared to modern RPGs in that gender greatly determines game options even at the character creation level, and further, there are very few non-white character portrait options (and the non-white ones are for green orcs and such, not other human ethnicity). No gay options either. Makes for a very in-setting character creation, but if looking for these modern features/political correctness in your RPGs, it lacks them. There's even a built in "dumb dialog" for characters with lacking intelligence (which could be construed as mocking the mentally handicapped) and slurred speech for inebriated characters.

Oh, regarding the ESRB rating, yes, it should be Mature in the sense that it checks the boxes that qualify, but it isn't really a mature game in the modern sense. Probably closer to Teen, these days. Graphics are rather cartoony compared to modern games. "Blood" is present, but looks more like red paint spills and little red sparks and sometimes limbs fall off in a very cartoonish way. There is lots of violence, but it's like a chess level of violence. There is swearing, but not swearing for the sake of swearing (some modern games seem to do this). There is only avoidable & consensual sex (which is described/implied but not animated). There is slavery and also unfair working conditions. There is drug use (potions, poison, medicine, and alcohol, plus implied tobacco use). It does satire religion, features a polytheistic setting, and not really give any credibility to their "gods" or the faithful. There are demons within the setting. The player is allowed to play an evil character: kill, steal, use necromancy, and otherwise commit crimes/sins. And the setting is very heavy in racism (between the fictional fantasy races, not between skin tones).

Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura was the first game from Troika Games, an outfit formed by Tim Cain, Leonard Boyarsky and Jason Anderson, who all worked on Fallout 2 at Interplay.

It's an isometric RPG set in a steampunk/fantasy world, and plays a lot like the Infinity Engine games (Baldur's Gate 1 & 2, Icewind Dale 1 & 2), but with some significant differences.  For example, it does not use the D&D ruleset, and the combination of magic and technology means there are interesting locations, items and different ways to solve quests.

Make sure to apply the unofficial patch before playing, as the game was released with a bunch of bugs.

This game is janky and has combat that somehow manages to be unfair both against and in favor of the player, particularly early on. I needed to install an unofficial patch and mess around with the launch settings to get it to run properly. It crashed multiple times. Combat for an early-game mage revolved entirely around spamming the Harm spell and hoping you didn't run out of fatigue, then leaving the dungeon, recovering, and going back in until you ran low on fatigue again. The soundtrack is entirely performed by a string quartet, which is a cool concept but gets old pretty quickly. The mere thought of Magnus Shalefist makes me want to start a new file specifically so I can disintegrate him before he opens his mouth. 

Normally, I wouldn't give this a negative review because, if I had decided to stick with a game like this, I'd have chucked my computer out the window and wouldn't be able to access Steam.

However, the depth and openness of the world, the little twists and turns in the story, the rather innovative (for the time, anyway) setting, and the sense that you could play this game over and over again and only scratch its surface, more than make up for its myriad faults. I just finished the game, and I kinda wanna start it all over again. 

If I give into the temptation, then buddy, Shalefist better watch his godsforsaken back.
GOOD RPG STORY
Amazing RPG trapped in a painfully mediocre game.

An all time isometric classic with a ton of content and replayability.
