No words to describe this game and the world it's set in.
Granted, what you probably heard elsewhere about it's flaws is 100% true:
-Combat wise this is by far (and i mean BY FAR) the worst Crpg ever probably...it's clunky as hell even with tons of patching and modding, the turn based mode barely works while real time is completely broken and exploitable (the spell "harm", even at level 1, can be spammed as fast as you can click your mouse...that's borderline access to infinite damage right away)
-It's still pretty buggy even after all these years, tho likely stuff that breaks quests/progression is fairly rare, and in my multiple playthroughs throughout the years i only got stuck once (so yeah..it's one of those games where you keep around 10 save files and keep cycling through them in case the last 1 or 2 break..)
-The world backgrounds and locales, while they create a very unique and interesting world, feel kinda sparse compared to other Crpgs from the same era like Fallout 1, Baldur's Gate and Planescape Torment or even more obscure stuff like Ruins of Mythdranor...it's weird to describe, but i ve always felt as if places like the initial crash site look like someone threw a bunch of lego pieces on a grass-earth looking background.
-I reccomend further modding + not launching it directly from Steam to avoid various technical problems (years ago i wrote a guide on how to optimize the game, but it was for the original version, and doesnt apply to Steam/GoG versions, which have their own problems..)

...and yet, despite all these major flaws, this is to this day one of the best Crpgs you can play.
It drags you into a story and a setting like no other, with a maniacal attention to lore and detail that has rarely been replicated (highly reccomend reading the gigantic manual just to have a taste) and the ability to build the type of character you want is staggering even today, and to put it simply..there has never been another game that quite feels like it, and the story toward the end takes a completely unexpected but welcomed turn.
The definition of an extremely flawed masterpiece

A great blast from the past for people with a taste for complex CRPGs, which is also capable of annoying you to death if you are not used to old games. Arcanum is set in the 1880s in a fictional world bearing the same name. A place torn by the wars between the Cumbrian kingdom and UK (Unified Kingdom). Steam locomotives are piercing the continent while people are figuring out how to adapt to the post-war rise of technology. Industrialization has left many agrarian cities abandoned, creating wider economic gaps between the common people and nobles. A socio-cultural and physical conflict between two forces has divided people even further. The older unnatural forces of Magick clash with the new Technology, which conversely lends the principle of Natural Law. This is the first choice you have to make as you create your character in Arcanum. 

The classless system, 16 skills, 16 spell colleges, and 8 tech disciplines (all broken down into multiple degrees) allow for huge flexibility in character progressions. Due to the aptitude scale your main decision will boil down to either going the magick or tech route. (Although I've seen hybrid technomage builds circulating online.) For my first playthrough, I went with a charismatic mage that relies on followers doing the hard work while I blast spells from the sidelines. If you are struggling with choosing a path, you can never go wrong with a simple melee built with high Charisma (with Persuasion skill) and decent Intellect. The melee focus will help you survive, and the social skills/stats will allow for a fun playthrough with interesting dialogue options and companions' support. 

Your voyage starts on the board of a blimp attacked by kamikaze orcs. A few moments later, you find yourself in the foothills of the Stonewall Range, being the only survivor of the crash. You are given a mysterious ring and a dreadful warning about the end of the world. Charged with the mission to find the origin of the artifact, you start your journey. 

You are introduced to the world of Arcanum ‚Äî a cut-throat steampunk (kind of.. but more on that in a bit), cultural hodgepodge brimming with intrigue, violence, and racism. If you have played any other vanilla D&D games, the races will feel familiar, except for the half-ogres. The only difference is that everybody hates everybody in Arcanum. My little gnome character was socially annihilated from the very first moment I met NPCs. Here, even halflings are not tolerant of other creatures of small stature. 

Although set in a fiction world, the in-game year alludes to the setting being a typical Victorian-era steampunk. That's where my first minor pet peeve comes with the game. 19th-century Victorian architecture is characterized by its steeped roofs, brick walls, turrets, verandas, and fireplaces. The buildings in Arcanum, with their flat rooftops, cement walls, and clean lines, resemble more of a 20th-century industrialism. The fashion in the game doesn't help with that, as most suits look like tailored for 1940s mobsters. I get it; it is a fantasy world, so who says it has to be your typical steampunk, but it's just hard for me to grasp the vibe of the setting due to the unclear visuals and graphics limitations of the time. Put in other words, visually, the game never felt like steampunk to me and just lacked solid art direction to solidify the depth of the world. 

That leads us to the next big issue of Arcanum: the poor and unclear UI. While the system is not abhorrently difficult to get the hang of, you'd need to play Arcanum with a manual, a glossary to understand all of the abbreviations and unexplained mechanics, and a map, as some locations are hard to find unless you have the pdf map and force walk to specific coordinates. Words like MSR, FT, NP, MA are a staple of the game interface, yet no tooltips are provided to explain what the same mean. Minimum Strength Required, Fatigue, Noise Penalty, and Magical Aptitude. Some stats like Total attack and Total defense are kept nebulous even in the manual, and I couldn't find any explanation anywhere else as to how these are calculated. Tip: The GOG version of Arcanum comes with all of the collateral resources needed to play the game more smoothly (like the high-res map), so it's worth checking it out. That said, the Steam copy also has the manual if you look into your steamapps folder of Arcanum. 

The movement and pathfinding in the game are the worst I have experienced on Windows (not counting old DOS games). Not being able to click beyond a certain point and being forced to draw a waypoint line with a limited number of points (as the easier alternative to rage-clicking across the map) is annoying as hell. I remember playing games from this era. Baldur's Gate 2 was launched in 2000, one year earlier than Arcanum, and I can't recall experiencing such issues with UI/movement. 

The combat is super frantic. With not-so-obvious action point indications, tracking what's going on is hard, even in turn-based mode.

If you are able to overlook and get used to the outdated graphics, uncomfortable UI, and lack of important quality-of-life features, you'll love Arcanum. It's an epic adventure with all of the ingredients of a great CRPG: a good story, a complex character system, fight/cunning/wits quest-solving, and unmatchable reactivity of the world based on your character choices. 

Before you start the game:

[list]
    [*]Download the manual and the guide from Prima available for free via archive.org
    [*]Download and install the unofficial patch to fix resolution and bugs. Read the readme file and enable infinite scrolling.
    [*]Make sure running is turned on by default.
[/list]

Tips for playing the game:

[list]
    [*]It's likely your first character(s) will be sh*t. Do a test run until you figure out your build.
  [*]Recruit Virgil, at least for your maiden run. He provides a lot of context for the main story arc, as well as much-needed healing and poison halt spells.
  [*]Save as often as you can and in new slots, especially before traveling. Random encounters during travels can often be unbalanced.
  [*]When looting bodies, make sure to take their equipped items, too. These will not show in the default loot bag; you need to click on the circle body icon next to the bag icon or the red arrow to collect all items. Only when it says that there's nothing to loot it means there's nothing to loot from the body.
  [*]If a stat shows red the two most common culprits are an item that reduces the stat (a helm, for example) or a condition like scarred, which can reduce your beauty. You can find your conditions in the Kills & Injuries log
  [*]Advancing time does not heal HP, but you can sleep in the outskirts of any town for free which would recover HP.
  [*]There are generally 3 ways to solve quests, especially as pertaining to the main arc - slay, steal, or persuade (also known as force/wits/stealth in game design). You need good damage input, pickpocketing, or persuasion skills, respectively.  
 [*]You don't need to focus on one single approach, but if you are bad at all three, you'd have a hard time.
[/list]

Since I played as a mage, here are some tips for magick users:

[list]
[*]Most important stats for mages are WP and DX - the first increases fatigue, and second your action points, so both help you cast more spells faster during combat without falling unconscious. 
[*]You don't need more than 12 IN. The rest of the stats will depend on your liking and build bug; generally, PE is a dump stat. If you want to build a charismatic leader, focus on CH. For battle mages, you can focus on ST and DX. 
[*]MA is critical for your mage. The higher it is, the more dmg you score with dmg spells. To increase it you can start with an Elf and learn more spells.
[*] The best dmg dealing spells are Harm (single enemy) and Fireflash (AOE). Utility spells like teleport and unlock cantrip are critical in making your life easier.
[/list]

Every time I replay this game, I am shocked by how much content it has and how much love went into it.

It has a rather unusual setting: a traditional fantasy world undergoing an industrial revolution, with technology and magic reacting violently to one another. And yet, this setting is somehow made to feel realistic. Disgruntled mages riding at the back of the train (far from the engine), exploited half-orc factory workers fighting to unionize, the gnome oligarchy controlling things behind the scenes, conservative nations failing to adapt to the rise of technology, scientists and explorers trying to make sense of the world, multiple conspiracies, it's all there and it works fantastically well.

The world is almost entirely open almost right away (there's a "tutorial" town), and everywhere you go, tons and tons of quests. Almost all of them with multiple ways to solve them, and often related to other quests or characters in a way that makes the world feel more consistent. With sufficient intelligence, charisma and persuasion, you can talk your way out of almost anything, including the last boss. It's often integrated to game mechanics, too: if you want Master training in Persuasion, you don't simply pay the trainer... no, you'll instead be asked to negotiate with another nation about joining the union and given a book detailing possible compromises and outcomes on ten different negotiation points, which you'll have to take to a council and adjust your position during negotiations to get as much as you can while still getting to an agreement. There's a quest for each of the 16 skill masteries and there's always a catch. Sometimes a really big one, such as the Dodge Master requiring you to kill the Melee Master, and possibly rescue the woman they're both fighting over. That's how deep they took things.

At the time of this writing, the game is over two decades old. There's an unofficial patch that makes it run fine and fixes bugs that made it into the release version of the game. The game itself is a little clunky mechanically speaking, but still very much playable, especially since you can switch between Real Time and Turn-Based combat to suit the encounter.

Truly an amazing game. There will never be another like it, no one has the patience or the passion.
I find the racism mechanics to be interesting. It affects gameplay and encounters based on which race is being picked. The combat leaves much to be desired, and I enjoy picking locks.

One of my favorite games of all time, Arcanum melds classic RPG characteristics with classic PC gaming characteristics, bundled into a package of poor graphics and an engine that wasn't designed with the future in mind. There's a few mods out there that improve the gameplay and performance quite a bit, but I truly do wish there was a bigger presence for modding, or even the possibility of a remaster. Alas, if you're looking for something inexpensive to waste an hour or four on, this game is for you.

Patching and character design, reading the manual and walkthroughs took more time for me than the actual playing. As a player I felt lost and without walkthroughs wouldn't have seen more than a third of the game. Somehow for me immersion was lacking. Mostly due to very scarce voice acting and interaction/dialogue possibilities with NPCs/Companions (I played a mage with high IN/CH/WP and a big party). I recommend to play it in multiplayer mode with some friends.

What a wild RPG. I play this and really miss Troika as a studio. They never really ever had the time, budget, or luxury to make the games they wanted to make. 

Arcanum is definitely one of those flawed precious stones you find while slogging through a Sierre Leone blood diamond mining operation knee deep in mud and gore. 

Lucky for us, this rough hewn gem is the size of a car. It‚Äôs flawed. It has systems that make no sense. There‚Äôs hardly anything user friendly. Most importantly it‚Äôs one of the jankiest games you‚Äôll play. BUT. It‚Äôs one of the rarest forms of rpgs out there, the kind that really let you roleplay with a capital R. 

The builds are limitless, the way the game responds to you as a character in its world are boundless, and it does something that other games can only dream of - give you true choice and consequence. Sure, most of it is superficial and you‚Äôre just going to end up doing the things it wants you to do anyway, but how you get there is all up to you. 

I like this game, but it‚Äôs definitely not for everyone. It‚Äôs a game that will probably never have a follow up in a world that deserves at least two more entries. It‚Äôs the Firefly of RPGs. If you can get past this, it‚Äôs one of the long lost forgotten entries in the RPG genre that may have you staring at your ceiling at night wishing beyond hope for a sequel.

It‚Äôs really unique and one of a kind. 

I will never play another RPG quite like it ever again, and that whimsically forlorn sentiment keeps bringing me back time and time again.

Try it, you may like it, you may hate it.
The gameplay is kind of clunky, but the writing makes up for it. Save often.

[h1]"There are times when destiny calls forth a man...and it is up to him to answer that call. Are you ready for this?"[/h1]
Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura is a role-playing game set in a fantasy world where magic and technology coexist, but are often in conflict. The game has been praised for its original setting, rich story, and complex character creation system. However, it has also been criticised for its technical issues, outdated graphics, and unbalanced gameplay.

The world of Arcanum is unique - it combines elements of steampunk, Victorian era, and high fantasy to create a diverse and immersive environment. The player can encounter elves, dwarves, orcs, gnomes, vampires, werewolves, and more in different regions of the world, while also having a wide variety of character customisation in terms of starting race/gender etc. Each race has its own strengths and weaknesses, and each background has significant bonuses as well as drawbacks. The game also explores the themes of racism, classism, industrialisation, and religion through its various factions and characters. You can choose to align with either magic or technology, which affects skills, abilities, and reputation. Magic users can cast spells from different schools of magic, such as fire, necromancy, or summoning. Technology users can craft and use various gadgets, such as guns, bombs, or automatons. The game also features a morality system that tracks the player's actions and consequences. Depending on their choices, the player can become good or evil, lawful or chaotic (alignment will also affect NPC responses and in some cases, which companions are willing to join your party).

The game also boasts a rich story that is influenced by the player's decisions. The main plot revolves around the player being the sole survivor of a zeppelin crash that was caused by a mysterious assassin. The player then learns that they are the reincarnation of an ancient hero who once saved the world from a powerful evil. Along the way, the player can recruit up to seven companions who have their own personalities and backgrounds. There are multiple endings depending on the player's actions and alignment (combine this with the widely varied starting race/background, and replayability is very high indeed).

However, Arcanum is not without its flaws. The game suffers from many technical issues that affect its performance and stability. It game is prone to crashing, freezing, or glitching at random moments (ALT-TAB is a lottery most of the time, and I suffered from the notorious slowdown which really made it quite painful). The game also has many bugs that can break quests or cause other problems - some of which can be solved by installing UAP. Ideally, before beginning, you will want to run through the links and process on this most helpful post ([url]https://www.reddit.com/r/arcanum/comments/s0vuib/arcanum_patches_for_new_players/[/url]) (in fact, you may need to do so to get the game to run in the first place). I had to install version 2.0.2 of the UAP in order to play the game, and as a result of the difficulties I faced I was unwilling to fiddle around to resolve the slowdown bug. If your luck is better than mine, the below may come in handy if you encounter this (all credit to OP):
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=755396888
Before you begin playing, you may also want to make use of the below two guides (all credit to respective OPs):
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2311393823
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=755978234
The game is quite complex and it will help to familiarise yourself with some of the mechanics before diving in.

Finally, many of the files as well as extras are hosted at [url]https://terra-arcanum.com/downloads/[/url] should you need it, or the other links not work.

The gameplay is also unbalanced and frustrating at times. For combat, you can switch between real-time and turn-based (turn-based is the generally accepted way to play Arcanum, but there will be times when you need to switch between the two). However, the combat is often chaotic and confusing due to the lack of feedback and control. The difficulty is also inconsistent and unfair at times - some enemies are too easy to defeat while others are too hard to overcome, with the curve seemingly flattened as you approach the end. The AI is also erratic and unreliable: The companions often act stupidly or get stuck in obstacles, and the programming does not always make sense (why do my ranged companions decide to get in close to attack? Make it make sense).

Arcanum is a game that has a lot of potential but also a lot of problems. This will appeal most to fans of classic role-playing games who appreciate its originality and depth. However, it is also a game that frustrates players who expect more polish and balance, and requires patience and tolerance to enjoy its merits to the fullest.

Played on Windows 11 Pro x64. It was not a simple task to get this game to work - in addition to the above, I had to create a custom override in Windows Security for Mandatory ASLR and force it to off. Without this, the game would not launch at all.

Oh, dearie me! I recently tried my hand at this peculiar game called Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura, and let me tell you, it was quite the experience. Now, mind you, I couldn't quite make out those pesky dialogue options, but I soldiered on regardless. By the way, have I mentioned Amanda from the church choir and her suspicious ways at Bingo? But I digress...

Arcanum presents itself as a fascinating world full of steam-powered contraptions and magical wonders. However, it's as if the game itself conspires against me, dear reader. The dialogue options elude my poor, tired eyes, leaving me utterly bewildered. It's a shame, really. Just like Amanda and her bingo shenanigans.

As I stumbled through this game, attempting to navigate its intricacies, I couldn't help but feel a sense of frustration. The lack of clear guidance made it difficult to truly immerse myself in the story. And let me tell you, dear Amanda, the church choir deserves better than someone who cheats in Bingo! Oops, there I go again, forgive me!

The combat system, oh my, it's a peculiar beast! It felt clunky and unrefined, much like Amanda's habit of snatching the winning card before anyone else has a chance. But I won't dwell on her dubious tactics any longer, my apologies.

The visuals, while dated, still possess a certain charm. The world of Arcanum is unique and intriguing, with its mix of technology and magic. If only the game's mechanics were as enchanting as the church choir's harmonies, minus Amanda's disruptive antics, of course.

In all honesty, dear reader, Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura left me feeling somewhat exasperated. The lack of accessibility for those of us who struggle with deciphering the dialogue options dampened my enthusiasm. And speaking of dampening things, Amanda's presence in the church choir dampens the spirit of fair play.

While I appreciate the game's ambition and its potential to captivate others, it simply did not resonate with me. Perhaps if Amanda learned to play fair in Bingo, I might have had a more positive outlook on Arcanum. But alas, such is life.

In summary, Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura left me longing for a more user-friendly experience. Much like Amanda and her Bingo tactics, the game felt frustrating and inaccessible. Ah, Amanda, Amanda, when will you learn? But I digress. Proceed with caution, dear reader, and may your adventures be less confounding than mine.
This game has the worst combat I have ever seen in an rpg and it's ugly as sin, 10/10 great game
Crashes on startup after installing the unofficial patch, and I don't have the time to troubleshoot it.

A beautifully broken game that never gets old. I have loved Arcanum since it's release in 2001. A good majority of the fun is constantly trying new builds and backgrounds. There's plenty of customization and it's always wonderful when you can add your own portraits and create your own backgrounds.

Play your way! Want to be evil and slaughter everyone in your path? Go for it. Want to be a goody two-shoes who never does a thing wrong? You got it. Want to just wander aimlessly and slaughter random enemies in the wilderness with powerful magic or blow them up with technology? You can do that, too!

The story is good and definitely serviceable for the game. While magic is rather broken if you take certain spells, any way you play this game is quite fun. Diplomats, gunslingers, sword and board, mage, sneaky thief, assassin...the choice is yours! The voice acting is well done (though quite a few get annoyed with Virgil). One thing to keep in mind is even though there's a real time combat option in this game, it's best to play this turn based. You'll find yourself getting frustrated in real time, especially if you're some kind of ranged fighter.

The AI of the game is quite stupid, but you really don't need a fully functioning AI for the combat. Combat is simple enough that you don't have to plan a lot of tactics after the first couple of hours (hard difficulty). You can choose to follow the main story as you see fit. I prefer to take my time and explore, but it's there when you're ready. I have always highly recommended this game to those who love turn based RPGs or something with a decent/good story.

22.5 years have passed since the release. Back then I would give the game 101% out of 100% for Fallout in a steampunk-fantasy crossover.
However, time has passed I got acquainted with many non-inferior games, and I may even write a short non-biased review.
TLDR: Recommended if isometric graphics doesn't make you sick, and if you don't mind that 85% of the game are a slasher while the remaining 15% are an RPG.

[b]Main story[/b]: generic, another Chosen one, but edible for a Fallout 1-2 successor in 2001. It is definitely blatant in 2023, but at least having some twists, although barely logical.

[b]Sub-stories[/b]: range from awful to awesome; mostly generic. It feels like the devs were running out of time before the release, and there are many starting points which have no follow-up. The weirdest thing is that your character has literally NO connection to the world of Arcanum. In one of the dialogues, your elf character says that she/he is from another continent, but that's literally it. So, this is not the game where you may expect any personal development of your pawn.

[b]Rule of Three[/b]: (strength, stealing, speaking) is only applied to some of the plots. Example: There are 31 Persuasion checks in total, 17 of which require 2 skill points out of 5 max -- the more you invest, the less useful Persuasion becomes. Also, it's worth to note that you may speak your main antagonist to death.
Another example is that the game is filled with unique super-items. To get them you need 2 "S": stealing or strength. There is no option to get them with charisma/money.

[b]Followers[/b]: include several interesting guys and gals. Many of them appear in the late game, so there is literally no value to exchange your current party members. The worst is their behaviour in combat, especially mages. E.g., an awesome archeress transforming her body into a water elemental and kicking enemies in melee. OR, an evil mage hitting enemies in melee barehanded instead of casting harmful spells.

[b]Combat[/b]: Real-time and Turn-based--both unbalanced. Before level 10, most fights are a neverending sequence of misses. After level 10, most fights end faster than a blink of an eye.
Old-fashioned melee is a god in this game.
Magic is cool, but you need to know meta.
Bows/Throwing are easy because based on the most useful stat--Dexterity.
Firearms suck as you need the second lamest stat--Perception. The good thing is that you may still create a successful gunslinger mage.
Technology gimmicks are too complicated for the fast pace of the battles.
As for the enemies, they act like your Followers in most cases -- all mages almost never use magic, and instead run in melee, unless they have a ranged weapon.

[b]Magic vs Technology concept[/b]: Nice at a first glance, unbalanced towards magic later in the game, both suck at the end because melee destroys everything (if you play without exploits).
Magic itself is pretty generic -- you invest a skill and get an ability.
Technology is more interesting -- you invest a skill and get a scheme. Then you collect ingredients/details and based on these and other purchasable schemes you create a device.
There is a catch, most technician Followers never invest more than 4 out of 7 skills in a technical discipline. So, to try all the devices expect replaying the game. This is somewhat mitigated by the Unofficial Patch, but you need to turn-off the auto levelling for Followers.

[b]Shady stuff[/b]: the developers literally push you to steal from everyone. They even introduced some noise and awareness mechanics and left several 'clever gaming' alternatives. Example, the doors to NPC's bedrooms are generally locked, but you may easily enter when NPC goes to sleep or gets up. Then wait for night, NPC will go to sleep ignoring you, and‚Ä¶
There are also several hexed items with poison. You may leave such item on the floor, an NPC will automatically pick it up, put on and die. After looting, you may even resurrect this NPC who will even be grateful.

[b]Game economics[/b]: Playing as a thief or a mage with the unlocking spell, it's easy -- just loot your favourite vendor.
Playing a technical (especially following Explosives discipline), it's quite easy to find a proper prosperity formula. This also applies to a player with a technical follower.
For a non-thieving mage or non-thieving fighter, it's harder, because your resources are limited, and you may even need to farm random encounters when you're requested 50000 late in the game. [spoiler]It's possible to avoid paying the money with a skill or by completing a long quest chain.[/spoiler]
For non-ugly females, you may get a permanent part-time position in the most ancient occupation.

[b]So, why the hell should I play it?[/b]
Arcanum is rather unique in its world setting: Victorian age with Orcish Trade Unions, Gnomish Conspiracy and OP Elves.
Arcanum introduces crafting system which is different from the trite survival craft, or from the standard "copper->bronze->iron->steel->mythril->adamantine" sequence.
Arcanum allows throwing grenades and deploying robots, regardless your character is a magic or technology user.
Arcanum allows your character to be ugly, but charming and still beat the game (relying on your bodyguards).
Arcanum allows your character quite an opposite thing: stand there beautiful, but dumb, and still beat the game.
Arcanum is rather easy even in its hard mode.

Probably the definitive RPG. the mix of magic vs technology is amazing alongside the race wars of orcs, elves and dwarfs vs the human world. yeah it needs some mods, it has some glitches. the game play is ancient and the graphics show their age, but this game has what all other rpg games have wished they had. its not just the story line and deep side quests, not just the multiple choice scenarios and open world play style... or unloading shotguns and hand grenades at religious nut jobs, monsters and mages.  The pure idea this game portrays and the world its set in is worth all the drawbacks, it was amazing when released over 20 years ago and all tho its been beaten in game play and graphics by so many games.... their beauty is only skin deep in comparison. there still isnt an RPG close to the  amazingly detailed world of arcanum, Arcanum is amazing

An easy game to enjoy for anyone looking for a deep, classic RPG experience. The games mechanics are top notch, and in a few ways groundbreaking. I really enjoyed the classless system that focuses leveling the character you want to play. The story and world building shines in this game. I've played few games with this deep level of magic combined with steampunk. It's such an interesting mix in time period and fantasy that it's a shame we get so few examples of this working.

[h1]It's actually 100+ hours with the unofficial patch - its launcher isn't tracked by Steam.[/h1]

I have to say, for a game that's now a few [strike]centuries[/strike] decades old, it's still a joy to play. There is a lot of custom build options to choose from, and from an rpg perspective, this is a fantastic start.

Arcanum is a world in the grip of what I like to think of as a cold war between technology and magick. Best example of this, while not something you'll be able to do straight away, is walking in to a shop of the opposite alignment your skills are at. Say you were a whizz-bang technologist and you walk into a magick shop. Just trying to talk to the shop owner will have them scream at you to get out! It's unique and fun! Just having your first companion with you as you master your schematics and degrees, then getting attacked and mortally wounded, and him trying to heal you with spells, only to have them fizzle out uselessly as you are too technically inclined.

It's a fascinating concept I've yet to see implemented in any other game.

Further about the build mechanics. Not only do you have your race and gender, as well as your standard good vs evil alignment once you start playing, but there are some backgrounds to choose from as well that can further define your character. Most of these are just stat re-balances, +4 here and -1, -1, -2 elsewhere, but there are one or two that can be useful for certain play styles.

Still further, there are a range of skills, spells and technical disciplines you can learn. While high tech aptitude doesn't really have much bonuses, higher magick aptitude can elicit greater stats on magickal armour and gear. Such is the nature of the game, you can invest in one, the other, or both, or even neither, should you so choose. You have complete freedom over how you want to play the game.

When I say neither, I speak of the range of skills you can invest in that do not fall under the tech or magick category. Skill points awarded at level up can go into new spells or tech designs, or even something like dodge or melee, pickpocket or detect traps, haggle or persuade, or even firearms or throwing. Some of these are tech, but I can't recall which ones. It's easy enough to check the tech / magick aptitude meter on the right anyway to see what effect they have on your character. Skill points can even go directly into HP or MP, should you so wish.

Entering the world of Arcanum with your character, you will take on a specific main quest that has a little branching depending on your plot choices - the village of Stillwater is perhaps the most affected as you might be expected to wipe it out, which will affect later encounters. If you've ever played Baldur's Gate you'll know what to expect, and clicking to move, as well as turn-based combat, is recommended. Realtime combat is too fast for clicking on enemies, I found. This is especially true if you need to use skills or spells.

One thing I HIGHLY recommend, if you're going down any combat route, is to get up your related skill fast. I was low on skill for far too long before I realised what my problem was, and once I got it higher from a trainer the game got sooo much more enjoyable. 

I'm talking about the early-game problem of the over-abundance of critical misses. 

It can be funny when your weapon flies out of your hand and your stamina bar empties the first time. But when you're just using a basic sword (and we all know how a sword is supposed to swing, right?), it can seem utterly impossible as to how in the world you could have a critical miss so bad that you miss your foe and slice your own neck open. This sort of thing is not uncommon in Arcanum, especially when starting out. Then you get the companion jeers and taunts. You'll be sick of Virgil after a while if you get a bunch of critical misses:

'What in gods... - I mean, better luck next time!' fully voiced as well, setting you up for a very nice epic facepalm.

I don't even want to imagine what would happen if you tried to use something like a pyrotechnic axe, with it's +30 fire damage, without any skill. You'd probably blow up.

More on the story though. It can be a bit unforgiving with clues sometimes as to what you need to do next. There is no going to the map, seeing a waypoint and just instinctively knowing where to go, a lot of it is memory. Even your quest log will only mention people's names - it won't tell you where you found them. I guess in this respect, it's best not to collect quests and let them stagnate. There are a lot of people in the game and a lot of names to remember. But there is enough variety in terms of scenery and what you'll be doing that the game always feels fun and adventurous. The music is not too intrusive either, and the patch I used has an option to disable the combat music.

Sure it has its bugs, but as an older game it is to be expected. As mentioned in the header, there is a patch out there (mentioned in various places, including the forums) that adds a bunch of fixes to the game, but the result of this is a new launcher that isn't part of Steam. It is well worth it. Tech play is made easier with the debug menu (by equipping the ring at the start and talking to Virgil), but I'd still say make sure you pause it if you want to alt tab, as this can crash the game.

Other features of the game include the fate point system, where you can earn fate points for certain tasks or quests, and the legendary Gods quest, where you try to get blessings from all the gods' shrines in the whole game, without making any of the gods angry enough to curse you for doing things in the wrong order. The only problem with this (and sometimes with the game as a whole) is access to certain areas is limited by where you are in the main questline. No one likes finally getting everything only to find yourself at the end of the game with nothing left to do.


In the end, if you're looking for an rpg and you've played everything else, maybe this one will fill your need. There are a lot of builds out there, and there are even forums that discuss some of the weirdest and most outlandish things you can think of.

An absolute gem of a game. Highly recommended! Sure it will require Drog's patch to work optimally and is a bit janky at times but overall it's a fantastic and memorable experience which takes place in a unique setting and has an excellent art direction as well as some legit decent writing and tons of choices with consequences to make through-out. Well worth the time.

This game has a wonderful and beautiful core elements. The story, rpg elements, characters, world, and character system are amazing. The only draw backs is this game obviously ran out of support and money part of the way through their vision. There are bugs and some parts are obvious not wrapped up and finished. However this game is incredibly worthwhile to play. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes rpgs.
Fallout 2 with magic

I absolutely love the concept of the game, the story, the lore and its aesthetics.

BUT

There's a reason Troika published three games and went bankrupt.
The execution is atrocious.

There are bugs galore, from moronic AI to literally making ranged characters go stand besides the enemies before shooting.
The worst part is the implementation of magick and technology. The story is about how the latter is replacing the first one. That would lead you to believe that, at the very least, technology is as powerful as magick. FALSE! The most powerful character you can build is a wizard. I've played one that had only one level one offensive spell and I completely beat the game without breaking a sweat. Playing a tech character is, basically, setting to game to extra hard mode, specially, if you decide to make a gunslinger (this last one is particularly enfuriating because the intro of the game is a warrior with magick equipment being shot with a pistol).

It's a damn wasted opportunity, I wish some company grabbed it and made a remake because there is a LOT of potential.
Great game for those wanting Baldur's gate with guns and locomotives.

An absolute classic for anyone who enjoys true RPG Fantasy - with a healthy mix of steampunk.
Deep lore, deep conversations (in parts), and truly a tricky game to get to grips with. (Unless you play 100% magic user and are an experienced player, then its a doddle.)
Power gamers beware, there is so much choice to be had you may become frustrated that you cannot master the entirety of your chosen field, whether magic or technology. Level cap can be overcome by mods I'm told though.
This is probably one for us oldies. The graphics are on a par with fallout 1+2, as well as general play.

This is for the fans of Fallout 1&2, because it's practically more of the same in a different setting. There's a vast selection of different characters you can build and the hardest playthrough is with firearms (which I picked the first time), because you'll always run out of ammo. The easiest way to play this is with a mage or archer/mage, hulksmash build is also very viable. The main campaign is heavy on combat against critters and the most irritating enemies break your gear. You'll be able to switch between real time and turn-based on will to make sure you'll land the most hits. This game is simultaneously awful and good, you can cheese it to the max if you like or play some stunted runt of a character. The soundtrack and sound design can get a bit grating, but you'll hear different violin tunes besides the ones that normally play everywhere. In general this is a diamond in the rough, with lot of the content left out because of budget or schedule reasons, in a way like Fallout 1&2 were.

The typical Arcanum dialogue interaction:
NPC: "Why hello there, fine day isn't it?"
Your responses:
A: "My good man, it IS quite a fine day old sport"
B: "I hope you're enjoying this day... because it will be your last!"

Truly amazing. The ever-present option that you could berserk and kill everyone feels like you are playing as an unhinged man who is one hair away from going completely insane. (Not too much unlike real life)
Unfortunately, this game needs some diving into the files before it becomes playable and even then you will still encounter game-breaking glitches. However, if you are playing CRPGs none of that is new to you.
One of my all time favorite RPGs would kill for a remaster to bring it into the new age.
Very good high quality game

One of my all time favorites. 
Lots to do and explore, anyone who loves isometric open world rpgs will love this game. The technology versus magic aspect adds a lot of variation to character builds. The discrimination the Orcs face and some ogres face is also unique, the orcs are treated as a slave labor force and very discriminated against in face if you pick a half-orc character even if you have very high beauty and charisma some characters wont talk to you and still wont let you do their quests even if they seem to sort of like you. 
By far a game i can go back to and always find something new!

A unique squad-based isometric fantasy game, set in a world where technology and magic coexist. The setting is unique, the gameplay will be familiar to any gamer over the age of 40. 

Especially unique is the character creation. Picking your race is pedestrian (human, elf, half elf, half orc). Choosing your back ground is not. Raised by snake handlers. Child of a hero. Ran away with the circus. Your choice will affect your stats. You are given 5 points to use in deciding your skills in combat, thieving, social, or technological skills. With so few points to disperse, you can't be everything. Which adds to replayability. 



conclusion

one of the more unique isometric games from the olden days of gaming, Will not appeal to everyone. If you find these games interesting, you should be able to get this cheap. It is old.
I cant get over how much I love this game. Such a true classic RPG!

One of the games of my childhood, in my opinion highly under-rated! Imagine in 2003 to have such a huge map, with all those characters and the possibility to choose among something like 36 different endings. 
Even in 2022, I enjoy playing Arcanum and never get bored by playing it: the world and the possibilities are so vast that there is always something new to discover. 
Besides that, I really like the main plot and the idea to have a world balanced between technology and magic, it reminds me in a certain measure of the Alan Moore comics. 
Personally, never had not even one issues running the game on windows 10. Highly reccomended to everyone interested in RPG that wants a taste of old games!
A classic, hardcore, steampunk RPG. Very similar to classic Fallout, although there are more options here and an interesting medieval sci-fi story.
its old and glitchy but amazing

I really love this game and all it has to offer, like a lot of Isometrics it has a steep learning curve and may seem boring to people who have not played a lot of them. Don't get discouraged! This game is still incredibly fun if you're into older games and it has a unique spin on fantasy, especially with how it places it in the Victorian era which doesn't happen often. There is a big emphasis on how technology and magic contradicts one another and it is just one of many compelling parts of the story.

I say play it, and if you do, get the unofficial patch!
A flawed beauty, but one with great depth and great replayability.

[h1]New Review[/h1]
I suddenly got an Arcanum itch and returned to one of the most unique and interesting setting for a CRPG I have still experienced to this day.

This time, instead of following my heart and excitement in creating a technology character like I did in my first playthrough, I went with a magic user (which is actually what many would recommend for their first playthrough).

Why? Because magic is completely broken in this game. The first level of one of the many, MANY different schools of magic unlocks a spell called ‚ÄúHarm‚Äù.

It‚Äôs literally a first level spell you unlock with just 1 point (that you get every time you level up) and it is quite literally the most powerful spell in the game. I completely cheesed the entire game with this one spell and it felt extremely satisfying.

I then spent another point in learning the unlock spell, which then completely invalidates the lockpicking skill you need to use lockpicks for and level up a maximum of 5 times plus training in order to open locked doors and chests.

It honestly makes playing a technological character feel bad.

As cool as it sounds to be someone who uses a flintlock pistol or rifle, doing so really gimps your character because you have to then constantly pay attention to ammo and purchase them until you‚Äôre able to make them. Which takes more level up points, that you also need in order to increase your perception skill to do more damage with said pistols.

But you ALSO need to spend those points in lockpicking as well as spend points into DEX so you can have more action points to spend during your turn in combat‚Ä¶ Which is also for the dodge skill so you can not get hit as much. Not to mention if you want actual companions, the amount you can have is dependant on your Charisma skill, so that‚Äôs even more points. You need max level (which is 20) in order to be able to have the maximum allowed number of companions.

Not to mention you also need to spend points in the various technological skill trees in order to unlock new schematics to learn.

So as you can see, playing as a technological character, you are at a severe disadvantage on spending your skill points efficiently due to the max level being 50 and you only getting 1 skill point per level up and then occasionally 2 when you hit certain level mile stones.

A mage can use much fewer skill points in doing similar things, which makes playing as one a lot more simpler. 

Hence my newest playthrough being so much more enjoyable to me. I was able to actually be quite comfortable in taking my time and exploring this time around because I didn‚Äôt have the stress of having so many different junk items cluttering my inventory in the chance I may need these materials for something to craft.

I just pew-pewed my magic at everything I came across and was able to level up my Charisma to level 20 much earlier on and grab all of the companions I wanted.

This time round, I believe I found and completed most of the quests in the game, I wanted to read all of the books I came across, but unfortunately the graphics and text of the books, while nicely portrayed, was just too blurry and difficult to read.

I only read some books that I felt was important to the story and skimmed the rest in the hope of the game keeping track of what books I‚Äôve ‚Äúread‚Äù in case they matter in some quest or whatever.

This game and its story is still one of my favourites, despite having difficulty in my first playthrough a few years ago, I still managed to enjoy it and I enjoyed it even more the second time round.

I think I‚Äôll come back for a third in another few years and this time play a dumb half-ogre character and bash everything to death.

I would so much love for this game to be given a remaster to make it work better at higher resolutions and modern systems.

The fan patch I used did get it to work, but increasing the resolution past 720p makes the game and its UI much too zoomed out, especially at a 4K resolution.

My first playthrough I played at 1080p on a 1080p screen, this time I played at 720p on a 4K screen and it was actually much better in my opinion.

[h1]Original Review[/h1]
Posted on 12 Dec, 2022 @ 4:09pm at 46.2 hrs

This was a really good CRPG, the world was very unique with extensive lore and an interesting Victorian/Steampunk fantasy setting.

If I didn't focus almost exclusively on the Main Quest, I reckon I could have spent 80-100+ hours on this game, but unfortunately the aged gameplay mechanics made it so I couldn't enjoy the exploration and side quests enough to take my time with them.

The jank of the pathfinding and lack of formation settings with your companions made me feel too uncomfortable when exploring. Especially since there were many times where my companions would run in and get killed or during turn-based mode their AI or the enemies' would get stuck and I'd have to reload the game.

Despite that though, I really, really enjoyed my time with the game and its story, and I would love to see a sequel some day since it has such an interesting setting. I'm definitely glad I got to play this classic.

This has to be one of my favorite fantasy role playing settings I've ever experienced in a game. I love the world building and the mechanics. 

The main issue is the game feels strangely unfinished despite having so much content and a full campaign, it just feels like it both came out too late and too early. Too late in the sense the graphics are almost 4 years behind and too early in the sense that there are obvious large omisions.

The world of Arcanum is deep and incredibly engaging. Nothing is bog standard about the fantasy and the world is intricate and exciting to explore and dive into. Despite it's age its still a blast to explore and easily encourages multiple play throughs with varies characters to get all the possible details and quests. Now there is a large drawback in that you MUST get the unofficial patch else the game is completely unstable on any modern hardware.

Arcanum, in my opinion, is the best game in the rpg genre, an infinite number of options for passing, excellent replayability, the ability to play both turn-based and real-time mode (I played in real-time), memorable characters with their own stories and principles, the best techno -fantasy setting of all the games that have ever played, but most importantly the atmosphere and the ability to make any decisions. It's a shame they don't make games like this anymore. A true legend and classic.

Best game of all time

Really fun rpg but you will need the drog black tooth unofficial patch otherwise it will be buggy as hell. Installing the patch is easy however and stuff like this should be a given for a game that's 20 years old. Can't understand people who negatively review old games for having bugs which you can fix with a google search and 5 minutes of your time

A game I have been wanting to play for decades, ever since I had saw an advertised in a PC magazine!  By today's standards the content might be a little rough.  Definitely some sexism and racism thrown into the mix, but in a fantasy setting, so no love for Half-Orcs or Half-Ogres and some races hate Elves or Dwarves, etc.  And men are always going to be stronger and can carry more because of it and deal more melee damage from brute force.  But women can suffer more pain and have better health and have a better resistance to poisoning for instance.

I will say that I have heard negative things due to it being an older game and trying to run it on modern systems.  I am not sure if something was patched in recently, but I can actually play this game on Windows 10.  Normally the game is $6 and quite frankly that is a bargain.  But on sale at only $1.50, it's too precious a deal to ignore.  I normally would not suggest testing the wheels of fate with purchasing just to see if the game works, but if you do not ask for refunds often, I do suggest it for this.  And chances are "out of the box" it may work as it did for me.  I did have graphical issues, but they went away on a restart and have not been back since.  And if you do not mind a little tinkering to get it to work, there are 3rd party patches and support for it.

Not a politically correct game as it were..  But you would be doing yourself a disservice if you did not play it.  The fantasy aspect of it, with it's mix of Magic and Technology makes a very unique steampunk atmosphere.  Plenty of decisions to be made when creating a character, including options that could severely hinder or assist you.  Plenty of avatars and prebuilt characters as well.  Dialogue trees that effect your play through and so much more.  I do wholeheartedly recommend the game.  And who can pass up on a game with a title like that!?  "Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura"

The game is very clunky, even with mods.  Has a counter-intuitive UI and I couldn't get into the pick magic or fighting or technology theme.  Too much open and tedious traveling.  I loved Fallout and I just can't love this game enough to play more than two hours of it.
One of the best RPGs of all times.

Very clunky, and very clearly a product of the 90's (despite having been released in 2001). Graphics comparable to the first two Fallout games. Also, it's buggy as hell, even with the unofficial fan patch. 

But...

Like the first two Fallout games- also developed by some of the people who worked on this game- it is an absolute gem of a CRPG. Brilliant worldbuilding, a gripping story, very open-ended gameplay for a game of its era, fantastic voice acting (when there is any), and a very fleshed out character creation and progression system.

Cannot stress this enough; if you love RPGs, buy this game. If you're a Fallout fan, this game is a must-play. Just go in with the expectation that it will be a very steep learning curve unless you grew up (or have invested a lot of time) playing these sort of games; and that this game isn't exactly the most polished in the medium. 8/10, cheap as hell, but worth far more than the price tag would suggest.

How did I not hear about this game 20 years ago? For me, where I have played 100's of RPGs since the 90's when I started gaming,discovering this game was like a combination of finding a missing link in the evolution of gaming and stumbling into an alternate universe where the makers of one of my favorite games, Fallout 2, released a game that surpassed even that.

Here you'll find a massive open world, an original take on the classic fantasy races and their interactions with each other, an amount of content and enough variation in play styles, such as the magic vs. technology dichotomy, to keep you busy for dozens if not 100's of hours, and plots that will keep you entertained and trying to guess what's coming next. While its easy to see why this game, with its complex systems and thoughtful themes, didn't top the best selling lists at the time, it really is a tragedy that this game's sales went as poorly as they did because there was greatness here and a potential for more in the form of sequels that expanded on the world and lore. 

If you're like me and have played through and loved all of the classic RPGs, from Fallout to Baldur's Gate 2, Dark Souls to Divinity Original Sin 2, and so on, but somehow missed out on Arcanum, this is like finding a long lost season of your favorite TV show. If that sounds like you at all, you missed out on playing this game when it was released AND you are somehow reading this review, don't make the same mistake again. You need to play Arcanum.
The only cRPG to surpass Fallout 1 & 2.

Ignore the play time, Steam didn't track it properly (possibly because of the multiverse patch?). I don't actually now how long I've played for, but it was a decent amount (not to mention playing a lot when it first game out).

I've gone back and forth whether to recommend it or not. Ultimately, I feel it's too dated with too many issues.

There's a variety of ways to play (tech, magic, melee/dodge) and races which have variety, but I feel like despite it being a world where tech is overcoming magic, magic is far superior. You only need to worry about getting your magic aptitude to 100 for good damage (which takes about 20 spells with 0 starting aptitude and no tech) and it is just so much simpler.  Most of the good stuff already seemed to be magical in nature, you get teleportation for travel almost everywhere (vs the more limited trains), you have disintigrate for the stronger foes and things like Harm for the ones that damage your stuff when attacked (like Ore Golems).  Tech needs to find manuals to build a lot of stuff and if you want to use say guns, you need to constantly get bullets.

I found the story to be lackluster and barely there - it felt like I spent more time wandering around compared to the story moving on and this wasn't even doing side quests - this was actual story areas where just nothing really happened much.  For the most part, the companions were just there.  Only Virgil really had anything to say and it was mostly towards the end.  Magnus had stuff to say if you do the quest to find the Iron Clan, but I don't think I heard much from my other companions (dog, Sogg, and Chukka).  I don't know if it was a bug or not, but when I finally beat the final boss, the game just seemed to end and the implication was that I failed? (I'm hard of hearing so it was hard to tell, but there was a pretty desolate looking picture and i think it did say Arcanum was destroyed even though I stopped the boss?

I had mastery in Persuasion, a really good alignment, high INT, high Beauty, and made it clear i didn't agree with the final boss so I have no idea what went wrong.  This is really annoying to me as i usually like to play more Diplomatic characters to complete as many quests as possible and do it peacefully, but it felt pointless here as it seemed very rare that I even needed Persuasion.

I also encountered a bunch of issues despite having the multiverse edition despite it including the most updated version of the unofficial patch (2.2.1 or something).  I experienced crashes every so often - not too bad, but then I got like 3 or 4 in the final dungeon alone.  Some of the quests bugged for me as well.  An example is I couldn't do Stringy Pete's quests to get his boat to get to the final areas.  I could return the treasure fine, but the others wouldn't complete. At least, the third one wouldn't.  The second task to fix an altar worked after reloading the older save worked, but the third task to destroy a sword in forge that was literally right next to it never worked.  I put the sword in, it would be destroyed, and nothing.  Thank Goodness Disintegrate works on Stringy Pete as I didn't care for what is supposed to be the hardest fight in the game...

Quizas uno de los juegos mas increibles que jugu√© en mi vida. A pesar de todo lo que tiene en contra, sigue siendo el juego que recordamos en mi grupo de amigos.
Puedo dedicar parrafos al apartado tecnico y la jugabilidad, pero resumiendo: no es un juego lindo visualmente (y no lo era cuando sali√≥) pero el mundo que plantea hace que todo sea atractivo. 
Es un mundo diferente... steampunk en algunos aspectos... Vivir una especie de edad industrial y su impacto en un mundo fant√°stico te atrapa, aunque quizas la historia es un poco clich√© en algunos aspectos. Sin embargo esta tan lleno de momentos y lugares memorables.

Tiene cosas de fallout (y fallout tactics), el combate se puede configurar para funcionar en tiempo real (diferente al de la saga Baldurs Gate) o en combate por turnos, con un sistema de puntos de accion.

EL personaje tiene un medidor de Moral (de bueno a malo) que afecta la relacion con compa√±eros de grupo y el mundo en general.... De igual manera tiene un medidor de inclinacion hacia la magia o hacia la ciencia. Esto ayuda a acentuar que en el mundo del juego la magia y la tecnologia se contraponen.

Hacer un personaje es bastante intuitivo y no es un juego muy dificil ya que todo tiene cierta l√≥gica. Por ejemplo: el valor de PERCEPCION del personaje determina todo lo relativo al combate a distancia y si lo acrecentamos las granadas que lancemos ser√°n mas precisas (tb afecta disparos y otras cosas...). Un personaje sin percepcion no suele lanzar los objetos exacto al lugar donde le indicamos..
Todo funciona de forma "entendible" si lo comparamos con otros juegos de este tipo y no recuerdo haber necesitado demasiado la ayuda de guias.
Otros valores del personaje nos dicen cuantos hechizos podemos mantener activos, qu√© nivel de hechizo podemos aprender (HAY 19 ESCUELAS DE MAGIA con hechizos exclusivos a cada una....), qu√© tan rapido nos recuperamos y cuanto resistimos al veneno, cuanto peso podemos cargar, etc... todo es bastante logico...
Lo mejor de todo es que un personaje inteligente tendra m√°s y mejores respuestas en dialogo que un personaje tonto. De igual manera, un personaje carismatico tendra otras opciones de dialogo y podr√° reclutar mas compa√±eros. 
Todo tiene mucho impacto y esto permite jugar el juego de maneras REALMENTE variadas segun el personaje.

Los personajes con afinidad tecnologica podran fabricar explosivos, municion, aut√≥matas... Es posible especializarse en ramas como la herboristeria para crear mejores pociones y antidotos. 

ES UN JUEGO MEMORABLE, a veces hermoso, a veces feo visualmente, siempre encantador. con un sistema de combate un poco "r√∫stico" pero √°gil que incita a jugar el mismo combate varias veces hasta obtener un resultado deseado. 
Los compa√±eros son geniales, en especial Virgil que nos acompa√±a toda la aventura (si asi lo deseamos).

Este juego tiene algo... la nostalgia es fuerte y siempre termino desinstalando otros juegos de este tipo tras jugar un poco. Pero en este caso, se queda instalado....siempre.

I originally got this game from my new step-dad, over 10 years ago, around the age of 12. It was on a CD, in a box, with a printed game guide, included. It didn't require a game-client login, nor an internet connection to play, and it was pretty much one of the only things my poor 2 gb ram, refurbished home and office laptop could handle. It was one of the first RPGs I had ever played, and one of the first willingly given to me, since all I could get beforehand were random CD games given to Goodwill that I prayed worked and didn't need internet connection when I got home. 

I was a baby gamer, I loved video games, wanted to play video games, but knew nothing about them, and had never played anything "big" besides Pokemon, because I was a little girl raised on a farm in the deep south. I didn't know what a "Triple A" game was, I didn't have internet connection, and I sure has hell hadn't played anything like Elder Scrolls, Fallout, or even Fable.

But let me tell you, I LOVE this game. I poured hours into this game, and it kick-started everything I love about RPGs. Some of my fondest gaming memories are in this game, even when my character was led to a room with a sheep in it by the hostess of a brothel when asked if your tastes are "Unique".  Nowadays, I feel like I'm quite knowledgeable about gaming and even have a decent gaming setup, and dabble in gaming journalism. It opened the door to other games, and eventually an interest in game dev (which didn't go anywhere), and now I'm a programmer in my day job. Once I moved on to Elder Scrolls, I found myself having a hard time playing isometric, "classic" RPGs, but once I saw this game was on Steam (I had already moved out and lost the CD by this point), memories unlocked, tears came to my eyes, and I instantly bought it and downloaded it. 

It's a quick download, since it is a relatively small game compared to most these days, despite the amount of content. I opened it and... spent 2 hours trying to get to the first city. I didn't remember it being this difficult. How did tween me just click with it immediately? But over time, things came back to me, I got into the flow of things, but with a more matured and experienced RPG-player mindset, and I just.. enjoyed it. I didn't care it was isometric. I didn't care it was from 2001. I was immersed in an amazingly developed fantasy/steampunk world where I can truly do anything. I wasn't me, I was a halfling trying to make friends and juggle responsibilities while exploring this fantastic world, trying to navigate this adventure I was unwillingly thrusted into by getting into the wrong zeppelin.  You know, the "true" purpose and experience aimed for by RPGs, originally. 

Okay, onto an actual review instead a recipe blog post: I recommend this game, but understand what you're getting.

1. This is an early-2000s RPG. It dates itself. It is difficult. It can seem overwhelming at first, but once you get into the swing of things, it feels a lot smoother and better.

2. You can truly play the game however you want. There is no such thing as an "essential" NPC. You can beat the game by killing everyone. NPCs that had "essential" information for you will have that info on a note in their pocket on their body. It's quite a bit harder, but if you play your cards right, you can even beat the game by killing no one. 

3. Your actions have actual consquences. Remember this. 

4. There are adult moments in this game, parents. No explicit scenes, but there is a brothel. And in that brothel is a sheep room. Take that what you will.

5. Very nice character creation with a variety of races, classes, and backgrounds. Think Baldur's Gate. 

6. So many companions. But the companions are actually complex and can leave you.

7. The quadrant system is interesting, if a bit complex. So you be more compatible with magick or you can be more compatible with technology (the steamworks part of this). There is a slider and it adjusts accordingly to your actions and skills you use. You can also be "good" or "evil" and the slider adjusts accordingly. These can affect how your character is treated, and even if certain NPCs are willing to be companions or not. You can not be both for either. 

8. I did not encounter any bugs, but that does not mean there isn't any.

9. Inventory management can be annoying, since it's based on geometry and not weight. 

10. I one day hope for a re-master or even a re-make.

Classic isometric RPG from the now-defunct Troika Games. This game has a unigue premise, in that it takes place in a fantasy world with all the traditional Tolkien-esque races (Elves, Dwarves, Humans etc.), but with the added detail that this world has recently entered an industrial revolution much like our own. Much like our own industrial revolution, this adds all kinds of advancements and troubles of its own. The magic that exists in this world has a negative effect on any technology operating in the area, and vice-versa, Would highly recommend that you give this game a try, with a few caveats. The unofficial patch should definitely be installed, it's basically required. This fixes various bugs that remained in the game after release. It also let's the game run in modern resolutions without stretching the visuals unnaturally.
Second caveat, I highly recommend you play the game with turn-based combat enabled. Not doing so makes certain play styles almost impossible. All in all, a highly recommended game. Hopefully now that Activision is owned (or will soon be owned) by Microsoft, the possibility exists that we may get a sequel.
Some negatives. The UI can be difficult to navigate at times. Also, it can be easy to create a character that is almost impossible to play with if you are not careful. The visuals can, and probably will put most people off of playing the game.
The positives: The music is unique and fits the game and the world itself perfectly. The story is reasonably interesting and the world-building is great.
Old classic!

It's a great RPG, but not a perfect one by a long shot, this is what Tim Cain went on to make after leaving interplay, sometime after fallout. Best part of this one is its industrialized fantasy setting, meaning it's a little bit steampunk, and a little bit Lord of the Rings. 

Magic and Technology have a balance, and when that balance is tipped in one way, the other suffers. In an Industrialized City magic will often fail, but in a more magically dominated area machines are prone to malfunction.

The amount of bugs prevent this from being perfect, you can boundary break because the game procedurally generates the world so that you can literally manually walk to any location in the game, if you switch between manually moving and using the map screen there are quite a few spots in the map you will eventually force your way through the shorelines and literally walk on the ocean to skip most of the game.

Combat feels clunky, they designed it in 3 modes(set in options), and none of them really work all that great, real time makes ranged enemies able to fling a hundred arrows/bullets at once, so just don't use that one.

They couldn't have blended fantasy and steampunk any better even if they tried. Credit where credit's due. Troika (rip) always knew what they were doing when it came to RPGs and Arcanum is yet another example. I absolutely love the story, characters and the entire atmosphere of the game, it was unbelieveably good. Even though it did not age well in terms of gameplay and mechanics (as old school CRPGs very rarely do), it's a bit hard to make it work properly since it wasn't remastered for today's computers. But it's an experience that's definitely worth the effort. This game is a cult classic that must be played by anyone who's invested in RPGs.
Great classic. Would recommend to anyone craving for a classic RPG.

The struggles between the forces of magick and tech, the juxtaposition of steam and sword, and the morally gray choices presented to the player at every turn help make Arcanum a memorable cult classic that should be enjoyed by all fans of good reading and great worldbuilding. It‚Äôs flawed and messy at times, but also beautiful, funny, engaging, and enraging at others.

A lot of the same team behind Fallout 1/2 helped bring Arcanum to life. While Fallout endeared its fans with cutesy cartoon characters, nuclear annihilation, and 50s retrofuturism, Arcanum shifts its focus to gentlemanly language, flintlock pistols, and locomotives. 

Fallout's through-lines of player agency and enormous roleplaying potential are even stronger in this steampunk pseudo-sequel. A massive game, a forgotten classic, a must-play for fans of oldschool RPGs that still holds up today.

There some old games that stand the test of time, but I don't think this is one of those. I'd only recommend if you have nostalgia for this game, or if you really like old games in general. I like the idea of the world/lore, and I can ignore the old graphics, but the game mechanics are pretty bad in my opinion. The game play seems a bit overly complex but also too simple in certain respects. Upgrade points apply to both attributes and skills, so you'll likely need to look at the skills you want and only upgrade attribute points so that you can use those skills, is the aim I guess. If you want to go for a ranged build, you'll need to dump quite a bit into it starting out, otherwise it's not very viable. I originally tried going for a gun focused character but only selected one point in guns, found out that means you only have 30% chance to hit which is just pointless really. The AI is pretty dumb and will just go straight after your main character, even if you have party members in between. So this game will likely favor melee builds. Trying a ranged build I had to run around quite a bit till I got lucky and the party member finally hit, which would often get the enemies focus. Final straw for me was this mechanic where my character just fell to the ground with fatigue and stayed down for the whole battle. Figured out after some time it was likely as my mana (fatigue?) bar was getting drained, there's no logs to show for sure it seems. I'll probably give it another try as it's a bit of a challenge now for me to figure out  a good build, but I don't think most people would generally like this. I'd recommend if your into techno-fantasy, probably best to look into the Shadowrun series.

The choice and consequence component in Arcanum is probably better than in many other classic RPGs. Your character can literally impact on nearly everything in this game and gradually change the world.

This one is quite old, but solid oldschool steampunk RPG.

It isn't as famous as "Fallout" series (Sadly), but it has similar fight mechanics than first 2 parts of that series. But here in arcanum, you can change it to the real-time/tactical modes and settings are quite different. The game itself is a hidden gem and you can play it on your gramma's toaster and replay it several times again... It will still be fun.

To keep the story short [b](Spoilers Alert):[/b]

[spoiler]There was peace among all the creatures of Arcanum. Dwarf used advanced tech in their underground castles, elfs had ruled over them magical woods. Humans, used to mind their own business and bulds capitalism&stuff in the outside world... Untill some dwarf picked up a orphan human boy and taught him about dwarwen inventions. Eventually, that got him kicked out of the clan and the boy had become an inventor of steam machines in human society, which lead to an industrial boom... Disturbing the powers of magic, which made elfs and other magical creatures quite unhappy and started a conflict between tech and magic. And after that point, starts the story of the game from protagonist's perspective, you choose how it ends. Keep in mind that your decisions do matter and there are several endings.[/spoiler]

It's an old masterpiece. Good music, ambient, game mechanics... A lot of tactical options to choose from, plenty of texted dialogs, different random quests and a whole steampunk fantasy world to explore. The only bad thing so far, is that since the game is old... It's not that friendly with steam interface.

[b]Do recommend... And I give it a solid 9/10.[/b]

Most gripping questline of any RPG I've played

Uhhh, I am going to be dating myself here a little bit.  I was still in high school when Arcanum came out and loved it!  So when it became available on steam I jumped at the chance, mainly to see what the community would come up with for it and I was not disappointed.  Arcanum is a game with a whole lot of quests that lead to other quests, but with little or no information to lead to the completion of some of those quests.  In a word, going in blind you will be completely lost for a long time.  Save OFTEN!  You will make decisions and then people will attack you and wind up being like, "What the hell just happen?"  This is mainly due to your ever changing character sheet depending on what you learn, actions you take, blessings, curses, being the hero of towns; so much will be effecting what you do if you play straight.  What this means?  it is difficult, but fun.  You rarely experience the same game twice.  Yes, the outcomes are limited, but I for one do not play games for the ending, but the journey.  You can be a human gun slinger one run, a dwarven archer the next, maybe a half-ogre wizard.  At the time of this writing I only have 5 steam hours into the game and playing straight have made it to three towns.  There is about 10 towns in the game and hundreds of hours of possible game play.  The UI is pagey and the fighting is basic slashy.  The sound effects for the weapons and magic and really good with the gun fire and bow work.  Not really able to use controller control and driven by point and click.  You have to have a good plan on what you want to run because skill points to use on your character can be hard to come by in the later part of the game and just from practical skills there are 16 skill sets.  That does not count the magic, tech tree, physical attributes, and health/mana increases.  If you are a fan of old fashion character buffs management, equipment and inventory control, and follower progression; you will love it.
Good story, interesting quests, lots of choices in direction and great companions.  Tedious movement.

Troika has build a very unique, compelling & story-rich world, a fantasy land called "Arcanum" in which magic & technology barely coexist together, this world which is obviously highly inspired by 19th century England during the Industrial revolution, is filled to the brim with interesting lore, dialogue, characters & locations to explore. 

It has very high replay value due to the nearly innumerable ways to customize ones character & build. I personally don't mind the combat mechanics either, my recommendation is to keep it on real-time & only change to turn-based if the enemies are either too hard or too plenty (or both). 
The voice acting is also excellent & the soundtrack is absolutely magnificent. 

I would consider "Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura" to be one the best RPG's of all time, "Top 5" for sure.

Synopsis: 
If there was ever a game that needed a sequel - this would be it. A love child created from past Fallout employees - this is easily a top 10 RPG for me. You get near limitless freedom with how you want to create your character and there are several factors in the development that will have lasting affects on the game. Want to have a magick vs technology focused character? Good versus Evil? Solo or an army of followers? The game leaves it all up to you. The story is great and the character interactions can be sad, uplifting or even down right hilarious. If you are an RPG fan in any capacity you owe it to yourself to buy this game.
