I love this game, It brings me back to when i first started gaming.
One the best games ever made. Period.

I've played this a lot more than 8 hours, used to have a retail copy. Lost the disc, lost the hard-drive, bought it here and on GoG. If you like a Fallout 1 or 2 style cRPG, this'll be up your alley. It's a steampunk-esque high fantasy setting. 

First of all, you may need to do some things before running the game. There are guides to help you with this, but don't expect steam over-lay to work as a result. However, imo, this gem is worth the effort.

There are numerous ways to play the game and build your character. Want to be a gunslinger half-Ogre that's only smart at one thing and dumb about others? You can.

Want to be a wizard halfling that is a trust-fund baby? You can.

Want to be an elven merchant who has a mysterious past? That's also in the cards.

The character customizability isn't to be scoffed at, granted it's not as in depth as, say, Pathfinder: WOTR, but it's deep in its own right, there's just a bit more role-playing you have to do that's not hardcoded into your character. 

The graphics are in line with what you'd expect from Fallout 1 and 2 and Diablo 2. The story, however, isn't. It's its own and, imo, is compelling. I would say it's on a level below Planescape: Torment, which isn't a bad place to be at all. The game is sandboxy so, you can absolutely get the intro quests out of the way and then focus solely on everything else BUT the main story. 

The sound is excellent imo. The soundtrack especially. It give you this early industrial revolution circa 1800's feel and is quality. There's a mix of spoken and written dialog, of the spoken dialog the voice actors did very well imo, the writing itself is fantastic. It reminds me of Morrowind except more coherent. 

My only gripe about the game is the issues I had running it. It needs some severe QOL updates so that it's playable straight out of the box instead of having to much around with various PC settings. I saw SsethTzeentach's review mention that you have to run the game in safe-mode. I didn't have to do that, but I did have to use a shortcut to the exe itself that had a command line that allowed the game to run without steam, which is why I said that there's no overlay. Once I remember the steps I had to take to get things up and running I'll update this guide. 

The story has a mix of linear and non-linear where some things occur differently depending on how you play them, while others are your standard "I can kill just about everyone but the critical NPC's and still get this part of the story". 

If you like classic cRPG's and want a steampunk spin on it, this game is for you.

Perfect example of a diamond in the rough. Definitely shows its age with some missing QoL features and even with fan patches this is super buggy, but it also manages to excel in many ways. Fantastic voice acting along with a charming orchestral soundtrack help elevate its presentation, and mechanically a lot of variety is offered with the combat and your characters background, with many unique and fun presets that can drastically change your game. Depending on your build you may have trouble with some fights, but luckily you can rely on companions to do most of the work if you dump a bunch of points into charisma. Combat aside there's still lots to like here with interesting varied quests that offer loads of different approaches and outcomes.

Admittedly my tolerance for jank is quite high but this is honestly a lot better than I was expecting, and a decent remaster would probably have people talking about this in the same regard as something like Planescape.

A classic broken masterpiece from the departed Troika studios. The best steampunk isometric RPG's I've seen thus far. Has it's share of issues, but if you can see past that at the world building and story is well worth the play.
Tried what i can find of fixes, but the game is still unplayable. Unresponsive buttons/meny items, invisible characters etc
if you like fallout 1 and 2 this is really the only other game out there that can scratch that itch

One of the greatest RPGs of all time.
In what other game can you play as a machine gun-wielding, tuxedo/magnetized top hat-wearing Half-Orc who instigates an Anarchist worker uprising against the racist, eugenicist, capitalist bourgeoisie industrialists who govern London (Tarant) and the rest of its constituent UK (Unified - not United - Kingdom) polities? In what other game can you play as a Dwarf committing genocide against the Elves with mechanized armor and a grenade launcher; or, on the flip-side, as an Elf who commits genocide against the Dwarves by summoning an army of demon rabbits? Those are just a few of the numerous possibilities that you may pursue, should you so desire.
Despite Arcanum being two decades old at this point, there are still few other RPGs that manage to reach the same level of making the player feel like a real part of the world.
For the best vanilla experience I recommend at least playing with the following mods: Multiverse Edition (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=760410053) with Sir Expectations Mod Pack enabled, as it provides much appreciated rebalancing, as well as the mod that makes ammo (bullets, arrows, batteries, fuel) weightless (labelled "ammo.zip" here: https://terra-arcanum.com/forums/threads/latest-uap-vs-other-hacks-patches-etc-etc.23016/).
Highly recommended.
One of my all time favorite games.
It's good.

It's a game that I have a huge nostalgia-bias towards. A 14 year old me, playing this inbetween tests and highschool drama. It will always have a huge weight and place for me, a Lord Of The Rings like adventure, with fellowship, wonder, nestled in a twisted conflict between Magic and Technology. Characters will have philosophical debates, quests will make you question your own prejudices and even racial tensions in a fantasy veneer are brought up, going further than the meme "Elf vs dwarf" conflict - a topic criminally underused in today's RPG games (albeit understandable, considering political implications). If you want to experience a game from a time where political correctness didn't stifle every new release, you will get a brutally honest experience.
Awesome old school game with massive character creation options.  Great sandbox that will develop based on your choices.  Such a shame the company folded and never created a follow up
One of the best games i ever have played.

Arcanum is a great game....but you have to have a bit of patience to get it working properly.
there are official and unofficial patches you need to make it not crash on you. even then, it's still a little buggy.
but, it's one of the best rpg's out there...the story is great, the characters are fun and varied, and it has i think the most unique rpg character system.....you choose either tech or magic....the replayability isn't necessarily endless, but i've had a great time building 4 very different characters, and assembling 4 different teams of follwers, and making different decisions in the game so every quest isn't the same.....there's multiple ways to accomplish most things you just have to think a little about it...

keep a notepad handy to jot down notes, because the journal won't keep all the pertinent info and it can get hard to remember all the details.
save often.
i havent played for more than 38 minutes but playing game would probably make me know why i'd like it. If i were to play trhe game id have it played
One of the best CRPGs ever made, yet p. flawed.

Ive played this for countless hours before i got it on here , i love this game soo much. when i played it back then there were huge problems, bugs ,even game stopping ones, magic system screwed.. but it was worth it. Theres so much to do, different character builds get totally different reactions from npcs and different quests. its a lot of fun experimenting.  Dont let the old graphics hold you back from playing arcanum, its one of the best out there, even now.
Great Steampunk RPG.

I've only played this game for a couple of hours but I'd say it's good once you get over the controls. Very detailed world and character setup, sort of DnD style. If you really don't like classic games, this one's definitely not for you.

6/10

A classic CRPG with an incredible atmosphere. In a beautiful steampunk/fantasy world with great artwork and amazing violin music, that is melancholic and fits the mood well. Complete the game however you want, this game has very great RP opportunities. If you want to play a complete pacifist, that is okay! You can your way out of most situations in the game, including the ends boss. While the world is beautiful, it is kind of empty and too big. Traveling takes time, even though there is a waypoint system in the overworld as well as in the location map. People complain about combat, but I don't see an issue with it at all. It can be hard at times and being a mage with the first Necromantic Black spell is very OP.

9/10, buy it!

Most of my playtime comes from long before Steam was even thought up.  I have to say, not once have I completed a play through.  I spent most of my time wandering the world having fun and adventure, then try a new build style and try again.  This game has more story and atmosphere in the first quest then most big studio titles these days have in their whole game.  Single player, story thick, world full of wonder, and a killer magic vs tech mechanic system that was revolutionary in it's time.
Very Good!

I must have completed at least 5 different play throughs of this game in the early 2000s. It's still one of my all time favourite games and having replayed it recently I think it still holds up. I would recommend it to RPG fans in particular, I can see why it might be too old for others. The story is complex, many of your choices will matter, and they really nailed the steampunk atmosphere. Had a lot of fun, would play again 10/10

I can't bring myself to make a real review for this. I have almost a hundred hours and have never made it past the first main quest dungeon. It's a game I like to start but not play. Idk its pretty cool. Love the theme and truly unique setting. The mechanics are weird, people will say "old game" but Fallout came out a year prior and isn't confusing whatsoever. Thanks Troika

On a serious note, this game does role playing better than any other game in the world, personally. The setting really gives you a feel for your place in the world. As mage, you FEEL like an outcast due to the industrialization of the world, you are not welcome here. As a technologist, you feel your place when you walk through cities with artificial lighting and craftsmanship. That aspect is bretty great.

A great classic with an amazing character advancement system. Be sure to look up how to increase performance under Windows 10, as it uses DirectX 7 (emulated badly in Win10). The best ddirectx.dll implementation comes from Wine.

Hum... Nope. This is an RPG/adventure game. It's a mix of Steampunk and fantasy. The graphics are old and dated. The music is decent. The story might be good but it takes a while to develop, so who knows?

No bugs or crashes. Works fine on Win 7.

Let's see. If you played the first two Fallouts you can get the idea behind this game. A huge map with lots of quests. Plenty fighting. This game will allow you to use technology and/or magic to solve stuff. The crafting system is big and complex, you gonna need to collect a lot of junk along the way. Looks fun? Nah. This game is not Fallout, not even close. This game is a chore. Everything takes forever. There's no real progression, many early quests will require the character to be way more powerful to solve them, so you gonna be running around, and that's a boring chore in itself, looking for quests that you can actually solve. 

The combat is unsatisfactory, to say the least. The RPGaming is deep, but also way too complex and slow, really slow, turtle slow. There're many things unexplained or partially explained. You do need to read the manual, but the manual is the same as the game, weird and tiresome to read. All in this game is designed to take a long time. You can sink a couple of hours playing and not advancing a bit in the quest at hand even if, as said before, turns out you can solve it at all at your current level. So this game is a true time-hog... but doesn't feel rewarding. 

So, It's old, dated, complex, a chore, slow-paced, not too interesting, and the design and direction are nothing to brag about. The idea is good but the implementation is mediocre. This is a very, very niche game. There's a public for this, sure, but I will venture the presumption that those are not legion. As usual, beware of feedback that comes from nostalgia. Don't overpay for this if you want to give it a try, you'll probably gonna ditch it unfinished anyway.

And now, after many years, after I played first Thief game and started to understand that graphics is not important give a try to Arcanum and oh boy... I really like this game, it's an old vintage piece that someone needs to remake at some point and add coop multiplayer.

Troika is the original Fallout creators with a game that looks like it might have been pieced together from the cutting floor of the cancelled original Fallout 3.  It is the work of masters who just had their budget pulled out from under them in a hardcore fashion.  Same top notch writing and design that we all love from New Vegas in a strange little package.

Gameplay is table-top rpg flavored but way more like Fallout 1 and 2 than anything else with a one button switch from real-time to turn based.   Everything takes getting used to coming from other similar games, but once you get the hang of it, its really fun to work with.  Setting is steampunk with characters favoring magic, technology, or classic smashy-smashy.

Current port is functional out of the box albeit without many graphical options.
For fans of early Fallout. I enjoyed playing this one for sure.

Completion Update:
It's still good,I had zero problems/crashes thanks to the patch I assume. It's a great setup.
In my 22 hours, I barely scratched the surface of content.After I completed the game, I went back to see some stuff so It won't be a spoiler for me. I missed tons of companions. I was only a bowman. No magic/no guns/no crafting. In one play through its nearly impossible to try everything properly. So you definitely need more than one. There is at least 40-50 hours worth of content. Worth the money.

Brilliant experience, but only with the fan patch. The game can be played without it, but the experience is vastly improved with it. Without it you will probably encounter some game breaking bugs if your unlucky. The patch is free online, the guys and gals who worked on it did amazing job.

The game I have played thus far that feels closest to the freedom of a TTRPG experience. The amount of not just player choice, but harsh consequence for those choices, was something I did not think was possible for the video game medium. One moment you accept a small side-quest, next you might never be able to get back to a city easily anymore where you still have objectives, because every guard there wants you dead.. and it was all your choices, your doing.

The world actually reacts to you. If you kill (enough) people, it will not go forgotten. If your armor is broken and you are naked, it will be remarked on. If your character is ugly as sin, or one of the more monstrous races, people will treat you with the harshest bigotry. If you do something great, everyone in the city will gain some respect for you. If you are doing evil acts, good followers will not be happy for long. If you are a magic caster, don't expect to be allowed on trains when you get too strong, because your magic will mess with the steam engines. 

There are so many possible builds and individual experiences that the first 4 or so hours, I was just trying out different characters that I wanted to play. I was questioning my choice as half-orc, as everyone treated me badly. I was afraid my experience would be severely halted by this, but it ended up bringing so much flavor for me and influenced how I reacted to the world back, wanting to prove that my character was more than the world told her she was. It informed my every decision, kept me immersed. It influenced where I put my points, rather than what would be most meta or beneficial. If I would have gone with that charismatic elf instead, my choices would likely have been different... but you bet it makes me want to come back to it for that reason. I want to have that other experience. 

.. So the roleplay aspect is absolutely spot on.. however, what is outside of that somewhat suffers. Combat is a mess (especially real-time, which I started out with and therefore stuck with), navigation is a chore and most of the time you are questioning if something is intentional or just broken (I had Raven attack me continuously with stray arrows and I am still not sure if it is a bug or if she was just bad at hitting those arrows). If you don't save every few moments, you will regret it, because you can't walk far without assassins on your ass or the game risking a crash (even with unofficial patch). 

It is an amazing game, but it absolutely had me frustrated on the regular. It is the sort of game you think about so fondly whenever you are not playing it, but curse out as you are playing it (... sometimes). Overall, I love this game, but it is another broken Troika masterpiece. Flawed, but you can't help but like it.

I owned the PC CD_ROM game Arcanum when it released just before 9/11 in 2001 (sorry for morbid reference, but that's why I remember when I got the game).  It is an open-world, point & click adventure game that was the first open-world game I played since the original Legend of Zelda.  It was released by the people who made the original Fallout game.  It was released with Sierra Online.  I did not like the open-world games in the early 2000's because they never held up to Arcanum to me.  It felt so ahead of its time when I played it back then, and it holds up today.  For example, I felt that the original Fallout was a good game, but the map was so small by comparison to Arcanum (which I played first even though Fallout came out in the late 1990s).  Arcanum feels more expansive than its contemporaries, and still feels huge even now.  I played thousands of hours of this game and I played as at least 10 different characters. good, bad and neutral, until my cat was caught munching on the disc after Troika went under.  I wanted to rebuy it, but couldn't find it for over a decade and a half.  When I saw Arcanum on Steam, my nostalgia bug made me buy it immediately, as I never forgot how much I loved this game. 

First of all, magic and steampunk technology...what?!  Hello?  Let's go!  I love a good fantasy game, esp. when there's magic and technology.  And just so you know how much I love the game's aesthetic, I redecorated my bedroom in steampunk not long before the pandemic.  

Weapons and armor can be light or heavy, tech or magic, given as a gift for completing quests, cheap or expensive, or you can make some of them yourself.  Learn from tech masters or the magic colleges. Worship the ancient god of each of the races.  Do it right and you'll be like a god yourself!  Not bad for someone who was getting his or her level one ass handed to them by basically ailing wolves and kites (look like little red cobolds).  

God-like powers aside, my favorite thing about this game is the freedom to do what you want.  You can play it a thousand times and never play the same character twice.  The followers are all so different, and I dig the way the good vs evil vs neutral runs of the game can give you such diverse experiences.  Even the followers are diverse.  There are 25 permanent followers (unless they leave or you kick them out), of all alignments and 5 or 6 temporary followers who will hang with you until you complete their side-quest.  Some followers who don't share your alignment may leave you or even attack you if you do too much they don't agree with.  

If it's your bag, there is a great strategy guide by Prima's Official on Amazon, with all maps, all items, main story, side quests, hidden quests, followers and who they will travel with, secret items, character creator options, where to find masters to train with for magic/technology/skills, and the full descriptions of even hidden things that are harder to find including where they are.  You can even find out which items are sold by which merchants with a description of what percent of the time they'll have them in stock.  It's super-comprehensive.  However, I would suggest at least trying on your own first, though.  If you explore the whole map, you'll find pretty much everything, including a lot of surprises.  Like stalk the whole map in every nook and cranny/  Just wandering around will also build up XP quickly by killing whoever/whatever you meet that attacks you, and it won't put off your good or bad followers if the people you kill attacked first.  I played on my own first then went back with a relatively neutral half-elf and played with the strategy guide so I'd see what I missed.  There's so much to find, with or without the guide.  Now, I just use the guide mostly for the maps (I'm lazy about remembering locations).  Finally, a quick review of the game mechanics is on Wikipedia, along with a synopsis that I recommend you don't read unless you've played before.  The surprises are half the fun of the story.  

In summary, this game remains one of my favorites, and I am not alone.  It sold well, was well-received by critics, and won some awards.  I highly recommend it even now, despite all the open world games that are newer.  The few things people complained about never affected my gameplay, and it plays just as well on Steam as it did on CD_ROM.  It's a download requiring about 1 GB of space, so it's a large game for when it came out.  Make sure you have room.  If your friends also have it, it has a multiplayer mode.  Play turn-based, fast turn-based, or real-time.  So many options and replay potential...I missed this game and I appreciate so much that Steam brought it back.

Good luck if you decide to try it!  This rabbit hole runs deep, but what a great ride!

Listen here Lads and Lasses, I have FAR more time in this game than what is shown. Once I got the Widescreen Mod, (Which I HIGHLY recommend), it stopped logging My time. This is one of the GREATEST RPG's ever! It is absolutely fantastic! Whether you go Sword n" Board, Wizard, or Tech Guru, it is engaging, interesting, grim, and just amazing. I rank it up there with the original Baldur's Gate, it IS that good. I have 5 Characters currently, all doing completely different things, and I'm loving exploring the world of Arcanum.

Ok so I saw someone complaining that they had to restart the game when they get stuck in turn based mode. All you have to do, is double tap spacebar to go out of and back into turn based mode. This will fix the problem. Sincerely, an Arcanum veteran.

This is one of those highly underrated hidden gems from back in the day. Before Steam was even a thing, I put hundreds and hundreds of hours into it. I highly recommend this game if you like old isometric RPGs. The game incorporates guns, swordplay, magic, and invention into the combat system. If you use guns, magic becomes increasingly ineffective on you as you progress in the tech tree. And vice versa for magic. Say you are a powerful magic user. Try to use a gun and it will backfire on you. The characters and story are so engaging too. No character is essential, so you can really screw up the story if you kill the wrong person. Everything you do effects the characters' disposition towards you in a small way, even scars on your face from combat effect your beauty rating, making people like you less. You can receive blessings and curses that effect all kinds of aspects of gameplay. What's also really cool is that creating a custom starting bonus and background for your character is super easy. Just edit a couple of text files, and you pretty much created your own mod! I like making backgrounds like "Attacked by Bees", which gives you a penalty to your beauty stat but a high constitution, giving you resistance to poison, and giving my character better starting equipment. Any custom background you can imagine is super easy to create. Thought I owned it on GOG, bought it on Steam to use the overlay. Found out you can't use the overlay. Went over to GOG, I apparently don't have an account. So I'm buying it again :)

Someone might call this RPG old-school, others might call it archaic. No matter what words do you choose, the fact is that the game mechanics are very complex and the controls quite counter-intuitive, making the game confusing and hard to learn for new players. So the question is: Are you willing to invest several hours into learning this game's inner workings or not? If yes, then you are going to have a great time. If not, then you should avoid this game.

This isnt Baldurs Gate, or Icewind Dale, or Planescape, or Fallout 1or2, It's unlike any of these isometric games. It's a steampunk world with magic and tech fighting each other. You could be the gigachad half elf throwing fireballs, or the technological-savant drawf that blasts foes with guns and bombs. It does have a crafting system, day-night cycle, stealth, roguery, reputation level (good or evil), different factions, quests have multiple outcomes.

Overall a pretty solid title. It sucks it didnt get the fandom that the titles I listed at the top got.
One of my favorite games but unfortunately full of bugs.  Trying to get all the patches to get as clean asossible which causes a few fresh copies to be attained. Still worth it!!!

An underappreciated gem that didn't get finished or recognized, still one of the deepest RPGs ever despite it. EA should let the license of this loose, let this Troika masterpiece live!

Dialogue, story and general vibe - great, highly recommend. I usually skip or skim dialogue in rpgs, but Arcanum is a notable exception.

Combat - causes me to go into a blind rage and thrash my keyboard like a manchild when I die because my character suddenly can't hit anything and he along with my entire party dies to a drunk halfling in some random pub after all the patrons become agro when I attempt to fight back after some random npc starts a barfight with me and I lose an hour of progress.

If you want to have a good time in this game, play a charisma character and for the sake of your own sanity, do not skimp on assigning points to vitality or fatigue like I did. With high charisma, you can collect all of the companions and gangbang any enemy you come across, but without a decent amount of vitality, your party doesn't matter as you won't survive most combat encounters.
This is the best game ever. Seriously. Just play it for an hour or 2.

This is the worst best game ever made.

Everything about this game is great!  The atmosphere, the story, the setting, the dialog, the RPG elements, the choices you make, the characters, the multiple ways to solve problems.  This is even better than Fallout 2 was back in the day!!!

Except the combat sucks sooooooooooooo  F'ing bad.  It's AWFUL.  It's a bunch of sprites bonking heads on screen.  It feels like I'm playing an NES game from 1992.  

What good is a game if you despise the combat?  Sorry but that makes all the great things about the game not worth it.  As much as it pains me to, I have to say pass on this.  Play Fallout 2 instead.

Stumbled upon this old relic from eons past. I remember playing it as a teenager back before Dwarves invented steam power. Countless hours playing this from a disk. When I found it on steam, I put it on the wish list as I was balls deep in another game at the time and it went on sale a week later so I bought it.

It is an old school RPG where you click on the ground to move and click on an enemy to auto attack. There are two paths you can choose. Magic or Technology. Progressing in one diminishes the effectiveness of the other. Being a tech guy you can make and use all manner of marvelous machines but the better you get, you might wanna find a tech replacement for your magical healer in your party as you impede each other's effectiveness. His spells won't work as well on you and I believe (although I've not noticed) your tech fails in the presence of magic.

Gameplay is a bit slow and the background music is dreary and depressing but that's the scene of the narrative.

Totally recommend!

Arcanum. The game that was released nearly 20 years ago, and still considered one of the ten, maybe one of the hot five best games in the steampunk setting. And one of the deepest RPG universes, with all those magic vs. technology Yin/Yang collisions, with so much diversity in the possible playstyles, characters, situations, and all that jazz. And It Is actually one of the greatest videogames I ever played, all hands down. It still has its 'one more quest, one more turn' needle of the strong addiction. I've played it on the release, and I still enjoy playing it now.

But.

With all that deep immersion, all those tons of quests, stories, and other nice and cozy stuff, Arcanum always had that ugly taint of the bad coding. Only the list of its technical problems can be longer than the compilation of all dialogs in many modern RPGs.

It all starts with the resolution. '800—Ö600—Ö65536' was already dated when the game hit the shelves. I remember some tweaking we did about it with other boys from the neighborhood, and it was before we get access to the Internet, because it was much more expensive and overall complicated than now. And you know what? Every time when I was reinstalling Arcanum after that, there were some new issues to fight with. But every time, it was something about weird resolution and screen behavior, for starters.

And what about now? Is it working? Is it dead, or still alive?
Well, you can play it out of the box, just by installing the game (thanks to the GOG release with resolution fix, I presume). Like I said from the start, it is still one of the greatest isometric RPGs. It is still providing just as much delight for any genre connoisseur, as it did in 2001. But, there are 95% chances that you'll need to download some unofficial, fan-made patch, to fix something. So tread consciously.

Speaking of the overall rating for Arcanum, it's a really complicated issue for me. For the provided content, it's kinda 9.5/10. For the technical realization, I dunno... 5/10? It's bugged as hell, and it still bothers me even with the latest patch installed. I love Arcanum, and it haunts and hurts me. A great game. Burns like the summer sun.

A decent CRPG but lacks polish.  Most of the dialogue and quests in the game are extremely dry and uninspired.  Most of characters you talk to feel like they're just interactive sign posts to point you in the direction you need to go, with no defining characteristics.  

The game play is also very unbalanced, with magic being much better than any other build.   The combat is also fairly janky, ranging from massive RNGfests to effortless steamroll depending on your build. 

You NEED to install the unoffical patch unless you want to play at extreme low resolutions without widescreen.   

Give it a go if you want to try a CRPG in a unique setting, but don't expect a game with the same quality of Fallout 1/2.

A jankier Fallout set in a fantasy land undergoing an industrial revolution. I love the amount of work that has gone into worldbuilding. It's not just an aesthetic choice or a flimsy context to have guns, steam engines and tophats. The subject of industrialization and its consequences is treated with a thoughtfulness that I haven't even seen in some "historical" games.

Character creation and progression are some of the very best around; there's a lot of room for experimentation, and the game makes an effort to accommodate different playstyles in its quest design.

It's a shame, then, that the biggest flaw this game has is the combat. You can switch between turn-based and real-time on the fly; both feel half-baked, and the encounter design is hot garbage: endless waves of enemies with nary a need for strategizing on your part.

Nevertheless, on the whole, this is one of the richest roleplaying experiences ever made and one of my favorite games.

This has one of the best character creation set-ups I've ever played with in a game, old or new. Oh, not visually. But as far as building an interesting, ready-made character: definitely. 

The actual gameplay is a bit of a slog. I didn't play old-school Western RPGs back in the day. Took me a minute to figure out fast travel, and frankly combat is boring and the palette is dark and makes it hard to distinguish buildings and NPCs at first glance. Also they missed a golden oppurtunity not making Virgil a love interest and I'm still salty about it. 

But this is a fantastic world with so much promise, and I still keep tabs on former Troika Game devs to this day in hopes of coming across hidden gems like Arcanum.

Note: Multiverse Mod includes UAP as well as other modes. UAP alone is enough though.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=760410053

TLDR: Can be empty, confusing, and dated. Made up for by great lore, great character customization options, a unique setting.

Recommend: 
Turn Based Combat
Use of a Walkthrough as strategy guide to cut down on confusing levels, maps, and hidden npcs in large sprawling maps. Arcanum Fandom Wiki is a great place to start.
Use of Unofficial Patch UAP 2.0.2 which reintroduces exotic races for player characters, allow XP sharing without the educator perk and disabling XP gained on hit and instead giving party XP on kills. enables widescreen resolution and fixes bugs and increases level cap for more variety in builds. You can right click on teammates portraits for a dropdown menu including combat orders.
If you decide ton install UAP remember to install it in the SECOND arcanum folder(inside the first arcanum folder). Feel free to enable most if not all of the optional options as they were curated by the modmaker.

Tips: You can end combat with the red shield button on the left side of the hud. You can use spacebar to quickly togger into Turn Based Combat or Back into Real time Combat. You can enable auto run to make travelling smoother. You can manually start combat by pressing the red shield, pressing R. You can Right click outta combat icon back to talking iconl. You can hold ALT while clicking in combat mode to destroy objects such as jammed doors. You can read the manual by pressing the button in the launcher. You can populate the toolbar from the open inventory by drag&drop of potions, grenades, lockpicks and other items. It is possible to scrounge large amounts of small sellable items such as shoes and iron daggers that you can sell to merchants as well as crafting materials from rubbish bins that respawn somewhat daily. Enemy corpses will still have their weapons and armors equipped in a separate window and not in the main loot window. So use the left red arrow LOOT ALL to get those, or manually open their paperdoll inventory by clicking the appropriate small button. if you dont want to blow up the generator in shrouded hills you can get the dernholm location from a human villager by a cow south east of percivals house after you heard of Dernholm from Percival. In arcanum mages can cast while wearing armor and can even benefit from special arcane armors. Sometimes the examine function at shops or to shop enemy health will no longer work. Exiting the game and returning seems to remove the default name-only descriptions and restore the proper examine information from hovering the mouse. You can right click to directly transfer items over to shopkeepers or across companion inventory. The numbers next to crafting components indicate the required skill level and the icon the skill type, it does NOT meant the number of components required to craft one. 1 point in a disciple ~= 10 points. Rubbish bins can be use to discard unwanted items since they respawn while chests in inns and the warehouse in tarant can be used as storage. You can mouse over the Sword and Shield icons in the character sheet to see a detailed breakdown of attack and defense stats to compare results of different gear. Drag and drop large items like armors to toolbar to make space. Right click drag and drop to return them to inventory. You can advance time one hour (small icon at top right of screen) to refill magicka. Use the KEY, BLUEWORLD and GEAR to access SKILLS MAGIC AND TECH. Click on map to add waypoints, big round button to GO. Buy multiple manuals of same type to stack additional free tech skill points based on INT. If you get 5 spells in a college and do the mastery dungeon you dont need to wear amulet to get the 50% mana discount on sustained and direct spells.

Liam Cameron Portal Method
A much faster & efficient way to level up is by killing monsters that come through the portal in Find Liam Cameron quest. The monsters spawning through the portal will let you level up extremely fast. However, the monsters are very strong so make sure you can kill them fast.
-- Personal Note: Monsters stopped spawning randomly after a short while --

Overworld Exploring Method !! This Method also gives gold if you kill Molochian Agents!!
If you travel from location to location in the overworld, more often than not you will encounter random enemies which will attack you on sight. You can simply keep travelling around in the overworld endlessly and kill the monsters you encounter. Some areas of the world map have higher encounter frequencies than others; check WMap_Rnd.mes for more information.

This is one of the greatest, fundamentally flawed games you will ever play.
It's was a huge creative achievement, everything from the music (it has one of best soundtracks in video game history) to voice acting, to story itself is amazing and just as enjoyable today as it was back in the day.

I don't think there ever was a CRPG title where you could roleplay charismatic leader leading a group of competent and deadly individuals. Point is, you can play Arcanum in million and one way, and although there are superior character builds (magic in particular is overpowered) each is viable in it's own way.

Now for the bad. Even for the time Arcanum was rough around the edges. It's not ugly but it lacks polish other CRPG titles had (Baldur's or Planescape or even Fallout). 
AI is atrocious, there's simply no way around it. You cannot modify the behavior of your followers which makes certain party members almost useless. For example, embracing technology makes it so your character resists any magic influence (healing spells included). If you get hurt while having a Virgil (magic healer) in a group, he will proceed to spell himself into a coma trying to heal you. Balance is all over the place and it can be difficult to get of the ground if you're low charisma technologist for example while mage will stomp everything into a pulp. 

But even with everything said there's just something about arcanum that makes me want to play it over and over again. Not sure if it's nostalgia inducing melancholy soundtrack or the fact that crafting in this game is actually purposeful and can support variety of playstyles. 
It's a game well worth your time.

Classic RPG

Best cRPG ever made and here is why:

- Great and original ambience and setting, medieval colonial vs technology (gunpowder, energy, engines)
- Amazing story with great characters
- Living world with npc routines
- Freedom of choice with real consequences in the world
- You can role play your char with a freedom no other game has managed to do
- Char creation is deep in stats and it will totally change how you'll progress in the game

Other things that this game does really good:

- magic schools, lots of magic and progression on each school
- crafting, technology and items
- great voice acting on main npcs
- the music is amazing

Standard things:
- combat is as any other cRPG, although you can toggle if going turn based or in real time

So, is there some negative?
Well... I can only say time did leave graphics a little dated, but still looks artistically good.

It is (if not THE greatest) one of the best cRPGs of all times.

Totally recommended... I really miss Troika Games =(

It took me a while before I finally approached to play this game. It's funny, since it was pretty high on my list because it was made by developers of two first Fallout games, which I consider to be one of the best CRPGs ever made. Unfortunately, Arcanum has aged unfavorably. Maybe in early 2000s it could be considered as a pretty good isometric RPG, but by today's standards it can be only considered as average, or even user unfriendly.

Our journey in Arcanum begins with a crash of an airship, which was assaulted for unknown reasons by a group of bandits in air fighters. Being the only one survivor of the crash, we have to find a reason why it happened and who is responsible for it. To solve the mystery, the only thing we have is an advice of a dying man: "find a boy and give him this ring. It's all up to you, my friend". And then, we are moving out for our quest. Main storyline has all what it should have: there's a mystery, there is a secret assassin society, there are wrong and good choices, even few interesting plot twists. As for the main quest - not only I found it properly done, but it also assured me that developers of the game were capable of creating pretty interesting storyline and lore. They also gave us a plenty of possibilities for creating a character: warrior, mage, archer, gunslinger etc. The character creator menu can be overwhelming at the start. The best way to understand it is to just play a game, so better be ready that you might start all over again to upgrade your skills effectively.

This open world has over 80 locations to visit: bigger towns, smaller towns, camps, caves, islands, ruins, castles and many others. Exploring the world won't make them easy to find, since they does not appear on the world map even if our route goes next to it, and it's a huge flaw in my opinion. Original Fallouts had no such problem for example, because locations became visible to us when we moved nearby. In Arcanum, in most cases we will find out the specifics about visiting places through dialogues. Unfortunately, even if someone will tell us about certain locations and we will visit them, not many of them will be interesting. Also, exploring them can be a time consuming quest. Most of the buildings in Arcanum cities and villages look exactly the same, there is no recognition points to find our way around, and because of that at the beginning of the game it's very easy to get lost in large cities. To make exploring easier for us, developers gave names to most of the streets in the game, but it seems more like a design laziness. Architecture in a world of magic and machines (since it's steampunk) should give to the developers a lot of space for artistic expression, but this aspect of the game was not treated with the attention it deserves. World of Arcanum - despite all of its potential - lacks artistic uniqueness and brings no emotions to the player through its visuals.

One of the biggest problems of this game is its illegibility: it lacks of deeper interaction with its world and characters. A simple icon of eyeglass, a possibility of taking a closer look at the environement (terrain, objects, characters) to see its better description would be a great improvement in a game that uses 2D graphics. Yet, it isn't there, neither the situation-log (like Pip Boy 2000 from Fallout games). For this reason, specifics of the world around us are very poor. Of course we can find books throughout our journey that could explain the nature of Arcanum to us, but I am talking about actual options of experiencing its world right here and right now. The fact that areas are big and full of different objects and characters, it's a shame that a player does not get proper tools to explore it and manipulate through it. Illegibility creates a compulsion that pushes us to ask all the questions and speak with as many NPCs as we can. As it seems pretty cool in the beginning - since the dialogues in RPGs are important - the result is not enjoyable at all. "More" not always means "better". Arcanum gives us a liberty to speak with almost every character in the game (you can also kill everyone if you want), but not many of NPCs has something interesting to say. 90% of dialogues in this game concentrates around asking about news in town, trading, looking for a way somewhere or playing dice. There is nothing interesting in such dialogues at all, and at some point in the game we are starting to figuring out which NPCs might have something interesting to say. In most cases there is no way to distinguish which characters are important and which ones are useful only to show us the way; the only option is to talk with all of them, and find out for ourselves. Usually in RPGs you can't speak with everybody, but when you finally meet a NPC that you can talk to, dialogue with him most probably will reward you with information, quest, his story, he might share his personal feelings about the in game world. Unfortunately, dialogues in Arcanum are not interesting at all. If we are patient enough to look through all the NPCs on the screen, someone finally will give us a quest or information about important people's whereabaouts. Until we find them, we can start to feel overwhelmed by size of the world of Arcanum.

Side-quests themselves are mostly fetch-ones: bring me this, bring me that, which should be expected. What bothers me, is that the main story quests are a proof that developers are capable of creating interesting scenarios, yet in a world of this size (I will repeat: there's over 80 locations that we can visit) there is not so many side quests that might be interesting. The ones I remembered the most were the "Ghost of Bessie Toone" and the one with mastering melee combat (there's a sad love story involved).

The last aspect of the game that I will speak of is its combat: it's not balanced properly! We can choose between turn-based or real-time mode - we change it by pressing space. The beginning of the game might be tough (I've played on hard difficulty as half elve) and we can have a really hard time with the bandits, especially when it comes to hand in hand combat, but it's normal: we need more experience, more equipement, good companions. But even if we level up pretty well and we are managing to take care of ourselves and our crew, one of the main quests will take us to the location where we will have to fight with several golems. At this point of the game most of the players should be confused, since not only our weapon breaks on them, but also they kill us with a few hits, so it should be good to keep them on distance, but if throughout your game you wanted to create a melee-based character: you're in trouble. Watch out, because Black Mountains are the most annoying part of the game. It gets a lot easier with magic (I recommend [SPOILER]harm spell or pyrotechnic axe[/SPOILER]). There's more: fighting can be pretty messy, since our characters are dropping very often their weapons. It happens mostly in real-time combat mode, that after few moments we realize that one of our characters is fighting using bare hands and we have no idea where he or she lost its weapon - our companions, nor our protagonist have no self preservation instinct to pick it up automatically without our direct order. Basically, a challenge of combat in this game was over for me when I have found a strong companion (spoiler: [spoiler]a dog[/spoiler]). And with that much of a force in my team, no enemy, no bandit and no boss was no longer a problem.

To be finished: I can't recommend this game. Of course it can still find its fans, maybe some old-school & hardcore RPG players will find it interesting, but for me it just aged pretty badly. It has its pros, but they are dissapearing in the blackness of dull dialogues, non-balanced combat and uninteresting locations. 5/10.

If only I could show you the places I have seen, you might understand the things I say. I have been to the Desolate Lands, wandered by those souls who still see the lands of the living but wear the cloak of the dead. Blind to their own ends, they cry, passing through one another like shadows in the dying light of day. I have travelled to where souls rot in torment, pierced with the jagged shards of life and vision, clinging to memory - regrets of the flesh. I saw that this prison was of their own making, and that the key was in unknowing, in release... and still, I travelled on. And finally, I came to the place where souls go to die. Where the mirrored and worn spirits fall into an endless sea of grey, mirrored glass... and I lowered myself within... and lay among them... and I almost did not return. And do you know what I found there? There, among the silent and battered shells of the innumerable? Peace. Enlightenment. Truth. Only then I realized that this place, this "Life", is an abomination, a horrible distortion of the natural order.

This "Life", who mothered Pain, and Fear, and Envy - these twisted children who exist only because we are here to feed them, to nourish them. This "Life", this... afterthought - a disturbance, a mere ripple in that great, dead sea, not even the cause, but merely an effect, sending these souls upwards, screaming for release from the day they are torn from their waters! The effect of what! I do not know. Nor do I care.

I see your soul, traveler. It screams, tattered and spent. Do you feel its pull? Do you hear its wailing? It is within my power to calm these waters, and that is what I shall do.

Have you ever spoken with the dead? Called to them from this side, pulled them from their silent rest? Do you know what it is that they feel? Pain. Pain, when torn into this wakefulness, this reminder of the chaos from which they had escaped. Pain, at having to live. There will be no more pain. There will be no more chaos.
Passei 2,1 horas tentando abrir o jogo, e simplesmente n√£o funcionava. E a steam n√£o quis me reembolsar. Triste. Porque era um jogo muito bom.

It's a classic RPG from some of the same guys that made Fallout. Yes, it's good. Lots of quests, rich dialog and some potential plot twists, freedom to do good or evil, and a deep character development system. RPG fans will like it. 

I'm still in the early stages but having a good time. However, there are some quirks. 
- The game makes you run all over the the place and it's pretty grueling to keep tracking back and forth across the map. The maps seem to let you run forever if you want; there's no clear delineation of a border where you can then move to the world map. The game does show it, but you have to watch for the map icon to change; then you can move onto the larger map. 

- The game doesn't always do a good job of letting you know what you should be doing next. In some ways, that's part of the strength, it's letting you choose your own adventure, but in others it can be frustrating. 

Update 2020-Dec-24: Merry Christmas to you. I have an update. After upgrading my system to a dual monitor setup (with two monitors that are better than the one I used before), I can no longer run Arcanum. I'm not sure if this is because there are two monitors, if it's because both are higher resolution than the old monitor, or if it's because the two monitors are different resolution. I could probably disconnect one of the monitors and see if it runs that way, but instead I'll probably just wait for the modders to eventually fix the issue. I still think this is a great game and want to play it, but there are too many games in the backlog that don't require hassles, so that's what it'll be for now. If I get really inspired, I will install Arcanum on a second PC with just one monitor or maybe a laptop. 

- You don't really know when you're level-appropriate for an encounter. The way you find out is to die. Again, that may be a function of the game's openness, but even though they're a bit more restricting, there is something to be said for zone control that lets you move to areas when you're ready and save you some reloads. 

- The in-game knowledge sharing is a bit weak. You really have to read the manual or a faq. There aren't tool tips on interface controls where you'd like them, and I played the first part of the game not really understanding what I'm supposed to do with the balance between magic and technology, which is one of the game world's foundational pieces. 

- Would it have killed them to make the early stores have a lockpick set for sale?

- Inventory management is pretty old school. And it sure would have been nice to have had some hints about "Yeah, that stuff's useless, you can sell it," and "That item will be really useful if you're going to craft as a wizard (or techie) so keep it." Yes, I know it's an old game, but a legit criticism is a legit criticism. 

- Apparently the game has issues with modern operating systems. Thankfully, good effort by modders has led to patches that will not just make the game playable but even better. Check these out for sure, and thanks to the modders!
10/10 horrifically janky and hurts my eyes

I'm having so much fun, it's unreal! It's been a long time since a game pulled me in this much. The world feels so organic and alive, you can talk to NPCs so many different ways and get quests done so freely. If you have a better idea than doing quests straight on, you will find that you can!! You can absolutely do anything!!! It almost feels like playing D&D or an adventure book!

good old skool game from the D2 era

Absolutely excellent. While Arcanum isn't quite as sharp as its older brother Fallout 2 in the gameplay department, it's easily one of the most intriguing rpgs out there both thematically and in story. 

I'm a firm believer that there's more to video games than how it looks and how it plays, but if you're one of those people that is unable to get over "bad graphics" and "jank", then I'm sorry but the rpg genre in general probably isn't for you... although to be fair, if Arcanum was a woman, it would be a very dog faced woman.
Masterpiece! 10/10

While the gameplay is rather jank, and it takes a bit of fixing to fix the lag issue, this is potentially the best CRPG on the market.

Arcanum's story isn't told via it's plot. In fact, it's plot is rather loose and open ended. Instead, Arcanum's story is told through the world presented to you, and that's what makes it great. The world itself is teeming with life and personality. I urge you to speak to every npc, complete every quest, read every book, and search every cave. It doesn't take much for it to begin pulling you in, which will leave you wanting for more. This accompanied with the melancholic yet hopeful soundtrack is what makes this game be known as a broken masterpiece.

Arcanum is a world where magick and technology co-exist in perpetual competition. It's like Shadowrun in the 19th century. But instead of hacking you can become a technologist who can assemble firearms and explosive devices out of stuff found in garbage bins around cities. If you focus your training and become really good, you can make machineguns and powerful steam-powered machines that fight alongside you. Or you can be a sorcerer who throws fireballs and heals himself with blue magic lights... The choice is up to you, but the latter choice definitely sounds boring, you can do that in thousands of other games... :) 

The story, the dialogues are clever and really well written. The whole world is really charming and captivating, it is a big open world. Arcanum is the best RPG ever made, along with Fallout and Fallout 2. It's not for the modern players though, no quest markers and hand-holding typical for modern games. And that is also part of its greatness. If you like classic games and their complexity, you can't miss here.

A beautiful mix of magic and steampunk technology, makes me very nostalgic for the early days of RPGs. Has a beautiful soundtrack and a fantasy/steampunk world filled with immersive lore. Reminds me of my early diablo 1/2 days...
The best steampunk ever

The closest you're ever going to get to a high-fantasy RPG in the style of classic Fallout: a majority of the same developers, same general approach to storytelling/worldbuilding, and and a good amount of shared mechanics implementation. All the elements are there, and in most of their accustomed places; there's just [i]more[/i] of it: more world map, more quests, more lore spread more evenly across more consistent story beats. It's almost what you'd expect Van Buren to have been, had Interplay not shot itself in the foot and nixed Black Isle's development of it.

Unfortunately, 'more stuff' also necessitates 'more stuff what can break' and Arcanum is nothing if not inclined to break. As other posters have noted, the widescreen fix and unofficial patch are absolutely essential on newer systems (and make sure you get the right version), and even then you'll run into the occasional glitched companion or hard crash in the second half. It's nothing you can't work around via the old 'save often and in different slots' mentality (especially as there are no autosaves), but it can be a little wearing when you enter Tulla and Virgil suddenly decides to polymorph into a random NPC for the sixth time that day.

Is it worth it? Absolutely, especially if you consider price vs. length of potential use. Will it take you a couple of restarts to figure out your preferred playstyle and acclimate yourself to the combat/magic/tech utility balance? Just like Fallout, yes. Is the story worth the occasional slog to get to it? Yes, though if you're finding yourself bogged down more by the combat or bugs that you were in similar titles, you'd be forgiven for just picking up where you left off in a YouTube walkthrough. 

Oh -- and a final note about the soundtrack: though it wouldn't be my first choice for a game like this (I prefer my fantasy pastoralism in Jack Wall or Jeremy Soule flavour), it is [i]objectively[/i] well-composed and worth a listen. It's a little heavy on the weepy violin in places, and the main theme ends up as a motif for way too many locations in-game, but the string-quartet style otherwise really suits the steampunk aesthetic.

Its a very old game that is unplayable on WIN10 without a lot of fiddling with the program files. It is very easy to corrupt the save file by alt-tabbing and playing just a few minutes will cause the game to start experiencing significant slowdown. 

The character customization is a little dated, with multiple races being exclusive to male characters with  no exclusive races for female characters.

The game doesn't seem to have an in-game listing for keyboard shortcuts, nor does the UI show you what shortcut goes to what.

That said, after installing an unofficial patch and running the game in winxp compatibility mode, the game is a very deep and satisfying RPG that has a lot of dialogue and neat combat mechanics.
One of the weirdest, best rpgs ever made.

I bought this game during a Steam sale because people online said that it was the spiritual successor to Fallout 1. It is not.

The combat system is crap. It starts off real time and there is no time to make decisions since you have to go into menus to choose which attacks/spells you want to do. You can change it in the options to turn-based, but that combat is even worse because the game wasn't balanced on it. 

There are too many needless items. I only played the game until the first town because the combat was so bad, but I had an entire inventory and follower inventory completely full with items that I couldn't even barter with. I'm assuming that some of them are for crafting, but I couldn't store them until I got to a point when crafting would be viable, otherwise I couldn't pick up any other items. 

The user interface is clunky and un-intuitive. 

The game runs through a launcher that isn't compatible with Steam. I played for like and hour and a half, then exited the game, but steam still thought the game was running. When I pressed STOP in Steam, the phantom game kept going. I used task manager to close the game. Steam still said it was running. I had to re-launch the launcher then exit the game so that could finally press STOP to be able to uninstall the game on Steam. My hours are like 11 on Steam because I didn't realize it was still "running" in the background.

I would not waste your time/small amount of money on this game.

Compatibility issues. 

Easy method, enter steams install directory for Arcanum and create a shortcut to the main executable file and add to the target field in properties after the file paths end quote -no3d. -no3d is built into the game. No patch required. Set compatibility mode to Windows XP SP3 and run as admin. Should run much better and not crash. 

Another option is to use the Unofficial Arcanum Patch 2.02 latest version downloaded online, it has DDraw compat included and will modify the DDraw.dll file allowing the game to run on windows 8 and up. The version is correct and works well, better than DXwrapper.  However the steam overlay is not compatible with this patch and could crash the game and needs to be disabled if you want Steam to log your game hours. 

There is also a DDraw fix for baldurs gate that has two files you can use which works alright. 

The UAP patch is a good performing option and allows for high resolution and windowed modes.

The best of all CRPG's. The spiritual successor to Fallout 2. 

The tastiest of Troika's three games.

The one, the only, ARCANUM!

The Good
========
The setting for this game has been developed with a lot of depth. One can slowly discover it while going along the main quest. Side quests also often provide extra bits of information that flesh out the world even more.
If you like exploring and discovering a complex world as you go along, you will like this game.
The whole idea of Magick-vs-Technology goes much deeper than what is known to the player upon character creation, as are the specificities of the various "races".
The setting seems to draw some inspiration from the real-life Victorian Era, some from Tolkien (which is actually consistent, as a glimpse of the beginning industrial revolution is described at the end of the last book from the Lord of the Rings).
Many assumptions that your character (and you) may have at the beginning of the game will change as you go along, which is a good thing.

Also, this game runs fine on Linux (at least with the standard patch recommended elsewhere, which should be installed anyway).

The Bad
=======
After the first few hours of playing, going from location to location becomes a bit of a hassle. The wilderness map (with random encounters) is quite alright, but the annoying bit is travelling around a town and exiting the town in order to access the wilderness map.
A partial workaround is to use the teleportation spell. This can be learned if one chooses to specialize in Magick, or can be used by an NPC follower... well, not quite: a "cheat mod" is needed, called "Virgil Debug menu", but it can be used in a non-cheat way like this: take control of NPCs leveling schemes (switch to "No Scheme"), keep Virgil as a follower and have him progress until he can learn Teleport. Then use the menu provided by the mod, but think of it as actually asking Virgil to use his teleport spell, which is quite reasonable, really.
By the way, there are quite a few spells, like teleport, that a follower can learn but won't use and can't be asked to use, which is a bit sad (conversely, technological followers can be asked to use their schematics).

The Ugly
=======
Sometimes immersion is broken by dialog that seems to have been designed to satisfy  a 15-year old boy's sexual fantasies, e.g. suggesting to a maid that she can go and work in a brothel instead, which she will happily do (and seem happy to have done afterwards - seriously?), or asking a widow whether you can "comfort her" (literally written like that, with a cut scene if you do). Also, apparently this kind of awkward dialog stays the same if your PC is female.

I played it when I was younger so it was a real nostalgia trip for me. I enjoyed coming back to it and seeing there be a community for it. If you enjoy older types of games with a good open world and story I'd reccomend it.

9/10 - What an excellent game... took three tries to get past the slow opening; Extremely glad and satisfied to experience it.

+++ For fans of Vampire TM, Fallout 1 & 2, DoS, Planescape... even Disco Elysium - this game is a treat
+++ Do soup your experience up with the latest patch, level cap remover and Arcanum Edit to correct leveling mistakes/experiment
+++ Fantastic lore, world, design, characters, narration, story, exposition and art
++ Writing is top notch as each character in the game is well realized and the world quite believable
++ Some flying "aces" with orc-like features down your airship and a survivor starts your journey with his dying breath...
++ Be a mage patrician or a crafting pleb or min/max to do both adequately with level cap mod remover
++ Very original game that has few contemporaries being quite unique
++ Plays like F1/2 with a higher learning curve to fully understand the game mechanics
++ When looting there are 2 TABS, be sure to check both INVENTORY and BODY as I missed the BODY part for my first 10 hours...
++ Do use a guide/look up items to smooth out/modernize the game as tutorials are formalized in the game manual which should be read
++ You cannot steal equipped items without using fate points/stone body exploit - thankfully DoS did not follow this principle
++ Stable/no crashes/latest unofficial patch a dream; performance wonderful with only light stuttering as you hoard away a king's ransom
+ Majority of items in the game are useless/limited purpose. Do look up their purpose prior to starting your collection spread over random drawers/barrels all over the world's cities
+ Garbage cans are not a permanent storage of your gems & trinkets
+ Humor usage wonderful; plenty of homages and wonderful moments
+ Ending slides quite memorable


- Main story falls off a bit/quite similar to PoE philosophical overtures making it difficult to follow especially in the last act
- If only this was not rushed/released full of bugs/incomplete at launch. Shame so much potential did not have a chance of producing further excellent craftsmanship due to the shortcomings on the business side.

So far I have tried charismatic elven mage and ugly dwarven thief technologist. Very interesting and different experience! Now I can clearly see that this game was well ahead of its time. In addition the magical and technological amplitude dilemma is cool once you get the understand the basics. At least with unofficial patch this game is still very playable almost after 20 years of its original release! You cannot say the same for many games!

[code]This review is an excerpt. To view the full review, go [url=https://arcadetheory.net/arcanum-of-steamworks-and-magick-obscura-review/]here on our website.[/url]
Visit our Steam curator page [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ArcadeTheory]here. [/url][/code]

[h1] Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura Review | Arcade Theory [/h1]

The title‚Äôs quite a mouthful, isn‚Äôt it? Let‚Äôs just call it Arcanum from now on. This is an old game for sure. So old, in fact, that on a modern setup, it won‚Äôt work straight out of the box. Be sure to install this patch to ensure your game doesn‚Äôt crash and burn on launch. Yet the fact that people even bother to go through such hoops to run this game is an indication of how good this game is. Indeed, Troika Games may be defunct now, but there is but one game the studio will forever be known for: Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Bloodlines.

The setting that the game takes place in is unique not because of the overall worldbuilding but because of the industrial revolution the land of Arcanum is experiencing. Magick has always been the predominant force in the land‚Äôs history, the elves being the most magically-attuned race, churning out generations of the greatest mages. Technology has also existed in some form or another, with the dwarves being expert technologists, but has never been as powerful or as venerated as magick.

In comes a man called Gilbert Bates (a completely fictional character, I assure you), who kicks off the industrial age with the introduction of the steam engine to the human world. Unfortunately, magick and technology are not compatible with each other, as technology follows the rules of natural law while magick is a supernatural force with no constraints from the natural order. When the two forces meet, instability results.

This brings us to the issue of coexistence between magicians and technologists. Since the invention of the steam engine, many cities in the kingdoms around Arcanum have become industrialized and thus utilize technology to its fullest extent. Spellcasters will find themselves unable to make use of their repertoire while within the cities (lore-wise, at least). In fact, should they get too close to a piece of machinery, they risk causing it to malfunction due to the abnormal nature of magick. It is less of an issue with weak magicians, but nevertheless, they must choose to either segregate themselves within the cities (e.g. ride the back of the train, avoiding the engine room) or distance themselves from cities altogether. Such is the course the elven races chose for themselves, living in their forested communities away from humanity.

Translated into game mechanics, the antagonistic duality of magick and technology is clear. Your affinity toward either magick or technology depends on your aptitude, a score based on how many points you put either to magical spells or technological disciplines. If your technical aptitude is high, you gain bonuses toward using technology but will find the use of magic to be less potent or even nullified. Similar effects occur the other way around, with extremely high aptitudes having effects on the game world itself (you simply cannot ride a train if your magical aptitude is too high). This means you have to choose between one or the other. No gunslinging wizards.

Should you choose technology, you get access to guns. What else could you really want in a fantasy world? Here, you have access to eight different technological disciplines:

    [*]Chemistry
    [*]Electric
    [*]Explosives
    [*]Gun Smithy
   [*] Herbology
    [*]Mechanical
    [*]Smithy
    [*]Therapeutics

Each time you spend a point on a discipline, you increase your level of understanding known as your expertise. Higher expertise lets you utilize more complex schematics for that discipline. Schematics are like blueprints. Get the crafting materials you need, be it batteries or a tonic, and you can craft items from grenades to poisons to robotic spiders. It‚Äôs a lot more work than magick, but magick doesn‚Äôt let you blast someone in half with an elephant gun.

Then you have magick, with 16 spell colleges and five spells each, for a whopping total of 60 spells total. High willpower is required to learn more spells within a single college. Here is a list of the spell colleges available:

    [*]Conveyance
   [*] Divination
   [*] Air
   [*] Earth
   [*] Fire
   [*] Water
    [*]Force
   [*] Mental
    [*]Meta
    [*]Morph
    [*]Natural
    [*]Black Necromantic
   [*] White Necromantic
    [*]Phantasm

There‚Äôs plenty of spells to learn. Resurrection lets you fully revive any fallen comrade, teleportation lets you fast travel to any location you‚Äôve visited, and polymorph lets you turn anyone you want into a harmless animal like a bunny or a sheep. Once you learn a spell, you have no limit on how many times you can cast it, save for fatigue. Hopefully you‚Äôve been increasing your fatigue points if you‚Äôre a mage because once it goes below 0, your character passes out on the ground and won‚Äôt wake up until it is back in the positives. So, if a spell costs 60 fatigue points and you only have 1 fatigue point on hand, you‚Äôll be doing a lot of waiting.

When we begin the game, we are greeted by a lovely cutscene of a zeppelin in flight, moments before it is shot down by a pair of half-ogres in fighter planes. Turns out, you were on that flight. You miraculously survive as the sole survivor, but not without being greeted by the best character in the game: Virgil.

Virgil is a member of the Panarii religion, based on the teachings of Nasrudin, who you are supposedly a reincarnation of. ‚ÄúAnd the spirit of Nasrudin shall be reborn on wings of fire in hills shrouded in fog, and fight the last battle with the evil one,‚Äù so sayeth the Panarii altar near the crash site. Seeing that you did just crawl out of a burning wreckage and that the nearest town over is named Shrouded Hills, you don‚Äôt really have cause to doubt the prophecy. So, you set out with Virgil (unless you killed him) on a quest to discover the owner of an engraved ring which you took from a dying gnome from the crash site.

The story takes you places all over Arcanum, meeting important individuals that are essential to the plot. So essential, in fact, that you can straight up murder them. You have plenty of choices you can make in this game, both in dialogue and in quest progression. This applies to the main story as well. To prevent players from softlocking themselves for being a murderous psychopath, there will always be a method to continue the story despite an essential NPC being dead, such as a journal or note that happened to be on their corpse. Anyone can be killed off, even Virgil, although you should spare him. His alignment is dependent on your own actions. If you are a good character, he too shall become a good character. If you choose to be a heartless scoundrel, he shall follow in your footsteps.

There are many other companions you can recruit‚Äîsome of them having a great deal of dialogue and significance to the story‚Äîbut none of them had the same impact as Virgil. Without spoilers, his subplot and related character development will make you glad you didn‚Äôt cut him loose at the start. [...]

This is clearly a good game, especially for anyone who enjoyed playing the original fallout series. A lot of die hard fans are saying 'download this patch' and 'follow these instructions to reduce lag' etc. I spent several hours trying to figure this out, and nothing worked. The game just doesn't run very well on my computer. And I don't think it's just me. Imagine having to wait 4+ minutes to watch your avatar run out of the city so that you can fast travel. Pros:
[list]
[*]Story is great. One of my favourites over the last ~25 years of playing RPGs. Also the writers were not afraid to cover some darker subject matter
[*]Fate point system is pretty cool. You can at rare times force a success on some things using saved up points
[*]Character stat differences lead to meaningful impact in how you play the game or navigate the storyline, for example: all your dialogue lines change if you have low intelligence
[*]Interesting setting. Magic and technology used together
[*]Crafting is useful
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Graphics a little dated now, and by default the game only runs in 800x600 resolution.
You can get some sort of patch to increase that, but it doesn't seem to work for 4k resolutions (the mouse is not interacting with the UI)
[*]No glorious 2020 remaster with endless replayability of the game out there :'(
[/list]

This game has many, many facets. It's huge, open-ended, lots of options and gameplay styles, but it does not hold your hand. No tutorial or anything.

Make in 2001, it has that 1990s cRPG (computer RolePlaying Game) feel to it, and I love that kind of thing.

I haven't played it much yet, but I can tell I'll need to do a lot of research and maybe download some patches before I can really get into it. That said, I'm glad I bought it, nevertheless.

Arcanum is one of my favourite games, it has a vast world with about 70 side quest scattered throughout the world.
The game features a large amount of recruitable party members which you can find in towns and dungeons, all brimming with personality. 

Arcanum excels at is expanding your vocabulary, it's filled with English commonly used throughout the industrial revolution period in England and mixing it with vocabulary you would find in fantasy type games. Arcanum allows you to solve various problems your way using upgrade skills, items or abusing the way the combat system works to it's fullest, speaking of which, it's not very balanced; you can change between real time and turn based combat based on which is more favourable to you. 

The plot is grand, it's interesting to follow but it isn't any LISA game, but the lore is pretty damn big and also enjoyable, for this alone I recommend that you read the manual but I also recommend it because it's necessary if you don't want to spend hours trying to figure out how everything works, also it has a banana bread recipe at the end, unfortunately I do not like bananas but maybe you do.

The graphics aren't all that impressive, however they feel nostalgic since I've had this game since my 12th birthday, but the soundtrack is pretty good 

Unfortunately time passes and as a result this game is old, you're going to need to install the unofficial patch for this game to fix the slowdown issue among several others. Also the game doesn't have support for online multiplayer, you can only really do that through LAN or some alternative method of fixing multiplayer (if you really want to jump through hoops).

It isn't too difficult however progression somewhat relies on utilizing the many quests available to level up as a preferable alternative to grinding, it encourages exploration but you don't have to 100% the game.

10/10
Wish it got remade with bug fixes and server support.
