Old-school charm and an intriguing premise ultimately don't save the pervasive issues of this competent, but mismanaged, CRPG classic. From obscure interactions and obtuse mechanics to terrible real-time combat, 'enjoying not having your hand held' is more 'being dumped on Everest and told to find civilisation equipped only with a spoon and a xanex prescription'.

Companion and NPC dialogue is limited. For the most part, you cannot advance your relationship with your followers at all except for story-related events. Conversations rely on basic dialogue trees and boil down to 'I'll help you' and "i'll kill you'. Towns have obnoxious layouts that discourage backtracking and exploration. Dungeons and world map areas have wildly varying difficulties that make save-scumming a necessity just to survive.

!!BEFORE YOU START THE GAME:
1. To play on windows 10 without issues install this mod: https://terra-arcanum.com/drog/uap.html. It fixes the bugs, enhances gameplay including high resolution. 
2. DISABLE G-sync and steam overlay. Delete your old save files. 
3. Read the patch's readme PLEASE. It explains everything. 

This is how I got the game to work flawlessy through steam on windows 10 ver.1909.

Otherwise HILARIOUS game, I love how absurd it is, it's a true rpg by essence. If you're ugly, all the NPCs notice and some refuse to talk to you, if you're stupid all the NPCs react to that. If you got some fugly zombie summons behind you, NPCs get scared and refuse to talk to you. Your choices do matter, your good/evil alignment matters. If you love technology or magic that MEGA matters. 

One huge gripe I have about this game though is the maps in the main city hubs don't mark what the buildings are and I find myself running around the darn map looking for the same NPCs over and over. (and 1 main city is HUGE).

*WARNING*: If you're looking for a FULL STORY playthrough DO NOT make an EVIL alignment character. There is a COMPANION called MAGNUS that is CRUCIAL to the story and he won't join your party IF YOU ARE EVIL ALIGNMENT! (I made a dark elf character that has a permanent evil alignment, mistakes were made :/ )

This game is definitely old. But if you're an RPG player, you'll likely appreciate the sound, the cutscenes and the atmosphere as you jump into the world. 

Character creation is interesting and somewhat flexible. The writing is fantastic and the concepts are admirable for an RPG. Race relations, Steampunk elements, all play a role in the game world. You can read newspapers, and when you walk around a city you actually get that industrialized feeling thanks to the excellent background art. 

Of course, the character interactions are fantastic as well. I won't give any examples to refrain from spoilers, but this is definitely a game that requires you to THINK and TAKE NOTES. It's one of the grand-daddies of modern RPGs.
This is an old-school game that doesn't coddle.  I thank the creators of this game just because not everyone needs a participation award.

Fallout is an absolute masterpiece, but if I have to point a flaw I'll say it's a bit too short. I always finish it wanting more, but Fallout 2, while good, is a bit bloated and unfocused. Of course, there's an alternative. Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura could actually be considered the true successor to Fallout, as its developers left in the middle of Fallout 2's development to make this game.

There's something that immediately engages you in Arcanum's character creation. I think it's the portraits: selecting fantasy races while seeing the portraits change between half-orcs in a gentleman's attire to elven women in makeup, it tells you right away that this is a far cry from your average fantasy RPG. Of course, if you didn't know, Arcanum is set in a fantasy world that's undergoing an industrial revolution. The worldbuilding is great, as you see orcs being treated as slave labour in factories and elves slowly losing their forests as machines cut them down. We are often too short-lived to see the consequences of our actions, and this is shown in a more interesting light when there are long-lived fantasy races to berate our hastiness. Luddite kingdoms become shadows of their former selves, and mages slowly lose the power that separated them from the common man, while vehemently keeping to their belief that technology is merely a fad and will go away "soon". 

You see, magick and technology cannot coexist: the manual explains this with detailed in-universe experiments, but the gist of it is that technology relies on the laws of nature while magick distorts them. This conflict is reflected in your character. You can learn spells and technological schematics, and as you do so you'll gain more magickal or technological affinity. Become too attuned to magick and you'll be barred from first class trains in fear that you'll make the engine malfunction; become too attuned to technology and both harmful and healing spells will fizzle out on you. This isn't all the ways people will react to you: playing as a dwarf, most people just told me to go away and that they didn't want anything to do with me, making me have to convince them to talk. The way people will react and respond to you differs heavily on race, affinity and reputation, and Arcanum is easily a high-water mark for reactivity in RPGs.

There's an insane amount of variety in what your character can do. Focusing on magick lets you learn dozens of spells, from basic damage to speaking with the dead to teleporting around instead of taking the train. Focusing on technology lets you craft all manner of things, from steampunk firearms to flame swords to mechanized spiders that will follow you around and fight with you, and much, much more. That's not all: much like in Fallout, you can invest in other skills and focus on gambling, melee, firing bows or persuading people. These skills are improved by putting points into them as usual for RPGs, but you can also gain special bonuses in them from talking to people and requesting training. For each skill, there's even a special quest that enables you to become a Master of it. While in my several playthroughs of Fallout I've often relied on Speech and Guns (barring a hilarious foray into a low Intelligence character), Arcanum lets you make much more varied characters.

Most of the game will be spent exploring towns and doing quests. These offer a large variety of ways to solve them as well: You can often kill quest characters to find some way to advance the quest in their bodies, you can use magick to talk to them after they're dead, pick the lock on their chests while they sleep (or just break it with your rifle because they're very heavy sleepers), just talk them into saying the right things, and I'm probably missing some things here. The towns are a bit too large sometimes (I've often set waypoints to walk to the town's exit, as you cannot open the world map and travel somewhere else unless you're outside of town, and just went to do something else while my characters walk), and the visuals are a bit bland, but the music makes up for it. These moody and melancholic strings are just beautiful, and they have stayed in my head for the past few days when I'm doing something else. Special mention goes to the opening cutscene music: it's really great seeing this aerial battle scored to just a string quartet. Sadly, I think the overworld feels a bit empty: like Fallout, overland travel is done through a map, but it takes way too long. I've spent five in-game years travelling back and forth, which makes the world feel way too empty, with towns months away from each other, which is not that realistic. The map would be better if it was a smaller and more condensed space.

Extremely intricate reactivity, quests with countless ways to solve them and endless build variety, a great setting... what makes Arcanum not stand with Fallout as an all-time RPG classic in the eyes of everyone? Well, sadly Arcanum isn't a very... finished game. The combat can be real-time or turn-based depending on your preference, and neither is fun. When the game wants you to fight something, it's going to be a dungeon that takes forever to go through, often with enemies that will break your armor and weapons, leading to fun tactical questions such as: "why is my entire party naked and unarmed?" Some of these dungeons can be skipped with certain skills (persuasion or invisibility, for example), but not all of them. 

In Fallout, the only "dungeon" I can think of that forces you into combat (and I suppose Fallout's combat isn't exactly great, but it's very elevated by great animations and enjoyable feedback text... and no armor breaking), and that's Vault 15, which is technically optional. The game feels very unbalanced: I usually play real-time to get the bad combat over with, but I will always switch to turn-based when the enemy's an archer, as they might as well be carrying an Uzi with their insane firing rate. One first-level spell will also turn the combat into a clicker minigame, as you are only limited by how fast you can click on something when you cast magic in real-time. Apart from the combat, the game feels very unfinished at points. While I may sometimes wish that Fallout would be longer, Arcanum is an example of "be careful what you wish for", as its latter half piles on bland dungeons and endless trash fights. And good luck if you haven't saved in a while and accidentally press quicksave (F7) instead of quickload (F8) because a companion died, since the game doesn't care and will save in the middle of combat.

Arcanum is a prototype for the greatest RPG of all time. The game itself is quite good, but the sheer potential that it still has can make you sad thinking of what could have been. Nevertheless, it's very much worth playing: stomach the bad combat and rushed areas, and you'll be able to experience something that often comes close to being the pinnacle of role-playing games. Do install the Unofficial Patch and High-Res mod.
Arcanum is really a very good game. In an age of modern games I still think this one trumps them all on the sheer amount of storylining options and quality.

I have learned the hard way recently that all of these old, classic games being offered on Steam will not play on today's computer systems.  Like me, you will bang your head against the wall trying to figure out how Compatibility Mode might be able to save your potentially non-refundable purchase.  You will search for hours online trying to learn all the stupid ways that people have tried using so that they can play these old games.

After your great investment of time, you will then discover like I did that there is no resolution - you wasted your money.  So far, there have been a few games where I was trying to get them to work, which included loading the games.  This puts them on the Steam timer.  Did you know that you only have 2 hours before you can request a refund?  What if your refund date has passed?  Did you know that you have about 2 weeks to request the refund?

Don't put yourself through this experience.  I understand the nostalgia - that's why I spent the $3.24 or the $4.99 in the first place.  But do yourself a favor, instead.  Go to your wallet and pull out a $5 bill.  Next, take a lighter and burn that $5 bill into a crisp.  (Be safe with this - don't burn anything else.)  After you finish this exercise, you will have realized that you just did the equivalent of buying Arcanum, a classic PC game, on Steam.  And if you ever want to buy any other old games on Steam, then get out your wallet and repeat.  Eventually, you will stop wanting old nostalgic games because THEY DO NOT WORK ON TODAY'S SYSTEMS and you sure as heck aren't going to want to bang your head against a wall trying to make them work and potentially losing out on your refund opportunity.

I'd never played a serious RPG game before Arcanum and now, after looking into others, it might not have been the best to start the journey with as there's no in-game prompts to learn. However I still really enjoyed it from the very beginning - it reminded me of growing up playing Dungeons & Dragons with how engrossed I became!

There are a number of choices for characters and I wasn't aware how significant these choices would be on the game as it progressed. You can reach your maximum level (50) quite quickly and can then become a bit stuck if you've kept your skills too general (ie without enough specialisation). I also didn't realise how crucial a team was to the success of this game and so my character became very strong but had not picked up enough team mates early which became problematic later in the game. So it's probably worth doing a bit of research before you start instead of diving straight in like I did!

I did have a lot of trouble playing this game on Windows 10, and so I learnt to save very regularly! I tried the unofficial patch which seems to help a lot of people (as well as resolving the level 50 cap) but it never worked for me. The main issue was extreme lagging when any sort of 3D graphic was introduced, this got to the point where the game was almost unplayable. Once I worked out what was causing it, I tended to save the game just prior to the 3D part, slog through the section with it and save, then restart the game which would get rid of the lag. Not an ideal experience but I was committed at that point! 

I will always remember this game as the one that kick-started my RPG gaming experience, and from that side of things, I think it set the bar high!

Used to play this 10 years ago on a shitty laptop, and back then I was amazed at the amount of freedom to do whatever you want in this rpg. 
Many rpgs have stats like Charisma but they never really do much with that, but in Arcanum all your stats actually matters and change your playthrough. It`s the only game ever to really show the difference between science and magic. Your character`s race matters, their Intelligence, their Strenght, if he is able to use magic at all, how knowledgeable he is with technology, how ugly or beautiful he is, etc...
The developers are probably not together anymore, but man if Arcanum ever got a remake...it could be a masterpiece.

[h1]Magie und Technik[/h1]
Arcanum war in den fr√ºhen 2000er ein einzigartiges Spiel, das dem Spieler viele Entscheidungen selbst √ºberlassen hat, z.B. welchen Weg er einschl√§gt, wenn es um die Frage nach Technik oder Magie geht. Ich habe damals unz√§hlige Stunden in dem Rollenspiel verbracht; das Spiel ist extrem textlastig. Ich habe sicher alle M√∂glichkeiten ausprobiert, gut und b√∂se, Elf oder Mensch; egal was. Jeder Spieldurchgang hatte ein anderes Spielerlebnis. Der Soundtrack ist heute aber kaum noch zu ertragen, es ist ein f√ºrchterliches Geigengefidele. 

[h1]Arcanum als Steamumsetzung[/h1]
Zun√§chst einmal muss man festhalten, dass es sich hierbei nicht um ein HD Remake oder so handelt. Es ist das ganz normale alte Spiel. Allerdings mit ein paar Problemchen. Das Spiel ist nur auf englisch verf√ºgbar. Zum Gl√ºck gibt es einen deutsch Patch. 

Nat√ºrlich empfehle ich Arcanum. Ich finde, man muss es zumindest einmal gespielt haben. Leider konnte ich nicht die Mu√üe und Zeit finden, es als Steamumsetzung nochmal zu spielen.

This is a great game, and despite the rather primitive mechanics, the story and characters prove just as lively as they ever have. My big complaint, and perhaps my only major one, is that this is not optimized for modern machines. Even having downloaded the Unofficial Patch (which is why my play hours are so low, since it doesn't allow Steam to log in-game time), it was still rife with bugs, predominantly graphical ones, which made having to traverse large areas a total lag-fest. That aside, this game belongs to the same category as the classic D&D games of the era and the first two Fallouts, and since we have all this free time now, it wouldn't hurt to crack it open and immerse yourself in one of the better video game universes.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#450 out of 612)... it's time for Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magicka Obscura.

Arcanum is one of the finest CRPGs ever made, and arguably the most impressive product legendary (if somewhat infamous) developer Troika Games ever built. It's a massive,, brilliantly open game in the vein of Fallout that offers players an unprecedented degree of freeom with regard to how they build their characters, how they play the game, and how they progress through the world. It's difficult to overstate just how deeply engaging Arcanum can be‚Äîthis one is a classic roleplaying game for very good reason.

Part of what makes Arcanum so incredibly engaging is the setting: the world of Arcanum is that of a high fantasy setting experiencing an industrial revolution. A chaotic world plagued by all manner of social, political and economic problems that feels much like our own: ready to come apart by the seams at any moment but, somehow, impossibly, it keeps puttering on. An especially interesting idea is the interplay between magic and technology, which defines both the lore and mechanics of the game. In brief, proximity to technology wreaks havoc on magic, resulting in a clear delineation between the "old world" and "new world" ‚Äì tradition and revolution. The often-dangerous, sometimes-catastrophic interplay between these two totally antithetical mechanisms also affects gameplay: technological weaponry may be incredibly effective, but it does not play well with the more conventional boons granted by magic‚Äîand NPCs will react to the player based on which end of the spectrum they embrace.

Which brings us to reactivity. And, good lord, is Arcanum a reactive game. Nearly every choice you make has a consequence as, like in the classic Fallout games, you make your way through the (fairly open-ended) main quest while balancing various relationships with the powerful factions that rule the land. Arcanum's is a complicated world that will constantly test you‚Äîphysically, mentally and emotionally. As fantastical as the steampunk fantasy aesthetic is, the world itself feels very familiar: it's hard, impossible even, to ever know if you're making the right choice. Deciding who to trust and when is, therefore, as much a part of Arcanum as reality.

Granted, Arcanum has its share of flaws. Especially so at the time of release, when developer Troika games was forced to push the game out the door far before it was ready. Thankfully multiple patches, official and fan-made, have more or less solidified Arcanum into a coherent and stable experience. That said, many of the fundamental mechanics remain spotty. The world of Arcanum is large, and the maps you have access to can be a bit confusing at times, making navigation difficult. Many quests also suffer from unclear language, making it sometimes very difficult to discern where you're meant to go next to progress. This can be a double-edged sword as it encourages simply wandering about, and there's a great deal of interesting and compelling content to discover out in the wilds, but it can also feel frustrating and aimless. Perhaps most notably, Arcanum's combat system feels a little half-baked. Its is certainly one of the more ambitious combat systems compared to other CRPGs of the time, trying to offer both a turn-based mode in the style of Fallout as well as a real-time-with-pause mode in the style of Baldur's Gate, but the end result is that neither mode feels sufficiently engaging in its own right.

But even despite these issues, Arcanum shines brilliantly. The holy canon of classic CRPGs does not list many titles, and there's good reason Arcanum often stands near the top.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

In short, Arcanum has writing in the style of Baldur's Gate 1 (but better-executed) and overall feel in the style of Fallout 2. 

I really enjoyed the plot, although it takes 3/4 of the game before it really gets rolling. The interface is rough around the edges, but that was par for the course at the time of its creation. The world is huge but largely empty, and the characters are mostly empty shells. The game desperately needed more music. The mechanics allowed a wide variety of character builds and allowed a few ways of completing many quests. Combat starts challenging, but becomes too easy by mid-game and never poses a serious challenge again. Unfortunately, the dungeons compensate by being much too long, often requiring an hour or more of boring slog.

For all that, I enjoyed Arcanum. It has a novel system and a fun mystery for you to uncover. During the last quarter of the game, I was constantly excited to see what was coming next. If you're wondering whether to play this or Baldur's Gate, go with BG every time. But there's no rule that says you can't try both, so Arcanum is worth a shot too.

While I have owned this game as a hard copy for many years before purchasing it on steam, I will try to keep out my bias towards the game.

The game universe is exceedingly well fleshed out for an RPG of this type, and lends itself to world building quite well, Its character creation is fleshed out just enough to let you run any type of character you could possibly imagine, and then some (viability of such builds not withstanding) The voice acting is brilliantly done and gives you a feel for each unique character to be themselves, not cardboard cut outs of your generic bad guy or good guy.

Though thats not to say the game is perfect, because using Guns in this game is a tedious and almost pointless process, thanks to being out scaled by STR/DEX melee builds (You can run around as a human that can kick wolfs heads off by level 15ish) or Dark necromancy Harm mage builds that you run in real time combat mode and just delete anything that looks at you funny by spam clicking with the spell until your foe crumples, As well as the fact that on windows 10, you have to download a couple of Dlls to get the game to actually run at a stable framerate, as well as get a couple of patches to bring the game closer to a modern era.

You can be a smooth, suave halfling that gets absolutely hammered before you fuck a sheep in a brothel while saving the world, Or you can be a bitter and cold half orc warrior that opts to end the world due to the racism you suffer through out your experience. The limit to what you can do comes down to your skill as a player and the grit you have to suffer through grinding out the low levels before your build becomes anywhere near viable.

All in all, Not a bad game, Definitely worth a buy, Just remember though, Troika isnt making any money off this, only steam. Yarhar.

Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura... oh, this game...

In spite of my low ownership, I am more than familiar with this bizarre, wonderful masterpiece, a game I sometimes thought was a complete fever dream from the depths of my imagination, among a strange number of other games including an action game involving Skittles and a dark knight. I'm still not sure that one still exists, though.

Arcanum is NOT a fever dream, however, and does in fact exist and is a masterpiece of a forgotten era where computers had the ability to deal with the unique and antiquated graphical features on their own. Because Microsoft doesn't know how to keep good features from previous operating systems, it is imperative that you look up a tutorial on how to play this game, and while on your way, pick up an unofficial patch and maybe a few mods; one of which being Virgil's Debug Menu. You won't regret it.

Arcanum is a very unique CRPG, created on the same engine as Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planetscape: Torment and Fallout: the Infinity Engine, but shares very little else with those other four games. Its mechanics are unique, relying less on the classic alignments and statlines in favor for showcasing its unique flavor. Your stats are Strength (obvious), Constitution (which, while it helps HP, it is more focused on improving your resistances), Dexterity (your most important physical stat), Perception (your most important mental stat), Willpower (where you get more HP and Fatigue), Intelligence (your other most important mental stat), Beauty (which affects how people like you) and Charisma (which allows you to bring more followers). There are no classes, everything is based on proficiency which takes up the same skill points as your Stats, making each level up a vital decision on how you improve your character. Give up hope on creating an ultimate, unstoppable character with 20 in all stats and fully maximized skills unless you desire abusing Virgil's Debug Menu. The races are your usual fare of Humans, Elves, Half-Elves, Gnomes, Half-Ogres, Dwarves, Halflings, and Half-Orcs, familiar to anyone who's ever seen a Fantasy game before, but their portraits are lovingly crafted to resemble those of Victorian photographs.

However, the main star of the show is the dichotomy between the eponymous technology and magic, as the game is highly affected by how you use both of these aspects of the world. You see, this world is undergoing a Victorian Era-esque industrial revolution, and technology is changing the world for the better and the worst. To represent these changes, the balance between magic and artificial technology is shifted, and how your character deals with this balance depends on your build. You can create a hybrid that doesn't mind either casting or creating gadgets, but by specializing in one or the other, you lock yourself from certain allies and make magic either less effective against yourself, or make science-y solutions less effective. Classism exists between those of magic and those of technological bent, as you'll be put on the back of the train if you are a dirty mage, or be seen as a spooky not-magical witch to the more superstitious. You can't win with people.

Your skills are also incredibly vital, and Troika, whose pedigree with Fallout can be clearly seen with a nifty little nod and the careful crafting of this world and its mechanics, has made every stat matter, with the way your character is built affecting nearly everything about this game. You can insert yourself the way you think you are, play as a mentally deficient man/womanchild with special needs and discover that everything changes based on your inability to learn names or concepts properly, and even whether or not you play as a Good or Evil character.

It is, however, a hard game. Most classic CRPGs are, but Arcanum can bring things to a different level. Early on in the game, you will be forced to brave a dungeon with monsters 10-15 levels stronger than your character, and can shatter your weapons. Of course, there are ways around this that don't involve cheating or massive amounts of grinding, but I prefer not knowing of such heresies. Don't fret, however, because whether you are good or evil, a master orator, a special needs Half-Ogre created by decades of selective eugenics and inbreeding [spoiler]and I wish I was not kidding about that part[/spoiler], a gunslinger that makes Roland Deschain look like a pansy, or a wizard that can put Elminster to shame, the game is worth it all the way to its climactic finale.

Now, if you excuse me, I have to find out if that Skittles game exists.

Good game, I like the freedom, the rpg elements, and exploration aspect to everything, but I can't recommend it with the level of bugs in the game. I know the game is old and not meant for Windows 10 - I don't hold it to the original developers, but if steam is going to offer it for modern machines then it should be somewhat stable (to get my recommendation at least). Even with the patch, I am forced to quick save constantly as it crashes quite often. The main crash is if I scroll too much in the local map. Another whenever I have to attack inanimate objects (this crashes it every time, but sometimes I can tab out to another program in the background, that I can't see because the game doesn't hide when not active, and then tab back to restore). 

Other times it locks up because of other events on my computer (I left my email open in the background and got a IM request which completely locked up the game - the game visuals stayed on the screen and the Windows 10 task manager showed behind it so it was a b--- to close). I also have to unplug my second monitor for the game to work. If I just turn it off sometimes window 10 will still detect it and mess with display settings which, you guessed it, hard freezes the game. 

Combat has also locked the game up. If my allies are on the other side of a closed door (just by chance the door was closed I'm not sure why) they weren't able to calculate how to path to the enemy. Sometimes that just makes them sit there and do nothing like idiots (that ally AI is really bad, one of the few things in the game I think the original developers could have done better), but on 2 or 3 occasions it just sat in a loop that wouldn't end (again a b---- to close in windows 10).

One of the best games ive ever played despite how old this is, make sure you get the un-offical patch.

I can definitely recommend this game. It has a learning curve, but you will figure it out looking around online. There is a good bit of player autonomy. And yes, it is really about roleplaying. The Victorian era theme is not cheesy, it is actually very neat. The 2D look is moody and calming in some ways. 
Like other games from that time, there is not a lot of visual control of your character. Doesn't matter, half the game is in your head. You are visualizing in your mind these conversations half the time. It is very much an RPG, like I said. 
You can go to options and switch between real-time combat and turn-based. Each have varying results depending on who you fight. You can be overwhelmed easily in this game, but eventually you start rounding out skills and are able to hold out. Enemies are not scaled to you, so be weary of places you go and whether the story has brought you there or if you are just there randomly. No autosave also, so yeah, save often, and never in combat or when you wasted a dialogue option you need. There are punishing mechanics in combat, and dialogue, so be mindful, and stay in character.

you'll encounter a lot of problems running this game today. I recommend Multiverse edition fan patch. But I still got some crashes running it through Steam. So I mostly played without Steam.
Art is very dated, and interface, and AI of your followers. 
Battle mechanics is terrible. It feels like a chore. Enemies are dumb and boring
Some quests are cryptic as fuck and not well explained. Even parts of main quest.  

But everything looks nice from story standpoint. Troika created truly unique world where magic opposes technology. Lore, story, dialogues and voice acting are top notch.
So in overall game with good story and not so good other parts.
I shagged a sheep and two hours later managed to crack my own skull with a critical fail while fighting a gnome. Would do that again 10/10

2/10
Have fond memories of playing this years ago, though I don't think I ever beat it.  Seeing it on Steam, I had to give it another go in the hopes of actually making it to the end this time.  The concept is amazing: take some of the people who made Fallout and essentially do the same game except set in a steampunk fantasy world. There's exploring, custom characters, strange partners, and a number of quests that can be completed in different ways.

But as soon as the game came up I remembered what stopped me from ever getting too deep into it: this game is PAINFULLY slow. Even on a computer that is amazingly powerful compared to top of the line machines of its day, the game is constantly slowing down, locking up, loading, and generally being non-user-friendly.  I would think this would have been corrected at this point, but it took ages just to walk from one end of the first town to the other.  The game design certainly doesn't help either. There's no fast travel, you have to wait for the characters to catch up to the scrolling map, you have to move in segments from the map, and going from place to place on the world map requires you walk to the very edge of town before you can leave even if there are no enemies anywhere. Going between destinations on the world map is a drag, too, since you have to watch the dot that represents your party slowly move across the land in a days-long trek.  

I have only put about 5 hours into this at this point, but it feels like at least double that. Black Isle Games came out with Enhance Editions of their catalog (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Palnescape Torment), so why not this one, too?  There's a lot of cool ideas in here that I just wish I could get to a little faster.
One of the best games a played in my life but it's got some bugs.

Classic game that really shines from a story, world building, and exposition perspective. Really interesting crafting system and nice variety of character play styles and builds. Surprisingly the voice acting is also superb and really has its moments.

Now for the bad parts. It is extremely dated graphically. Poor combat with boring enemies and really dumb party AI. Lots of bugs. Not necessarily obvious where your character must go or how to solve certain quests. I think that you can use a reference or guide when you get lost in this game and not lose any enjoyment. I also recommend following a non-spoiler character guide like the one below. Believe me, the combat of this game is not the strong point and you really don't want to waste more time with it than you need to.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2S5RAzYY1rg

That being said, this is actually a very good game. The world that they have put together is very nice and enjoyable to experience. However, realize that the strong points of the game are the dialogues, small elements of role play, lore, etc. If those things appeal to you give it a try.

I would recommend getting this game on sale. There is always the chance that a bug (there are a lot of them) will ruin your playthrough, and you don't want to be spending too much just to run in to a game breaking bug.

Nostalgia for dayzzzzz.
I used to play this game all the time. In fact, I still have the CD version but I went ahead and bought the steam version too.
NOTE: Since this game is old, you will likely need to do a fix for windows 10 otherwise it'll be kinda laggy regardless of hardware. There's also some mods such as the High Res mod that I'd recommend... 

Even among all the modern day games, VERY few games immerse me into its world like this game does. Without giving away too many spoilers, this game really has an amazing variety of elements. You have a nation that believes in chivalry and the ways of knighthood, a nation that believes in industry and technology, elven cities, dwarf clans, magic, guns, and steampunk tech. This game is awesome for roleplaying. Whether you want to be a dwarf that recruits all the dwarf followers while in search of his own clan. Or you can be a powerful elf mage that attempts to recouncile and recruit from elf factions despite their differences. Options are limitless. Also, there's a ton of interesting things to find out and locations to explore in the world. 

I've played real-time combat mode ever since the game came out so I can't speak to turn-based. I like the fast paced combat more. Getting master in bow or gun and seeing the insane attack speed is awesome. Definitely recommend.

Its the game where you can play as a pistol wielding knight. Its by no means the best CRPG, and even contains quite a few bugs and flaws (as its studios shut prematurely, it lacks a great deal of polish) with the realtime combat system being one of the more standout flaws. But despite all the negative aspects to it, it still presents an amazing and surprisingly unique world, which originally pulled in my attention with its steampunk theme back in 2007. 

Arcanum provides a curious world that combines steam technology with high fantasy, where magick exists in a troubled state against the rising steam and electric machinery tech in 1885 that distort the nature of the world around it. Spellcasting elves and technological dwarves exist among humans and halflings in a decent sized, if somewhat empty map. Its not a bright land, its rather dreary, but its captivating, its a bit lonely, its wonderful, and its accompanied by woefully pleasant violin music. If that all sounds good to you, that's probably enough for you to enjoy this game.

Its esoteric, and you really need to know how the game works to enjoy it. Expect your first character to suck, and hard. Don't worry about playing on easy, as it makes the experience much nicer. Make sure to save often, because it is definitely buggy.

I could say many more positive and many, many more negative things, but all in all Arcanum is my favorite CRPG. I definitely recommend it for fans of the classic Fallout games and steampunk themes.

E‚Äô difficile per me parlare di Arcanum senza farmi prendere da una certa nostalgia. Il ricordo delle lunghe peregrinazioni pomeridiane (e notturne) nelle sconfinate terre di Arcanum rovistando trai rifiuti, nei negozi, nelle periferie delle citt√† in cerca di qualche rudere abbandonato che nascondesse al suo interno oggetti rari, qualche erba per preparare degli ungenti, o alla ricerca di qualche personaggio strampalato per completare una quest. 
In Arcanum √® facile imbattersi in una bottiglia di vetro in un cestino dei rifiuti e farne una molotov, o fare un fucile lancia-coltelli con delle parti di pistola, un tubo di ferro e dei coltelli, appunto.
Quasi tutto quello che si vede sul monitor, in Arcanum, si pu√≤ manipolare o ci si pu√≤ interagire. E tutte le quest, o comunque la stragrande maggioranza di esse, possono essere affrontate in modi diversi o addirittura opposti. E lo svolgimento della trama non √® per nulla lineare: si pu√≤ fare tutto ci√≤ che si vuole, quando si vuole e come lo si vuole.
Se queste possono sembrare piccole cose adesso, features presenti in quasi in tutti i GdR, o almeno quelli di un certo livello, bisogna considerare che Arcanum √® un gioco uscito nel 2001 all‚Äôombra di titoloni GdR ben pi√π noti come i due Baldur‚Äôs Gate, Torment e compagnia. 
Paragonato al miglior GdR attualmente disponibile sul mercato PC, Divinity Original Sin 2, tralasciando la componente tecnica (parliamo di 17 anni di differenza), Arcanum stravince sulla vastit√† e la diversit√† del mondo di gioco, sul crafting (in Arcanum molte armi si possono guadagnare solo creandole, e per creare un‚Äôarma bisogna sviluppare quel ramo specifico di specializzazione: esplosivi, armi da fuoco, spade, archi, eccetera). 
Non esiste un vero sistema di classi in Arcanum, c‚Äô√® piuttosto una tendenza che avr√† il nostro personaggio verso una o pi√π caratteristiche. I punti esperienza possono essere investiti in abilit√† (Armi da fuoco, Mischia, Mercanteggiare, Persuasione), punti caratteristiche del personaggio (Forza, Destrezza, Carisma) o nell‚Äôalbero delle tecnologie/magie. In questo modo si delineer√† la classe del nostro personaggio, che potr√† essere un Mago evocatore abile nel mercanteggiare o un Guerriero abile con la spada e con l‚Äôarco che all‚Äôoccorrenza pu√≤ usare anche armi da fuoco (archi e pistole, e tutte le armi a distanza in generale, diventano pi√π efficaci aumentando lo stesso parametro, la percezione). Ed √® su questa vastit√† e diversit√† che in Arcanum si ha completa libert√† di approccio.  
Anche l‚Äôallineamento non viene definito a monte ma si modifica in base alle nostre azioni, al modo in cui concluderemo le quest e alla facilit√† con cui ricorreremo alla violenza. E non √® raro che durante una singola partita si passi da un atteggiamento pacifico a uno pi√π belligerante e malvagio o viceversa.
L‚Äôambientazione ha poi un ruolo fondamentale. Il mondo steampunk di Arcanum √® vivo, se ne palpano le contraddizioni, le meraviglie di Tarant e la decadenza delle altre citt√† che non hanno voluto piegarsi all‚Äôincedere della tecnologia: il contrasto tra magia e tecnologia si sente tutto. 
Arcanum √® a mio parere un gioiello dal gameplay unico, corredato da musiche che sono a mio parere tra le pi√π belle mai realizzate per un videogame, e da una parte narrativa ottima.

3/10

I remember seeing Arcanum: Of Steamworks & Magic Obscura on the shelves at stores when I was a teenager playing D2, SC:BW, and M & M, and always wanted to pick it up but never did.  I saw it on sale on Steam one time for cheap, and decided to finally check it out.  The game has some merits - the tech vs magick system is an interesting take on character building, the world is large enough and fairly immersive, there are some really interesting and compelling stories within the world (the half-ogre project, the treatment of orcs in society, etc.), and there is plenty of world to explore.  The biggest thing in Arcanum's favor is the sheer variety of ways you can play the game - play it evil or good, play it as an ugly brute or a beautiful diplomat, play it as a mage or a fighter.  Even the game itself works fine - the only bug that I encountered is that my Steam would occasionally determine that the game was running on its own, which put a few hundred hours into my time played on Steam and required me to restart my PC in order to successfully start the game for reals.  That said, I did play the game with a variety of improvements - the high-def packs, the unofficial patch, follower mod, ArcanumEdit, etc.  

However, I was overall unimpressed with a number of systems and elements within the game to such a degree that I can't recommend the game overall.  Inventory is cumbersome and finicky, travel is unintuitive in several regards, combat feels often very binary (you wreck the opponent or the opponent wrecks you, no in between), the tech/crafting piece of the game is utterly unclear and unapproachable without reading extensively outside of the game on how it actually works, and there are dozens of minor mechanics and conventions within the game that are never made clear in any sort of effective manner.  I tried playing the game legit for a length of time but finally gave up because of a number of the minor nuisances that were killing any enjoyment I got out of the game and ended up just following a walkthrough and some playing with ArcanumEdit to speed through the remainder of the game.  

Here's some spoiler-free nuisances that really detracted from the quality of the game overall.
- In combat, until your characters are melee masters, they frequently get disarmed.  This means that as you're bouncing around through a variety of combat encounters, your characters drop their weapons on the ground, and your other followers may pick them up.  You then have to go sorting through everyone's inventory to go get your weapon back, re-equip the correct weapons, etc.
- Also in combat, there are a variety of enemies who do significant damage to your weapon or armor, usually encountered in clusters within dungeons.  These guys chew through your equipment in an unreal fashion, destroying your good equipment (unless you finagle with inventory even more than necessary already to keep some backup gear for fighting such monsters...  which requires you to be using walkthroughs to know when these guys are coming).  By the way, repairing equipment (unless you yourself are a master repairman) quickly and significantly damages the maximum durability of items too.
- The journal in game that tracks quests is very unclear about who wants what and where they are.  You really need to take notes.  Why have a journal if it's going to be missing these things?  Even the later Might & Magic games that preceded Arcanum had good worthwhile auto-journaling.  
- Followers gain a level when you do, rather than having their own experience.  As a result, they will never catch up to you in levels, if they are recruited below your own level.  You're level 15 and just went and found that guy who is level 5?  Sorry, he'll be 10 levels behind you forever.  This was something I fixed with ArcanumEdit, once I got my party set up and realized that they were never getting any closer to my level, I just used that to edit my followers and raise their levels accordingly.
- Speaking of followers, you don't get to control how they apply their character points as they level up.  They follow their own auto-levelling scheme, even if it's not actually what you want or how you want them to be.  Want that guy to use a gun so that he's not getting his face stabbed all the time in melee?  Too bad, unless you go and edit the follower in ArcanumEdit or you recruit him early and then use the FollowerEditor program to deactivate (or re-assign) the autolevelling scheme so you can choose whether those character points are spent on a spell or a tech or a skill.  

Overall, I cannot recommend Arcanum in the year 2019.  I know I would've been happier with this game in some ways 20 years ago when I was in my early teens and looking at it on a store shelf, but I still would've found it lacking and in many ways frustrating compared to some of the high-end PC games that were out at the time.  That comparison has only grown worse in the 20 years that have passed since, such that I don't think I could've strongly recommended it in 1999 either.  I kind of don't like saying that, because there was definitely some worthwhile ideas and elements here, but especially at this point in time, whatever time this game might've had has definitely and irrevocably passed.  Unless you're really a junkie for old-school 90's RPGs, skip it and go elsewhere.

Ahhh Arcanum... my old friend. If I was willing to fight through bugs, glitches, and lag to experience the wonderful setting and story 20 years ago I was certainly willing to through five dollars at Steam to see if they managed to streamline things. 

I was not disappointed. 

The magic and mystique of this game holds up while the bugs and glitches have largely fallen away with time. 

My only nitpick is that I do seem to experience slow down after playing for 2 hours or so, but a quick Save/Exit/Restart seems to clear things up. Considering I'm playing a game ported across about a dozen platform changes, this is a pretty small price to pay to rediscover the little quirks and deep character development that made this a sleeper hit and one of Troika's most beloved last projects.

120% old gold. If you can get it to work and you are a fan of RPG games where the developers have painstakingly made every social encounter to reflect your race, sex and reputation/attractiveness.

The best mechanic in Arcanum is the balance between magick and technology. Although magick is just wonderful with a wide range of spells, technology is an interesting way to develop your avatar in a fantasy world. The biggest disadvantage is to run it on modern PCs (especially on Windows 10).

Must recommend, great experience, buy and play.

I did enjoy similar games like [b]Fallout[/b], [b]Fallout 2[/b] and [b]Planescape: Torment[/b]. They made me change my opinion about oldschool RPGs from negative to positive. And another [i]Troika's[/i] game [b]Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines[/b] is one of my favourite RPGs of all time. So, I was expecting at least an interesting story from [b]Arcanum[/b].
Yet, I can't see myself finishing this game. 
Not because of the old graphics, they are not the point of these oldschool RPGs.
Not because of the simplistic combat system. I can tolerate that.
Not because of the bugs, because the patches pretty much fix them.
Not because I have to use Google all the time to search info on how to complete quests and how things work in this game. That's kind of a standard for old games.
But because of the story, which is what every fan is praising it for.

It's just boring to me. I have finished almost all quests in the first three towns in this game and some additional areas, and I didn't find any quest interesting. They all are pretty much fetch quests. I feel lack of cohesiviness and context to my actions and it doesn't seem that it will get better. Everything just seems so disconnected.

The freedom and versatility of character development in terms of skills, moral alignment and magical vs technical aptitude seems promising, but it also looks like that this game has bitten more than it can chew. It's just not delivered in a fun, balanced and easy understandable way.

Inventory management is also a chore, even with the companions that you can use as pack mules.

Perhaps the only really praiseworthy aspect of this game that I'd like to point out is the beautiful soundtrack.

But that's not really a reason to play a game, is it? A good story would be the minimum I would expect from an RPG. But it's simply not there. The gameplay is just a drag.

I can only recommend this game to people who like games with a strong role-playing aspect ("strong" as in "you have to make the story in your head") with almost absolute freedom of choice and multiple possible builds and who don't mind the old graphics.

[b]My overall rating:[/b] [u]5/10.[/u]

Obsidian called Troika during release, has long been heralded as one of the most innovative and outside the box rpg developers to ever grace this earth, and if you believe that to be true Arcanum is there magnum opus from an artistic and creative point of view. Everything about this title defy's conventions of storytelling, setting, and characters. Is this a fantasy game or a steam punk game, well it's neither. Is this a game that focuses on story, or combat, well that's largely up to you. Are there essentially character classes, a karma system, dialog trees, and some big bad evil guy to beat at the end, again the answer is a resounding sort of, but not really. I think at the end of the day, the highest praise I can award this game is, that if I was forced to live on an island for the rest of my life with one game and one game only, I would choose Arcanum. The possibilities are truly endless with this overlooked gem of a game.

The father of all modern (MMO)RPG games with their chips after 2001! Masterpiece ! If you are a fan of a real RPG and you know how a real RPG should be, then you have played this game, and if not, then you should play this game because it is a real RPG with the theme of Victorian steampunk with magic and technology and unforgettable music that leaves a beautiful reminder and impression. In fact, there are few bugs in the game, since before the game was released, the pirates hacked the beta version of the game and let it go online. But given the masterpiece of the game, those bugs can be forgiven.

Ok. After few tries finally passed the game. I was reading that Arcanum is one of best RPGs ever, which is kinda true. Before you play this game on Steam, you have to know that original game was full of bugs. So first i ll  talk about negative aspects of game. Bugs - however with fan made patches, 95% of bugs are removed. If you get sometimes bug, for example you hero stuck after the fight or in fight, just go to option and switch to real time fight , then return to turn based fight and you are fine. I didn't notice much other bugs, so fan made patch was great. 

Now second negative aspect - it is fighting system. For me, i get used to it, it is fine, but people are talking that it is unfinished. Use turn based fights, sometimes you can combine with real time. You need some times to get perfect in those fights , after few hours you should master fighting system and you will be fine.  So bugs -mostly fixed , fight system -not that bad.

Now focus on game. Its amazing. Huge world. 2million of square kilometers of territory - although its mostly empty.  However there are huge amount of quests that can go different way. NPC that you feel like they are real persons, especially some followers. I finished the game, and follower Raven before last fight said that she has fall in love with me <3 . Probably bcause i invested some points into beauty and i was half-elf and good align . 
You can be evil guy, rob stores, steal their property and magical items, do nasty things , and gather crew of evil followers. You can be mage (i think it is easiest way to win), or you can be knight with magical swords, or engineer with master degree in mechanics and electrical engineering or explosives and guns . 
I never seen other game offering that much variety. Also before you start the game, you have so much races, "background stories" (for example poor guy with more strength but less money, or raised by monks or you can start as super-model with high beauty and charisma and walk through game by talking with people, or you can play as stupid half ogre). Also game is hard. Very hard for fist time playing arcanum. Also it will be almost impossible to pass it alone first time, so my advice use on-line guides to help you about some quests. You can follow main story, and go around. For example when you reach early capital city , dont go straight for main quest. Clean the sewers , it will be hard but you will get few levels and lot of bounty that will make than main quest easier. 


Anyway i can talk all day about this game, it is amazing, one of the best RPGs ever made. Some stuffs made in this game are still unparallel to any other game even almost 20years latter.  I finished game as a good mage, fallen in love with Raven NPC, had sex orgy in StillWater village after i finished one quest, maybe i ll try now as Engineer.  Install fan made update that you can find on steam, (turn off antivirus while installing and playing) and use help of online forums when get stuck. This is an amazing RPG. It is an older game so of course it has out dated graphics but that shouldn't matter. This is an amazing game with a ton of stuff to do in it. You can choose to be good or evil depending on your actions. You can be a sword wielding knight, a gunslinger, a tech wiz, a wizard, or many other things. The game doesn't really give you much guidance but that is because it wants you to explore and talk to everyone to slowly learn the lore and uncover the story. You can go around and steal from people's houses or go and slay monsters that are attacking people. You can choose to rob a bank or defend it. The character creation is fun as well. You pick your race and then your personality to determine your stats at the start of the game. A guide helps a ton in this game so you know where to find all the recruitable characters. The inventory system makes it tough to loot anything and everything. The inventory system is a grid or a certain amount of squares and each item takes up a certain amount of squares in the inventory so you got to do some crazy tetris magic to make sure you keep all the good stuff. The one thing I love most about this game is the soundtrack. The developers put together their own symphony of some of the greatist musicians at the time to create some amazing songs for the game. They put a lot of effort to make the music epic but fit the area your in. I would say this is a game I would highly recommend trying. Great music, great combat system, a decent challenge so you actually have to think about what you want to do first, and just all around fun.

Alright, I don't do many reviews.  But, I have loved this game since I saw it's add in a magazine a year before its release, and even with its delay.  I will say this is my #1 RPG.  So know, there might be some bias in this review, but I will speak of it as impartial as I can.

I will say, I had encountered a few bugs before.  I got trapped in a dungeon, with no escape, because of one before.  At times, it will glitch as well, like the screen not going black at the brothel, so you get in the room, and just fall down.  Small things like that.

Combat seems to be peoples biggest complaints.  I play the game almost exclusivly in RT mode.  In RT, some things suffer.  Also, the combat AI for opponents is pretty repetative (in RT).  They pretty much charge at you, or shoot at you if they ranged.. and thats it.  Kill a guy attacking you, the others suddenly run off a bit, then return.  Rinse Repeat.  In this fashion and mode, Ranged Characters suffer some, and many spells are kinda pointless.  Also, there are areas that will kick your teeth in with their difficulty.  This is most prevalent in the dungeons.  Part of this is due to the fact, while in the overworld map, if you or your allies are low on fatigue due to casting or battle, you can wait an hour and get fully rested.  You won't heal, but you will gain fatigue.  In dungeons, you can not wait.. which means you need to use tonics.. or just wait in RT for it to heal naturally.  There are also creatures that are SUPER annoying to fight.  Golems are the worst.  They aren't unkillable, but it takes a bit of finess.

The other complaint is the balance.  Best character in the game?  Master Melee/Dodge with sword and shield.  You can kill anything in the game by endgame with almost no trouble.  As a mage, it takes a bit more work, as you have to manage your Fatigue, which many enemies actually attack.  But even still, Mages are far 'easier' then Tech characters.  For one, the first companion is a mage.  He is also a healbot.  If your tech savvy, then it is quite possible his spells will fizzle, thus not healing you, wasting his fatigue, and all around causing problems.  This makes the early game harder.  Also, the one other issue with Tech users in the core game.. is the avalibility of components.  Most things you can 'learn' through your points, are fairly common to find.  However when you start getting into some of the complex ones that you find throughout the game, they become a bit more rare.  There are Items in this game that I have never built because I never found the component.  At least not without an Editor, which I used before with my core copy.  So while Tech is far harder to play, I enjoy the fact that it does CHANGE the way the game plays out.  Also, its old school in the sense you can't just click to win no matter your build... as they all have their own strength and weaknesses.

Now, the positives.

Story.  It has an amazing main plot.  The main plot, doing none of the hundreds of side quests, will take days to finish, and takes you all across Arcanum.  It also is amazingly written.  Virgil, your first companion, has his own questline.  Most of the Voiced companions, have their own little quests, but Virgils is by far the most extensive.  The story moves and evolves.  How you LEARN that story, is where the change comes in.  You are an ugly Ogre that everyone attacks on site? (Which is not an exageration) and kill a questgiver that is essental?  There are other ways to learn about it.  I am currently trying to run through the whole game as a huge idiot.  I have never done the whole game that way.. so I can't say just how much the story changes when you can't ask questions like other characters.  But some of the dialog is HILARIOUS.  

Sidequests: Ok, the game is a true open world once you pass the 'tutorial' town.  I say that, because there is a quest you must complete before you can move onto the rest of the world.  There are, as I have discovered, 3 ways to complete this quest... and some are far easier then others.  Also, in this 'tutorial' area... you can easily die.  Just because you survived a blimp crash doesn't mean your invincible.  But, in the tutorial town, there are over a dozen quests.  Some are easy, and take place in town.  Others require you go elsewhere.  Some build up in time.  And some require you to have certain skills.  Then you go into the world proper, and there are NO restrictions.  You can go ANYWHERE you want.  There is not always things there, but usually it always has at least one quest to do. 

Character Creation/Intergration:  Character Creation is one of the easiest but most elaborate system I have seen.  Stat system is a bit different, and you get bonuses for having a 20 in the stat.  Like having 20 CON makes you immune to poison. 20 STR doubles your damage.  Its a very fun system.  As for your intergration in the game.. it actually puts you in the game.  Your inital reaction is based on your beauty and Race, and reputation and alignment.  Talking is based on your charisma.  Sometimes, being a simpleton aids you as people take pity on you.  Other times, people ignore you, or use you, like the constable.  His first quest could net you 500 gold I believe at most.  However, if your an idiot, he gives you 20.  Other people refuse you talk to you all together.

A truly patrician choice. 

The soundtrack has haunted me since I was a small child working in the steel mill. It is by far the most mature and engrossing soundtrack in a role-playing game created for the computer. 

1800‚Äôs setting mixed with fantasy dungeon and dragons, the world of Arcanum is indeed still a post-apocalyptic RPG, however it is not nuclear fallout, but indeed, the ideals of the world as we know it are over. The idea of steam engines meeting spells has been a setting I have longed to return to, alas the world as we know it now in 2018 has left Arcanum and its intellectual property behind. 

First and foremost, the character creation is the most flexible in a CRPG to date. Gone are the days now whereby one may create a character, but by no act of their own input points into the wrong attributes and skills, found themselves a character that has no practical skills and is lost to the wilderness in the first area. 

Critics over the last eighteen years have spoken of the idea of balance, apparently a gunslinger type character will be underpowered in low levels but overpowered once they have invented the elephant gun or repeater rifle. This point is moot. Life is unbalanced. I have come to embrace games that are out of balance. Rather than complain about a loop hole, exploit that loop hole and I will promise you, you will find yourself escaping the blank mountain mines party fully intact. 

Like with other Troika games, the unofficial patch saves the game. And the game is indeed playable and completable. 

My gripe with this game is not the unbalance or bugs, as the reviewers of the last twenty years will have you read. The game just isn‚Äôt that polished and fleshed out. The setting demands more attention and I found the world emptier than I remembered it. Still, it is an important addition to the CRPG compendium.

I've got Arcanum on GoG and now Steam, and both are patched to 1.7.0.4 which is the latest official patch of the game.

The UAP (Unofficial Arcanum Patch) by drog fixes almost everything that's within the scope of possibility without the source code on hand, and is definitely worth using. Additionally, for the ultimate Arcanum vanilla experience, I highly recommend Arcanum: Multiverse Edition. It fixes bugs I was not even aware of and makes some much appreciated tweaks to certain mechanics in the base game, fully fleshing out technology schematics and generally just a lovingly crafted quality of life improvement overall. It has a configurator to easily apply resolution changes, checkbox toggling of certain options provided by popular mods and is available in both English and in Russian.

Other big overhauls worth checking out with more drastic changes to the base game include A:WIP and Carcanum, both of which I also recommend trying at some point. With the communities that have sprung up around this game over the years and the GoG and now Steam releases, it can be enjoyed by anyone interested enough to fire up a 2001 cRPG in the same vein as the original Fallout's. The soundtrack is largely completely performed by a string quartet, a creative choice by Ben Houge that mirrored the asynchronous nature of the conflict between magick and technology in the world of Arcanum- I enjoyed it and found it very fitting for the game.

There is no need for further releases or re-releases, Beamdog fanboys begone.

Firstly, the strengths.
An incredible experience for anyone who loves RPGs, and even a few who don't. Whether you love exploring the insanely flexible branching story, or just like mind controlling people and blowing things up with dynamite, the game is willing to let you have fun any way you want.

Play as a pure Charisma build and amass followers to be your meat shield. Study technology and wield tesla cannons, flaming axes, and build an army of robots to overwhelm your enemies. Study the arcane and summon elementals and demons, to tear apart your foes and then resurrect them as zombies. Neglect your intelligence and fumble through the hilarious dialog as the village idiot. Or study the ways of stealth and thievery, relieving poor fools of the very clothes off their back and shops of their precious earnings.

Truly, anything is possible in Arcanum, a game where lockpicks, fireballs, and dynamite are all viable options for opening doors, and where even major story characters are not safe from death (your followers, too). And with high-resolution patches, the graphics don't suffer so much on modern monitors.

Now to address the drawbacks.
Perhaps the largest issue, if not the most prominent, is that the world is perhaps [i]too[/i] open. There are a lot of huge questlines and bits of story and lore that won't become apparent unless you know exactly where to look, and the gameplay is super awkward until you figure out what works and what doesn't. Especially in the beginning, you might feel like you've picked the wrong build until you figure out how to make it work- there's a definite curve to some builds, and some drawbacks that you might not notice until it's too late.

I see gameplay is one of the most common complains about Arcanum, but I think it's mainly because we're used to games easing us into it. Arcanum will not do that. It will drop you into a world where even passing strangers stand a fighting chance until you attain some advanced skill, spell, or equipment. Multiple times, you will be forced to find alternative solutions when faced with an enemy you cannot punch or stab or Harm to death. I think this is a good thing, as there are always multiple paths to every solution! But it can be frustrating, especially if you don't invest in magick or tech healing from the outset. Just remember that holding shift and a hotkey will self-cast whatever is bound to it, be it a salve, potion, or spell, and casting on the follower portraits is much easier than trying to target them in the midst of battle!

[h1] Retro Review[/h1] 
As a member of the merchants guild i was surprised when papa SsethTzeentach recommended this game. I immediately bought it and kinda tend to differ that it is a game i would recommend people.

[u] Gameplay[/u] 
One of the strongest and at the same time weakest points of Arcanum is the gameplay. On one hand you have a open world, tons of things you can skill, build, explore, solve quests in many ways, you get on the other hand a completely broken combat system. 

The combat is just one of the worst ive ever seen. You either choose real time(without a pause button) or turn based. Neither of them are in any way balanced, nor fun. At the beginning i switched between them, later on i just let the real time mode progress so my companions could auto kill the enemies. 

The turn based mode works  but is boring and unbalanced. Most of your spells are completely useless compared how broken the others are. Bows in real time mode shoot faster than a gatling gun and technology tree itself is only useful in mid/lategame which makes it totally obsolete because the only hard times you have in this game is the early and early midgame. 

Quests are annoying sometimes aswell. The game gives you 0 clues at some point and then you end up discovering in a guide that the person you search is in another town about 10 or 20 hours into the game later in some random house. So you end up looking into each house in every city you go if you didnt read a guide. Since there are mostly only npc¬¥s who are just cosmetic its a tedious and boring task.

I encountered a bug that broke my savegame at the end of the game which made me watch a walktrough of the last part of the game despite i have patched everything with the fan patches.

[u] Story[/u] 
Arcanum offers a quite surprising twist at the end, otherwise it is your average story about an evil nemisis from the legends comes back again story. It kept you wondering if the prophecy is actually true or not. The twist tough is pretty good and will definetly make the story stand out a bit but its still nothing mind blowing. 

The world building of arcanum is interestening but only partially utilized. Technology ceases magic to work and vise versa. So if you are a mage you cant ride the first class train and some shopkeepers will kick you out of their store. Otherwise its not mentioned really and the struggle between technology and magic could have been told and utilized better.

[u]Aestethics[/u] 
In contrast to games like fallout or baldurs gate arcanum didnt age that well. Character models look pretty much alike and its impossible to distinguish between cosmetic npc¬¥s and quest givers. Cities with technology are florishing while the other cities fall apart. Backgrounds look rather average while models of objects do look good.
The best part is probably the music and the voice acting. The main theme is a violin play that really got the renaissance feeling to it. It sounds beatiful yet depressing just as the ingame world. The voice acting is fantastic and i recommend to everyone to just listen to a few samples of them.


[u]Conclusion/TL;DR [/u] 
Arcanum is definetly not a must play because it doesnt offers a fantastic gameplay but has a mildly interestening  story and world building. It definetly lacks in many areas and is broken in combat. But it got a very interestening elements i didnt see before. Especially the almost untouched industrial revolution era in games. I would recommend this only to people who already played trough the old classic isometric rpg¬¥s and crave some more and really dig the setting

Geiles Spiel ohne Frage! Ich hab es immer geliebt und werde seiner immer in ehren gedenken! Hab es mir gestern wieder mal geg√∂nnt, hab es noch auf alter CD hier herum liegen l√§uft aber nicht mehr ganz so geschmeidig wie einst auf dem guten alten Win/98-Hobel. Wer es nicht in Englisch spielen mag der findet hier: https://www.validstrategies.com/files/file/16-arcanum-german-language-pack/ das Deutsche Sprachpaket. Aber! Ganz gro√ües ABER!! Unter Win-10 bekommt man es ums verrecken nicht vern√ºnftig zum laufen. Mein Rechner schafft alles; massen schie√üereien in Fallout 4, herrliche verfolgungsjagden bei GTA-V, aber Arcanum l√§uft als w√ºrde man es auf ner schimmeligen Zwiebel zocken! Hab zig tipps und tricks und .dll's und sonst was probiert; keine Chance!
Ich gebe die Hoffnung nicht auf das es irgendwann mal ne Neuauflage gibt, vielleicht sogar in Firstperson *Tr√§um*, aber is es nicht zu gebrauchen. Leider..

Ich habe das Spiel NICHT nur 0,4 Stunden gespielt, wie angezeigt. Ich hab dem Goldst√ºck wirklich mehr als Zwei Chancen gegeben und locker mal 3 Stunden gezockt und geschustert um es am -fl√ºssigem- laufen zu halten!

A good, classic, retro ARPG! Arcanum really excels with its steampunk-magitech environment and world, surprisingly lore-dense and interactive for its old time. The character and combat systems are just about identicaly to D&D, so if you've got experience with that, you'll have an easy time with this. The soundtrack is also really interesting, being entirely string quartet, and it's a good one. The few bad points I'd point out are that it only pretends to be open world: there's this huge world map that takes literal weeks of in-game time to traverse, but unless you're at a key location, there's absolutely nothing out there. Fun technical crafting system for Technology disciplines, opposite Magic(k), though Magick is objectively stronger in just about everything.

If you like classic Diablo/D2, I would 100% recommend Arcanum!
