The following review was written when I played a technologist:
Played for 23 hours and got to level 30

This is not a good game, period. I love the other 2 games of Troika (VTMB and TOEE), played them for hours. The problem with arcanum is not its world or its characters- in this department it seems to have huge potential. But even after the official and unofficial patch, the game is just irritating to play. The combat is terrible, and you can't avoid it. It took me sometimes hours to finish one dungeon, and it always means exploiting the weak AI and weird glitches. The graphics are low standard, even for the time period- it's not the quallity itself, it's the design- the game looks not even half baked, more like 20% baked. The music is of course beautiful- but sometimes it just doesn' fit the mood and can be irritating. 

Bottom line: a remake is in need. The game shows potenital, but right now it's just a chore play, no fun at all.

Sadly, this game has a too poor performance, choking and freezing every second. This makes it unplayable.

Despite being an old game, it has a very poor usability; Every action seems to be hard and there are some unnecessary over complicated tasks. Learning how to move around between locations, for an example, should be something simple that took me half an hour.

It appears to have some nice mechanics and freedom of choice, which would be very interesting if the game was a little more playable. The story and the dialogs are just ok, and the environment is a little strange.

I understand it is a old game, and things were different. Still, talking about today, at least, this game needs too much force of will. You  probably have better options out there.

To a lack of usability and performance
4/10
Can we get an enhanced edition of Arcanum? Pretty please?

A note on play time: I haven't played a lot of this game on Steam, but I played this game through several times in it's original form. The Steam edition (especially with cut-content mods, high-resolution patches, and official patches) is superior. I'm planning to play through this steam version soon, but only when I have the time. Most of my review is based on the original version, so your experience may vary. I'll probably update the review when I complete the game via Steam.

General: There is a substantial depth of lore within the game. Much of the lore affects the main character's reactions to events, abilities, and interactions with the people in the world. The implementation of magic vs. technology is effective, especially in how these two elements interact.

Characters/Combat: Player Character skills and attributes can be personalized a lot but this is, in many ways, a combat-oriented game. The combat system can be switched between real-time and turn-based on the go. Usually, if you have problems with a fight, you can enable turn-based and have more control over what happens and when. Even then, the action point calculations are cumbersome. Attempting to create a non-combat character can work but expect to run into problems if you are unable to defend yourself. Focusing solely on combat, however, brings with it it's own problems.

UI/Controls: Some of the UI and controls require getting used to. Some problems can be helped with key bindings, but much of the control scheme is outdated by today's standards. It reminds me of old-school computer RPGs (because it is one) before more robust control schemes were created. Expect to have to click and/or button press a lot to achieve certain results.

Graphics: The graphics are serviceable, but don't look that great. Some computers might experience problems with dropped frames and other issues. It's an old game.

Sound/Music/Speech: Some of the menu sounds (especially the 'error' sounds) are annoying. The music is generally good and the voice-acting is functional. (Edit: Playing through it a little now, the voice acting is better than I remember. Some of the character lines are actually very good, especially Virgil.)

Difficulty: Depending on character creation and upgrades, this can be an extremely difficult game. Don't expect to have your hand held throughout. Combat can be very frustrating. Expect to read and reread descriptions of everything (along with trial and error) to even have a chance of understanding the intricacies of this game.

Overall thoughts: It's worth a playthrough if you can get past the dated factor of the game. The story is well-conceived but requires a lot of work to piece together. It doesn't require multiple playthroughs, but like other computer RPGs, you need a lot of help or dumb luck to put together a character that really shines through to the end.

Great game, became immersed within the first hour of gameplay. The first time I played though, I made the mistake of creating a melee character and didn't realize you actually had to out points into persuasion. So I restarted and created a firearms character, and began investing my points into persuasion and firearms. Combat is definitely this game's weak point and the graphics aren't the most amazing, but I could honestly care less about graphics and I can overlook the combat by setting it to easy and real time combat mode, which makes it a little less stressful. Overall the games flaws can be overlooked and it has great characters, story, and humor.

Want to be straight forward with this one. It's such a classic for me, the game i grew up with, though at a time gore violence and language was too much for a child mind of mine. 
Choices matter, and usually, in a long run, what skills you invest in - matters a lot, so you have to think carefuly and plan ahead.
Dialogue options matter, some can give you a new friend, and others can insult the person to the point when he tries to murder you in cold blood, and sometimes you have an option to bluff your way out of the combat and gain a lot of new useful information.
Way of presenting your adventures and knowledge is very immersive aswell - you have a diary you put all your thoughts and progress into, always can turn to it when you think you missing something.
Tactics to combat, dungeons and other situations always differ, in order to be effective you have to adapt, so just rushing in is usually a bad idea, everything is sort of a puzzle, an ode to how people would actually act, how enemies would logically act.
Characters have character to them, their motives, stories to tell. If you care enough to listen. Story and the world you are in are very immersive and make sense.
Is it a bit unfinished? sure. So grab your self a few community patches beforehand, and immerse yourself in this world by thinking everytime "What would I do in this situation, and which tools do I have to use to succeed". It can't get more RPG than this.

Has some frame rate problems off and on here while PubG doesn't, still playable. The game really looks great and the towns seem the right size etc. The dialogue choices are wide and even race sensitive and leave you usually with 2 or 3 different ways to approach a task. But the character build plan has some balance issues and probably needed to be tweaked a little bit before shipping the game.
Great Old School game. Works well and good story.  A+++++  10/10.

Despite being into cRPG's all my life, Arcanum never spoke to me back in the day. I gave it a second chance and I'm happy that Steam gives us the option to get a refund. Some reasons:
-required a ton of patching to make it work properly
-still had a ton of bugs after all the official and innoficial patches
-the music is kinda meh
-balance in this game is a myth- there are strategies that are better, and there are strategies that won't work because screw you for trying to be different
-and the thing that baffles me to no end- the game forces you to choose either technology or magic and actively punishes you if you even dare to achieve balance. No thank you.

I believe anyone who says the game has charm and becomes better if you give it more time, but I have no time for this shit anymore. You guys have fun, I'm out and still waiting for a good steampunk/fantasy RPG to come.

The very first pc game I ever purchased. 
I devoured it. I LOVED it when I was 13 and I'm very happy my feelings didn't change at all!

Beside the huge amount of nostalgia I feel for this game ... 

Arcanum has a huge world. The main and side-quests are super fun to live through. You can be everything, make everything, beat the game in any way you like. Every decision is important to the ending. It has more synchron-actors than skyrim, though only one romance option. ... (Waited like 17 years for a certain romance mod *cough* never came and probably never will .. *big sigh* in my dreams, Virgil p_√≤ ... err.. anyways!)

- What might be a bit annoying to some is the music. I like chello music, but after some time it gets dull, the fighting music especially. But I guess given for it's age, it's a minor. 

- The huge world mentioned seems empty. There's a lot of space to be filled, dear community! √î_√î 
But if you enjoy running through forests, plains ect for hours without using the world map fast-travel .. Eh! Have fun :D *thumb up*

What else? ehh .. 
Virgil romance mod, PLEASE! T_T

This is one of the best rpgs I ever played. The combat, the story, the immense world to explore. It was THE game of my childhood. It has some problems like bugs that kills your save (be sure to have manys slots) and some clonkyness that hurts the gameplay. But in overall it is nothing short than an excellent game, with great mechanics, many combinations of "classes" and a very strong replay value.
Give it a go, enjoy the beautiful music, the many stories it has and try the best steampunk game made untill now.

Hoory. My favorite RPG of all time is available on steam. Why is it doing those weird flashy things in the intro. Pretty good fun like I remember it. The only issue is the resolution can't be changed and as a result it looks very dated on a modern monitor. Still if you liked playing it when it was first released it is worth giving a revisit.
Great game, I just wish they would add a patch to make the screen 1080 :)

I knew about this game for more than 15 years and yet I only just now played it through and it was totally worth it. I fell in love with it and it become one of my all time favourite CRPGs out there, perhaps only behind Fallout 2. The atmosphere, story and music were amazing. There are some flaws in it, like confusing UI at first, a bit boring graphics and some bugs but don't let those stop you from playing this game, it's worth your time! Must buy for any CRPG fan out there.

Ne vous fiez pas √† mes heures de jeu, j'ai achet√© ce jeu sur CD il y a longtemps. Ce jeu fait partie de mes jeux de r√©f√©rence, avec BG2, NWN et n'importe quel fallout et maintenant POE2: deadfire et D:OS. J'aurais tendance √† la mettre en premier d'ailleurs, car c'est le premier jeu que j'ai essay√© avec du crafting, et pas n'importe lequel : avec un gameplay d'inventeur. 

Ce gameplay unique permet de combiner diff√©rents domaines scientifiques pour cr√©er des objets tr√®s puissants, tr√®s vari√©s, et dont on comprend la logique ais√©ment. Le fait de combiner les objets 2 par 2 rend le crafting parfaitement compr√©hensible et stimulant. Plusieurs objets ont diff√©rentes variantes radicalement diff√©rentes selon le sch√©ma et les ingr√©dients dont on se sert. Ce jeu a un des meilleurs gameplays que je connaisse, avec un syst√®me de crafting particuli√®rement r√©ussi. 

Le syst√®me de magie est int√©ressant aussi, mais je dirais que la grande nouveaut√© et r√©ussite de ce jeu est la branche technologique, que je cherche d√©sesp√©r√©ment dans d'autres jeux, mais qui n'y est g√©n√©ralement repr√©sent√©e qu'√† 10-20 % en termes de vari√©t√©.

L'histoire est assez r√©ussie √©galement, mais je prends d√©j√† un grand plaisir √† amasser de l'or et collectionner les sch√©mas. Il n'y en a d'ailleurs pas 56 comme c'est parfois dit, mais davantage encore avec les sch√©mas multi-technologiques que l'on peut acheter ou trouver, et qui sont encore plus int√©ressants. Les 56 objets √† crafter √©voqu√©s dans les reviews sont en fait ceux de base uniquement.

C'est un jeu peu cher qui plus est et particuli√®rement recommand√© poru tout amateur de cRPG. Seuls les graphismes sont un peu viellots maintenant, mais la plupart des amateurs de cRPG pourront s'y habituer et passer un bon moment.

A phenonenal RPG that has a lot to offer. 

Fans of Fallout 1, Fallout 2, Baldurs Gate and other top down Computer RPG's will probably find a lot of joy in this title, as it is a wonderful world full of interesting epople and locations. There are plenty of options for different classes while also experimenting with race and personality. 

It is a little buggy here and there and quite rough around the edges, but that just adds to the charm for me personally.

"I'll be the sickest necromancer in the fucking world dude, radical!"..
Those words. Those are how it started. Little did I know how it would end up..

I made my character, a sickly elf. Physicality of a frail, old, HIV-positive neighborhood pervert, but the mind of a supreme cosmic being.. I play a bit into the game, get better at the dark necromancy skill line, get some gear, pimp up my follower, I'm living life, doing quests.. I'm walking around the streets of Tarant. Suddenly I see a sign. "Brothel", it says.
Don't mind if I do!
So I enter the brothel, and talk to the old head mistress. She tells me all the prostitutes cost 100 gold. "100 gold? Geez, that's steep, don't you have anything cheaper?", "Sure, for the most deviant of clientel, you can pay old Belle a visit for just 25 gold". What a good deal, huh?
So I pay the 25 gold, enter Belle's room, and what do I see..? 
The love of my life. Belle. A large, white sheep. To make a long story short, I end up making sweet love with that sexy piece of wool till my character passes out from fatigue. 

That can't be right.. I passed out from screwing Belle? How could I do that to her? 
That's when I decided. I needed to hone my abilities, so that I could fuck Belle all night without passing out.
The ultimate quest. The first step was to take a vow of chastity. I sent myself into exile in the Vendigroth Wastes, a place of sand, drought and spiders. Lots of spiders. The poor sods didn't even know what was coming for them.
Blue-balling myself, crushing spiders and demons, praying to Belle every night, caused my necromantic powers to grow. My fatigue had grown exponentially. For months I walked the desert, a robed figure; more dangerous than any creature of the night. My celibacy gave me immense strength. I blew up the heads of my enemies, with my necromantic "harm"-ability. God, it was like watching Dr. Manhattan blow up gooks in Vietnam. It was time. Time to make my return. But first, I figured I might as well do a part of the main quest, in some nearby mountains. I make my way in. Rats and other pests try to stop me, but I crush them like the vermin they are. Suddenly, an enemy approaches me that I didn't anticipate. An ore golem. He knocks me out and cleaves my skull in. Bah, no worry, I saved my game.. That's when tragedy struck. Through some dark prank by the gods, my hand slipped, and a finger landed on a button on my keyboard. Before I knew what had happened, my save game was deleted. Just as I died. 
My dear Belle, I am watching from heaven, but it is important you move on with your life. 

tl;dr 10/10, fuck sheep prostitutes, blow up enemies with magick and be reminded of the inevitability of death, would do again :)

Pour les fans de RPG en 2d isom√©trique. Un jeu du niveau de fallout avec une opposition tech/magie formidable √† jouer.

Que no te enga√±e las pocas horas que tengo en Steam, hace m√°s de una d√©cada jugaba a este juego d√≠a si y d√≠a tambi√©n en mi viejo pc con windows 98 pas√°ndomelo en grande con la cantidad de cosas que me ofrec√≠a.

Arcanum es una especie de Fallout 1 steampunk con vista isom√©trica y con un toque rpg brutal, puedes ser lo que t√∫ quieras: Desde un nigromante que invoca elementales y demonios hasta un ingeniero con ara√±as mec√°nicas pasando por un vulgar ladr√≥n, pistolero o un herborista que invoca espiritus del bosque. ¬°Incluso puedes hacer una combinaci√≥n ca√≥tica de todas ellas, el juego no te lo va a impedir!

Las opciones y variantes de di√°logos que tiene sumado a las skills/perks para la profesi√≥n que te de la gana (o la combinaci√≥n de varias) y el tipo de raza de tu personaje con sus pros y sus contras hace que este juego literalmente se r√≠a de los dos primeros Fallouts. Es un juego bastante desconocido e infravalorado pero si le das una oportunidad su mundo te absorber√° enseguida, no hay dos tipos de walkthroughs iguales debido a la cantidad de eventos distintos que se dan y posiblemente acabes en situaciones nuevas.
Hay una grand√≠sima cantidad de ciudades y calabozos que explorar en el mapa, infinidad de tesoros muy interesantes como gemas, armas sagradas o piezas para hacerte tus propios robots.
Sobre los monstruos que puedo decir... Hay pr√°cticamente 300 tipos de enemigos distintos (lobos, zombis, robots, fantasmas, golems y un largo etc...) junto a encuentros aleatorios cuando vas por el mapa, m√°s te vale farmear bien.
En cuanto a la OST solo te puedo decir que si te encantan los violines vas a disfrutarla mucho, a mi particularmente se me hizo muy memorable ;)
Y si, puedes tener followers, una gran cantidad de ellos casi sin limite, algunos se unir√°n a ti sin dudarlo y otros requerir√°n algunas condiciones como tener buen karma, los hay que se negar√°n a unirse a ti porque tienes un follower que les cae mal incluso.

Una buena noticia sobre Arcanum es que es un juego del que no se necesita parches para hacerlo runear correctamente en windows 10 (los hay para mejorar los fps, HD packs y alg√∫n que otro para fixear bugs) y ha envejecido bastante bien en comparaci√≥n con otros juegos de la era prehist√≥rica.

TL;DR: Fallout 1 steampunk que expande los horizontes de lo conocido como un rpg, para mi, una joyita infravalorada adelantada a su √©poca.

Arcanum... Ah ! Un vieux jeux parmi tant d'autres, et pourtant qu'il est unique !
Alors commen√ßons par tirer dessus √† boulet rouge : il y a des bugs (corrigeables par des patch non-officiel), l'√©quilibrage des "classes" n'est pas √©quilibr√© (faire le jeu avec un voleur est... tentable dans le meilleur des cas, le faire avec un bourrin du cac est ennuyeux, le faire avec un personnage charismatique est int√©ressant, etc), le sc√©nario est parfois obscur et quelques plantages sont √† pr√©voir.
Bon, et bien voil√† le maximum de n√©gativit√© dont je pourrais faire preuve √† l'√©gard du jeu...

Par cons√©quent, attaquons le plat de r√©sistance et allons vers le positif, ce sera nettement plus copieux.
La cr√©ation de personnage est int√©ressante, avec beacuoup de possibilit√©s et √©norm√©ment de personalisation. Les graphiques sont √† l'ancienne, mais c'est fluide (bon, √ßa rame parfois sur les nouveaux syst√®me d'exploitation, mais il suffit de quitter et de relancer le jeu pour que √ßa aille mieux) et jolie dans l'ensemble. Les musiques sont agr√©ables, parfois stressantes, et les ambiances sonores vraiment sympas et plut√¥t bien fichues. Le sc√©nario est un peu long √† d√©marer mais... prenant, et avec quelques bonnes surprises.
La cerise sur le g√¢teau, et ce qui fait d'Arcanum un excellent RPG : cette ambiance, bon sang, MAIS CETTE AMBIANCE ! Simplement magique... Ou technologique selon votre orientation. Le style steampunk est parfaitement r√©ussit et le m√©lange, parfois le choc, entre les cultures techno-vapeur et magie est particuli√®rement bien g√©r√©. C'est toute sa force, car cela en fait √©galement un univers original. Le fait que le background soit assez bien fournit est √©galemnt un plus qui ne fait que renforcer cette ambiance.
A rajouter √† cela que le gameplay est complet sans √™tre lourd et que ses aspects sont agr√©ables tout en √©tant changeants. En effet, passer des sch√©matiques technologiques aux sortil√®ges en passant par les comp√©tences g√©n√©rales et le social n'est absolument pas rebutant et parfaitement g√©rable pour n'importe qui, sans pour autant enlver ces choix que l'on devra faire. Car non, on ne pourra pas tout faire et c'est parfait ainsi.
Et par cons√©quent, la dur√©e de vie du jeu est plut√¥t bonne ! Refaire le jeu est envisageable sans trop de probl√®mes car m√™me si le sc√©nario aura son fil conducteur, et bien cela ne se fera pas du tout de la m√™me fa√ßon avec un arnaqueur n√©, un voleur halfelin, un guerrier demi-orque associable, un mage elfe ou un technologiste nain.
Rajoutez √† tout cela des modules suppl√©mentaires et vous avez un petit bijoux du d√©but des ann√©es 2000.

Alors, il reste ce prix √† 10 E sur steam alors que le studio a disparu me direz-vous...
C'est pas faux. Et j'aurai pr√©f√©r√© verser cet argent aux d√©veloppeurs qui ont cr√©er une belle r√©ussite. Malheureusement, Arcanum reste difficile √† trouver et √† faire fonctionner convenablement sur une machine r√©cente dans les bonnes r√©solutions. Steam a g√©r√© ces deux probl√®mes. Et puis √† titre posthume (ouais, je capilotracte la chose, je sais), continuer de faire vivre Arcanum reste une belle r√©compence pour ceux qui ont travaill√© dessus voici pas loin de vingt ans.

Arcanum vaut vraiment le coup pour les fans de RPG comme d'univers steampunk. Un beau coup de coeur ind√©modable.

Arcanum is my favorite bad game ever. Due to the circumstances around its release, it was never completed. I'll let y'all research that if you're interested. Suffice it to say that the game is pretty broken in some major areas and the combat is absolutely atrocious. Beyond that, it's one of the best, most entertaining, inexhaustible games I've ever played, and it has really shaped my taste in games as an adult.
It isn't a perfect (or even finished) game by any means. But it is the structure of a damn good game, and most of the substance of one, too.
One of my Top 5 of all Chuck time.

This dungeon crawler is interesting. Set in the victorian era, you are still able to choose from the normal races.
Human, gnome, ogre, and elf. Quests are interesting and the gameplay is somewhat akin to baldur's gate.

Movement is either mouseclick or arrow keys. WASD is non existent and as a matter of fact, the S key opens your rest options. If you have trouble with your eyesight, this could prove to be an issue since you can't adjust the display resolution. 
Characters in the game seem to have their own unique personalities so it makes banter somewhat entertaining.
Beware though, this game can be challenging!  

There are options to turn auto attacks on and off and also set difficulty levels. If you like the feel of classic dungeon crawlers, this game will not dissappoint.  definate recommend!  7/10

TY sir - not all Heros wear capes and you are doing Gods work.

I remember when I first played Arcanum. A good friend of mine introduced me to the game a ways back. I'd forgotten about it for a while but when it came to a game that had options this was the game I always mentioned and came back to in my memories (though I forgot the name) and now, it's on steam.

Arcanum has a lot going on and can be fairly overwhelming at first look. With some things such as 18+ schools of magic, 8 tech schools, and 4 skill bars along with each one having around 4 to 5 (in the case of the technology skills) skills/tiers each. A morality system and a bar that gauges how inclinded to magic or technology you are? That's a lot. Thankfully the game has built in tool tips to give a bit of information by overing over the stat or bar.

So lets look at some of the game's highlights
1. Choices affect the ending - For those who have played a game like Dragon Age Origins, say is here, your choices through the game no matter how small they may seem, can have a huge impact on the story's ending. 

2. Inventory - Inventory is one you have to think about, in the later Mass Effect game for example, the more weapons you took effected your use of powers/abilities. The same applies, you have a weight limit and like in Diablo and early Fallouts, you have limited inventory space, More weight will mean less actions in battle and it means being less prepared in some cases. You have party members (max 2) who can help carry items, but in all its something to easily lose track of until you get in a pinch.

3. Allies React - This has a few meanings, like if you have a low intellegnce or take a background that makes you seem like an idiot, your allies and the people you meet will react to that, they also react to your moral choices through the game. Do too many evil deeds with a party of noble characters and they'll turn on you, like wise for a party of evil characters and doing too many good deeds, only people I've seen never leave are Virgil (first party member) and the Dog.

4. Magic vs Technology - The game offers a lot in play time, replay ability and just general ways to do things. The big focus though is magic vs technology. If you are too allied with Magic, Tech shops will demand you leave (and sometimes assault you to make you leave) Like wise going tech and into a magic shop, this gets even more complicated when you realize there's 4 potions, 2 tech and 2 magic (your cursor changes to show which type is being used and they are different) use the right tools for the job, don't use Salves (tech potion) on a mage, you might actually use 6-10 before you get a single heal, same with magic healing (potion or spell) on a tech character.

5. Combat - You can change the combat to turn based or free flowing in the options. Personally I like turn based as it gives me time to plan. You have lots of options in combat from spells to melee to inventions and guns. The main things to watch are of course your HP (if allies die, they're dead unless you have a skill/tech that can revive them) and the blue bar, it's not mana, it's Fatigue and if it hit's 0 you faint in battle. This isn't like pokemon where you go back to the inn, it means 100% chance free hits on the character! It can be useful though as weapons have a HP damage and Fatigue damage stat and you can drain your enemies fatigue to give yourself an edge.

6. The world - The map is a very big one, and you have the options of either running place to place the long way or when you reach the boarder of  an area, click the map button (turns to a blue globe) and click points to fast travel. Now obsticles will still be in the way, so if a mountain is in between you and the point you want to go to, you do have to map around it. And it can be a trip, along the way you can be attacked by monsters/wildlife (bears will hate you) and it's not always a cake walk as it can be an enemy you're used to or it could be a horde of bears (had 3 at once before) but there's lots of points to visit on the map and they become active just by passing them. Keep in mind, though you can go to areas such as the final dungeon from the beginning, the game will punish you for it in combat.

7. Character Creation - Probably should have led with this, but oh well. You pick how your character is set up before going on the Zephyr. You pick a portit (that's the easy part), gender, race and background 1st. These all effect how your party memebers and NPCs react to you. Females get races of Human, Elf, Half-Elf, and Half-Orc while males get those, dwarf, halfling and gnome. Each race has unique backgrounds, abilities and reactions and each background effects reactions too. Exaple if you take the Idiot Savant background, you have a huge bonus to your intellgence, a penalty to your strength and everyone talks to you as though you have a intellegnce score of 2 (which leads to some entertaining commentary). After that you get 5 points to level things, you have 8 stats and a ton of formentioned skills. Everything takes only 1 point to level, but is effected by a skill, like to learn Tech tree blue prints you need the matching level of intellegnce(or be really lucky and find the blue print for sale in a store) all magic is learned through the schools here (no buying spells, sorry fellow mages) So planning a bit a head is a good idea, but not manditory. Then you have the option to buy some gear (background effects starting coin) be it some bullets, a gun (you get one fairly early) or just some fair armor/sword to make things a bit easier at the start. 

8. Criticls Effect nearly EVERYTHING! - That's right, from haggling to lockpicking. Shooting to pickpocketing its effected by a crit chance. Some aren't that bad on a failure, like haggling and you might just have to pay a bit higher price, in combat you can kill yourself with a crit fail, lockpicks can jam the door/chest (don't worry you can just break it down/open) But if you don't have the skills, you can ask a party member to do it (or they'll voulenter) for you.

9. Leveling - as you've noticed probably in the pictures, there's 2 red bars in the middle of the screen. Those are your experience bars (yes, bars) The top, thick semented one is your to next level bar, fill it up, you gain a level and a point to invest in a skill/stat. The small thin red bar undereanth it, that's also an experience bar, max it out to gain a portion of the other experience bar. How do you fill that little red one? Do anything but walk and you'll fill it. Make inventions, hit/miss in combat (yeah, hitting yourself with crit failures gives EXP) everything you do will give points to that bar. When you level your HP and Fatigue are restored (you can level mid-combat from crit failing as long as it didn't kill you)

10. One member's trash is another's treasure - There's no real 'vendor trash' items to the game. There's that stuff you'll probably never use like a mage character has no use for old rags or coal. But a tech character can use those things to make explosives and bullets provided you have the recipe. Now you're probably going "but earlier you said tech merchants won't sell to mages?" That's true, but there's also general stores who sell the odds and ends of tech inventions like rags and fuel and batteries regardless if you went tech or magic.

Now somethings I'd call 'Cons' to the game (everything else, take it as you like.
These are kinda big now a days. There's no autosave feature. So save often especially in an area you're not famliar with!
The main 'bug' I've found that would be the 2nd "con" for me, is you can't tab out. What this means is if you click alt+tab and then go back into the game, it causes a strange graphics glich that will corrupt that game. You can play like that, but it prevents you from saving.

All in all at 6 USD as a base price, this game has a lot to offer besides it's rich story and deep lore.

Fallout: High Fantasy Edition:

- Blow up  f@%$en doors to whatever quest important rooms you need with some dynamite if you don't have time or points to put into lock pick.
- Make every major real world religious figure look like a noob and resurrect fallen companions when they inevitably get themselves killed (literally, one guy managed to cut off his own freaken head)!
- Or screw compassion and kill quest crucial characters, then resurrect their tortured ghosts to find out what you need! Or bully them, because at this point your already an evil prick! 
-Become a steampunk sniper and kill everything with a long distant steampowered sniper, which you built from your own bare hands!
- Become a powerful archmage who can teleport, then realize you have to walk because technology literally cannot work around you (including trains)!
-Recruit dozens of Companions including a drunken Half-ogre, a newly converted high fantasy Mormon, a suspiciously "did I mention I am a traditional dwarf" city dwarf, a delightfully hammy sociopathic necromancer, a super British big game hunter (in a world without Great Britain), and a dog that will murder anything that is not you! 
- Bulls$&t your way through several important conversations, including the big bad himself!
- And more!!!
I loved this game, but it does not run well on Steam. It is laggy and I get error messages a lot

I have this game on CD and have put in a lot of hours and finished the game years ago.  Nice to see it on Steam.  

It's set in an age with guns, trains, flying machines and recipes for making all manner of technical devices...a more industrial age...but still clings to swords and magic if you're so inclined to go that way.  A very odd mix but either way you choose, it's fun and challenging.  

The story is rich with many twists and turns depending on the dialogue you choose when interacting with others.  Your ability to influence others, including party members, is important as it has the effect on who will deal with you or not or who will party with you or not.   If you're into making your character as good as he can get or as evil then this game is for you.

To players who are used to more modern games be warned this is an older game with dated graphics. (Despite this, the game still runs smoothly}. There is A LOT of traveling between towns and other places just to accomplish one task here and one there.  Seems, at times, there's more traveling from place to place just to advance the game than actual fighting.  There are lots of quests...just about every NPC your character encounter's has a task or three. The world map helps a bit because you can use it to travel to places more quickly.  You will auto-stop to fight if there is a monster encounter along the route.

I recommend this game for an older age group as there are some elements in the game you may not want your younger children playing: i.e., a "dancing" parlor with ladies of the evening and sexual innuendo.

This game was great. There was so much to do and it was really well-written. There were so many options for character building and development and there is definitely a ton of replayability. I played this game for a long time and I know I missed a lot, even after 80+ hours. The story was a decent length and there were tons of side quests of varying difficulty. It took me a little bit to figure out the various menus but I was able to do it without reading the manual. I would recommend this game to any RPG enthusiast and to anyone who may have enjoyed Fallout but also enjoys fantasy/steampunk settings.

Unfortunately, as is, this game has some serious technical issues. It is almost completely unplayable without a fix (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=755396888 worked perfectly for me). If you try playing it without, you will face severe lagging, bugs, and freezes. I played it for a while without and I had to restart the game every five minutes because the lag was so bad that it was taking several times longer than it should have to play. Just take a few minutes to find a fix and it is well worth your time.

The game does not play nice with newer versions of Windows. Apparently a problem with Direct X and universal on anything after Windows 8. Laggy, jerky, long load times - basically runs like you're trying to play a new game on a 17 year old machine instead of the other way around.   
  
You can fix it by following this guide: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=755396888

But they really shouldn't be selling it in this state.

I've always been in love with this game. It's a buggy mess, it's not the most attractive, and the combat and animations aren't great. Arcanum just has a charm to it that I can't get passed. It's so immersive, and doesn't pull any punches in the story, so you get to see some dark things in the world, and try to understand the world it's in. This game taught me about what racism and sexism is when I was a child. I don't mean in the modern "everything is sexist, everything is racist sense", it taught me the historical realities of what it was like through a fantasy game. Putting me in the shoes of somebody living in the industrial era, even though the game has magic and steampunk madness. 

Truly one of my most beloved games. I own three copies. One on steam, one hard copy, and another hard copy that was so scratched it was unusable.
Arcanum was always one of my favorite games when I first started playing PC games. It has a great story and the classic Fallout 1&2 style gameplay.
If I had one game to play for the rest of my life this would be it. This game cures cancer.
One of my most favorite games of all time. Dozens of choices to make, find your playstyle, find your favorite NPC and then develop their own stories. A great game for any RPG lover.

This was recommended to me because I really enjoyed Divine Divinity, but this is nowhere near as good as the first DD. The map is massive, but mostly empty. Even the simplest of battles leave you flailing around missing 90% of the time. This means you die a lot. Killed by wolves. Killed by rats. Killed by little spiders. Killed for accidentally stealing. Craft pistols out of junk you find in rubbish bins.
----
Follow shopkeepers into their bedrooms at evenings.
Watch them sleep.
After they return to work in the morning, magically unlock their inventory chest.
Sell their stock back to them.
----
Use the Pyrotechnic Bow.
Your opponent is now naked because their armour took too much durability damage.
----
Use the Disintegrate spell to deatomize your target creature, item or piece of street lighting out of the game
----
Find a cursed ring of invisibility in a strange swamp.
Become unconscious from the ring's mana drain.
Have a follower remove the ring.
Permanently invisible because of a bug and break your save because NPCs now think you're a ghost.
----
Use the ring in Vendigroth to deactivate automaton soldiers.
Deploy your new army of 20~ salvaged humanoid murder machines.

Arcanum is a classic isometric rpg, that has always been one of those games that I keep coming back to, no matter what, or it's flaws, or glitches, and I always remember it fondly.. It was either a case of too fast too soon on Sierra's part, or simply before it's time, but it never seemed to attain the popularity of other rivalling RPGs had. It's character design, and interesting, slightly dark, slightly humorous tone made for an impressive world.. The gameplay was designed to be very open, allowing you to make a vast array of character concepts, focused on many different roles.

The steampunk setting made for a nice divergence from anything made, and indeed, most games being made currently.. And it's take on magic and machine, having each affect the other, mages found alchemical enhancements and salves failing, while a technophile found themselves resistant to both offensive, and curative magic, felt very grounded and implemented well.

It's a good, if aged game.. If you were ever a fan of games like Fallout, Baldur's Gate, and the like, give arcanum a try.. It take's a little getting used to, but there is fun to be had.

From previous experiences, this game is awesome, however, I have been entirely unable to get this version to run for more than 20 minutes without crashing. I don't recommend getting this on newer PCs.

Great writing, great art, great world building. If you're a fan of top-down CRPG's, you've played this game. Requires manual patching to work with modern systems. Controls take a bit of getting used to.

I have owned the original, classic version of Arcanum for ages, and I am basing this review on this original copy of Arcanum that I owned.

The Fallout series has been known for the multitude of choices and possible play styles, and is iconic as a series where the choices in the game do matter. Even in the later, non-Interplay members of the series, choice is still a strong theme: in Fallout 3, if you did a certain dastardly deed, you can still meet the survivor of one of your deeds, and make some form of amends. With such a strong pedigree to its name, one may wonder if the developers of the original Fallout had applied a similar design approach, but to an entirely different setting, one that would appeal to those who prefer something less dreary than the post-apocalypse. Such a game does exist, that game being Troika‚Äôs Arcanum. Troika, which was founded by Tim Cain, one of the lead programmers of Arcanum, made what could be considered to be a fantasy version of Fallout. Except, it is a lot more than that.

Arcanum takes place in a high fantasy Tolkienesque world, that is currently undergoing an Industrial Revolution. Magic and technology are presented as mutually exclusive choices: as magic is a supernatural force, it contravenes natural, and as with it, technological, laws. As such, a mage carrying a gun will have the gun explode in his face, and a machinist trying to use a scroll with experience a similar critical fail. This can be offset, by carefully balancing between both disciplines so that neither aptitude will affect the player character, but this comes at the cost of experiencing the full potential of focusing on either a magic or technological aptitude. But it is this kind of limitation that makes theorycrafting and character-making in the game so incredibly fun. Not to mention, if Fallout allowed the player freedom as to how they wished to play the game, Arcanum takes that freedom and doubles it: there are more options to make a more varied character, more combat options, and even the way combat is conducted can be changed: alternated between classic turn-based, and that real-time that we all know and love.

The game does has one weakness to note. At one early point in the game, there is a very difficult dungeon that every character has to go through. Basic Melee and mage characters can pass through the dungeon with varying levels of difficulty but playthroughs that focus on charisma, persuasion and intelligence, will have to literally cheese through the dungeon, running past all the enemies to reach the end. 

This is, however, only one exception: pass this point, the majority of Arcanum is a game that can be played in a myriad of ways. Want to go full pacifist? Just max out charisma, persuasion and beauty, and focus on diplomacy, and picking the ideal dialogue options, literally avoiding as many fights as possible. Want to play as an inventor with a robot army? Yes that is possible. What about a gentleman mage with a small private army? Also possible. And, to those in the know, you can also play as a corrupt mage that permanently mind controls certain individuals, and amasses a private team of specialized minions to defeat really strong foes.

But that is just gameplay. What about story options? Arcanum is still filled with all kind of choices. You can be the normal goodie two shoes, and do what is right, act like a normal person, ask the right questions, and be hailed as a hero. Or, you  can be a complete sonofabitch, kill your enemies and, loot their personal belongings for clues on where to go next. Or, if you are a dastardly necromancer, you can raise the spirits of the enemies you have slain, and interrogate them for information. Yes, you can do that. You can even follow a completely evil path of the game, follow through on it, and then, halfway through it, decide to go back on the alternate ‚Äúnormal‚Äùroute - and the game wills till acknowledge that you made both choices.

The game, of course, does have its flaws. It is imperfectly balanced, and, for tech warriors, a certain overpowered weapon can be available to the player far earlier in the game. Additionally, while there are a number of varied technological schematics, and colleges that the player can learn, not all of them will seem relevant to a munchkin playthrough, and thus feel more novel, a challenge for more experienced players to try a playthrough with these weaker colleges. The same applies to magic. And of course, for a game that is now nearly two decades old, it has not been optimized for new computers - certain options have to be undertaken to play the game on modern systems.

But. and for those that can look past the game for its flaws, Arcanum presents a lot of options for the gamer that seeks as much choice as possible. Its world is vibrant and alive, perhaps even more so than Fallout, as it does not exist in the post-apocalypse. Its world, while experiencing an Industrial Revolution, still feels like it is in its prime. The main quest of the game is engaging, and, on top of the main quest, there is a whole bevy of side quests and detours that the player can pursue. The more adventurous can find some really interesting items, including a certain, legendary kungfu throwing weapon. The characters the player can be meet are all varied, even the annoying Virgil, the first character the player encounters. And, assuming one maxes out charisma and persuasion, there is the option to add on fairly incongruous members to the party.

All in all, Arcanum is a forgotten gem. It is sad that Troika did not manage to make the planned sequel to Arcanum that made use of the HL2 engine, but, just as Interplay‚Äôs Fallout has been acquired, and revived, by Bethesda, there might be hope that Arcanum could be revived into a sequel. And, even if such a sequel is a complete travesty, the original will always exist, a relic of potential.

EDIT: Having played Arcanum on Gog.com and with a physical version and, those versions of the game require tweaks in order to run it on Windows 10. Booted up my Steam version of Arcanum for the sake of this review, and was pleasantly surprised to find that it starts naturally without any problems. If you love RPGs with multiple paths, endings, and where the actions that you do early in the game will affect later progress, get this game. It‚Äôs worth it.

This game is just so much fun, I've put in a lot more hours than shown on Steam (I repurchased on here, after misplacing the CD copy I own).
Character creation alone is worth the price of admission, there are are a lot of options available to you, not just in the race and how you lay out your stats/skills, but also in the special background than can have a minimal or massive impact on how your playthrough goes.

I really like the distinction the game makes for conversations based on your characters intelligence level, and the multiple options in how to complete all the various quests that come your way.

This is one of the few CRPGs of the late 90s/early 2000s I had missed when it came out so I picked it up in late 2016 and got absolutely lost in it for a few weeks. It takes a bit of behind the scenes maintenance to get running properly (you'll find the unofficial patches and HD mods fairly easily) but it's worth the effort.

It's not necessarily a gripping story with memorable characters like Baldur's Gate, Fallout or Torment, but the gameplay systems in place, the crafting and exploration/world design make up for it in my opinion.

It's definitely a classic and I'd recommend it to people that are into old school RPGs and steampunk

This is the best Isometric RPG I have ever played.
It has a massive variety of content and fantastic story, level design, art direction and world building. This game is very dense and feels very real and lived in at times.
The game allows you to choose between Turn Based and Real Time combat, one of which is useful for situations that are moderately difficult and above, and the other is fantastic for when you're level 30 but you decided to do a rat killing quest that you picked up 20 levels earlier. And both options can be exchanged with a simple press of the spacebar.
If you've played Fallout 1 and or 2 and enjoyed it. You absolutely must have this game. It's better than either of those in my opinion. It surpasses Fallout 2 in terms of content, and beats out Fallout 1 in terms of story and writing.
You should definitely get the unofficial patches before playing this game, but once those patches are in then the game is far more stable and smooth than either of the classic Fallouts. I've put about 32 hours into my second character attempt and finally beat the game. I've missed out on a ton of content apparently as I found out from the ending sequence which was akin to the one you get in Fallout where it shows the fate of all the major factions. So there is still plenty for me to revisit and discover on a second full play through.
The sheer amount of skills and professions and schools of magic alone makes the game worth playing. It's all very well thought out and works wonderfully together. I was amazed from begining to end. I'm hoping they will never make a sequel or that no one *cough* BETHESDA *cough* will ever try to ruin this games world with a soulless cashin like they did with the Fallout series.
Like Fallout with magic and steampunk.

I liked the interesting story and the skill trees.  It's a good game even though the graphics are extremely outdated and map travel is pretty slow.  The major disappointment was when my character maxed out his level-ups only half-way through the game.  There's a mod that is supposed to fix that problem, but I haven't been back to the game since then.  I didn't really feel like replaying the whole thing because of the old graphics, but I enjoyed it even though I never finished it.  Recommended assuming you get the mods before you start playing.

Arcanum is a classic RPG in vein of Fallout or Dragon Age. You have a single character and some other characters join you. It looks like open world game but there aren't so many locations and dungeons, but each one unique and covered with some sort of quest. There are lot of those and they usually have varying outcomes.

The game has a very unique world, the main theme is industrial revolution happening in a typical fantasy world. There are many ways to develop your character but if you chose magic or technology then you'll have to go all the way for the best effect. There are lots of dialogue in the game and it's often important, only few characters have voice over. The best thing about this game is music and atmosphere: it's a really appealing take on Victorian fantasy. Novel-like dialogue adds to it.

Sadly the combat in this game isn't very good. You can switch between turn-based and real-time combat. The good idea would be to use turn-based combat in serious battles, you should also raise your main combat skill early to not have constant critical misses. The game allows for a lots of freedom - classic "kill everyone" challenge is certainly possible, as well as being pacifist, or never use magic and so on.

This game has dwarves with guns, elves with necromancy, half-orcs being exploited as a cheap labour in factories, human entrepreneurs changing the economy of the world, archaeologists excavating remains of dragons, greedy gnomes conspiring in their secret societies. It also has the best city in any RPG - Tarant. It's huge, interconnected and believable. Sadly the game may feature too little reactivity and depth for modern standards - while some NPCs go home to sleep most just stand there. Certain playstyles are much better than others: traditional melee fighters is better than anyone, guns are underpowered, mages are only great in late game, throwing is useless. It's an old school RPG system where the game allows you to create any character you want but the world has very specific challenges; being a great gambler would help you in a couple of quests and will solve your money problem but it's more of a self-imposed challenge to learn Gamble instead of fighting skills. Still the game is not that hard and you can get several companions so you can complete the game as any type of character.

I recommend using Multiverse Edition to get widescreen and some fixes. Don't get too greedy with the resolution, everything will be too small if you try more than 1600x900.

This is a wonderful game that was overlooked when released and fell into the dustbin of gaming history.

First off you create your character with all sorts of "perks" and backgrounds which are quite humorous. Just putting together your character is loads of fun. 

The world you visit is very intersting and quite large, like the JRPG's of that time aka Final Fantasy. The combat system is sort-of DND, turn based, with magical vs technological weapons & the writing is decent in a sort of tongue-and-cheek play on Victorian England. You also get to make various choices which will affect the world, summed up in a final epilogue after you defeat the big bad guy. 

I haven't had any issues with the game apart from the native resolution which either runs in a window or is haphazardly stretched to fit my 21:9 monitor. So if you have an ultrawide that is one thing to consider.

If you liked older RPGs such as Septerra Core and Baldur's Gate you will probably like this too.

AFTER you download the respective patches, this game is a gem. I have replayed 10+ times and always discover new things. The customization on this game is something lacking in today's rpg's. My favourite videogame, absolutely recommended.  

- Wonderfully written dialogues
- A coherent and deep as hell ecosystem of phylosophical positions, cultures, social dynamics, history...
- Potentially an infinite replayabiity thanks to the combinatory system of skills, race, gender, background history...
- Decisions actually causes entertaining consequencies, thousands of decisions
- Vast explorable open-world
- Film, books and every kind of cultural referencies hidden here and there
- Beautifully modeled isometric steampunk artworks
- The soundtrack. Man,  Ben Houge made a pure masterpiece. 

Plus, it's one of the most complex and original storyline eva made, keep your the witcher 3 and it's  photorealistic repetitive questlines hahaha

 Jokes apart, it's a classic piece for nostalgic buddies like me, and in order to be appreciated requires some patience and forgiveness because from the gameplay experience /  graphic point of view it's a sweet poor 2001 grandma. Not pure adrenaline, but slowly appreciable.

 I still love it after all these years and bought it again to feel nostalgic and say thanks to the developers.  (It required a DOUBLE CD version at the timeto install and play haha)

Now the tweaks.
On windows 10 you may need to make some adjustments to play it properly but after that it will works fine also in 4K:
Just download the "arcanum unofficial patch" (google it or here is the link https://terra-arcanum.com/drog/uap.html) It solves every compatibility issues and adds many cool features!

If that doesn't work just try this old workaround:

if you go to C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Arcanum You'll find a file called "SierraLauncher.ini" 
Open it as a text file and replace it with this:

[Launcher]
Name=Arcanum
NumButtons=1
GameManual=Manual.pdf

Game1Name=Game
Game1Prog=other
Game1Path=Arcanum\
Game1Exe=Arcanum.exe
Game1Cmd= -no3d -doublebuffer


Actually you modify two options in the Game1Cmd part: you activate "no3d" and "doublebuffer" options. 

Someone also suggests to delete the "ddraw.dll" file located in C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Arcanum\Arcanum, and replace it with 
another one that you can easily find online, plus a file called "wined3d.dll.

Online you can also find a level Cap remover (maximum level otherwise is 50)
and some resolution modifiers to play it on 16/9 res.

Thank you for your time if you read til here, and let me know how it goes ;D

I just finished the game, and I'm going to give it a positive review. However, this game does have some technical problems. Many times while I was playing it got very slow and laggy and I had to restart the game to fix it. It got quite annoying after playing for a while. If you can get past the technical issues, the game itself is very good. Arcanum is a large world with plenty to do. There is quite a lot of options in character customization and many companion characters that you can get to join your party in your travels. One of the best things about this game is the dialogue. Some of it is very funny and you can be a huge smartass to people at times, which I enjoyed to do. All in all, the game is fun but the technical issues can frustrate you. Keep that in mind before you start playing.

Old:
I would love to recommend this game but I can't in good conscience because it doesn't actually run very well on new computers. I tried doing several fixes but never really had any luck, would love to see a patch that actually makes it playable.

New Edit:
After performing a fix found in the Steam Guides the game runs great on Windows 10 and is incredible. Highly recommended if it works for you. The game is dated so there are some QOL things from newer CRPGS that won't be there, but the writing, the world, and character building are all top notch.

This is a great classic game.  But I have tried the fixes, things like the -no3d and the uofficial patch and it still only runs sometimes.  It also still has super lag.  If you have a newer kick ass computer then it runs horribly.  I am trying to run it on my less than one year old top of the line Alienware and it is just crap.  If they fixed this it would be a great review, however I am tired of trying everything and everything to make this game better.  I, as a consumer, shouldn't have to have this many issues.

"I'm steampunk now."- Jordan Peele, after playing this game

Pros:
+ Characters, quests, and the setting in general are engaging and well thought-out.
+ [spoiler]The interplay between magic and technology[/spoiler] is integrated into the mechanics in an enjoyable way.
+ Unlike other CRPGs made by this dev team, different character builds (technology, magic, stealth, gunplay, etc.) are pretty well-balanced; a [i]lot[/i] of different approaches are viable.
+ Any RPG that lets you play a dwarf gets points in my book.
+ Exploration is rewarded; besides barrels of loot, exploring that little side path will often lead you to an interesting sidequest.
+ This game does a better job than some others I've played of keeping track of quests and rumors.
+ Theoretically, local co-op is possible via LAN, if you can get together a bunch of nerds who would rather set up a switch than just play some shitty steampunk homebrew on roll20.

Cons:
- Windows 10 no longer directly supports the type of graphics card this game was built for; consequently, it lags a lot for a game that, on paper, should be about as resource intensive as a powerpoint slideshow. 
- The steam download doesn't include the world editor, which is pretty much the main draw of multiplayer. 
- The auto level-up mechanic is the real hard mode, because it'll blow your points on useless health and fatigue upgrades.

Garbage...utter crap.

I wanted to like this game. It sounded intriguing. Player reviews ramped it up. So I buy it, start it. My sad, 84 minute epic is as follows:

-Ship crashes
-Search wreckage for items
-Meet dude who will most likely be my lead into the story
-Explore, get attacked by wolves (or something similar)
-Try to fight back. Attacks NEVER hit, not even once.
-Get dead, try over...multiple times
-Then, main quest dude gets killed, and I get killed again, because I can't HIT ANYTHING.
Get fed up with crap game, chalk it up to a complete waste of time, uninstall, and move along, thankful that I only paid a meager sum for this piece of crap.

Now I get that I probably did something wrong in building my character. But if that's the case, then the damn game is too limited in scope if it's forcing me to build a certain way to play the game. It sounds like it has a great story, but sadly I'll have to pass, because that shit beginning has left a sour taste in my mouth, and I just can't be bothered with it anymore. If I could uninstall it from my steam library, I would.

May you have better luck than me if you buy this thing. But I can't recommend it.

At this point i've only played 20 hours of it, but i have atleast scraped the bottom of the barrel on this one.

Arcanum is a really old-school game from a time where walkthroughs weren't readily available as it is now, but ive tried playing the game without it and found out that i love it.

It has some resemblence of diablo like game, but it has more like a Dungeon and Dragons kind of wibe when it comes to combat, where everything has a "chance" to happen. Like everything from healing to hitting your opponent or the gun you're using exploding in your hand.

This game doesn't hold your hand, you have to figure out everything on your own, which i love about this game. There is alot of try, die, try and survive aspects, so you have to save everytime you are going to  do something at all.

From what i've played i would highly recommend this game from a modern gamer standpoint. Even tho i did start with old-school games like this one, i didn't really "understand" games until i grew older.

Just give it a try, and atleast learn the gist of what the stats means. You'll be fine ;)

I played Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura around it's initial release and I enjoyed it as much then as I do now.  For it's time, Arcanum was a great puzzle game. I still get lost in the nostalgia and the story line keeps me interested. I learn something new each time I play. I feel it is still a great strategy game but today's computers make it a bit glitchy. I hardly know anything about computer specs, but I cannot run it with Window's 10, but I CAN run it smoothly with XP.  Arcanum is enjoyable and worth your time. But be open and patient with the graphics and such as the game was not designed for today's computers.

10/10

Well, I know this is gonna garner hate, but it's about time I said something.

Older games like Arcanum may be lauded as underrated forgotten classics, which it may well be, but I don't think I'll ever find out personally. The reason for this is that the simple acting of moving, looting, and doing basic rpg things in this game are a pain in the ass.

This along with System Shock 2 are the few games under my "i believe you when you tell me it's a classic", but I'll never finish it category. For having the basic sin of be almost anti-player friendly. In fallout you can move across a map quickly and easily, even in Baldur's gate gate and IWD with a party of six, you can manage without much trouble. In Arcanum just looting around the airship is a lesson in tedium.

So, that's about it. There's a reasons some forgotten classics remained that way, like a really pretty dress from 1925 with awkward zippers that like two people know how to correctly fit into.

Update! 2/3/19 - If you install the unofficial patch and the high res patch, then open the .exe in windowed mode (as administrator) it seems to run smoothly. This amazing game was previously unplayable in fullscreen but works like a charm in windowed mode. It's a shame this game has been long abandoned because a hotfix to make it run in a windowed mode (or better yet full screen windowed mode) would be amazing for this. It takes some effort to set up, but if it is worth it if you do!

I will keep my post negative because it seems to be helpful, but I completely endorse this game with the aforementioned fix to optimize it.

Original post:
While the gameplay is pretty fantastic it simply is not designed to run on Windows 10. I've spent a lot of time trying to optimize the game but after a few minutes it will almost definitely slow down on you to the point where it is unplayable. Every few minutes will require a fresh restart.

It cannot be run in a high priority mode without destroying the graphics. I even tried setting up short cuts to run it in on high with no luck. It uses an ancient version of direct X that simply doesn't work as well on Windows as you'd expect.

This definitely needs a reboot though. The game is so much fun.

If you love the classic Fallout games, you have to try this one out. Just like Fallout, this game focuses on role playing, character development and exploration. No cutscenes, no long-winded dialogs - it's as core as you can get, and it's brilliant.

without exaggeration this is one of the best rpgs ever made. it has a depth and breadth not found in modern roleplaying games with a focus on creative problem solving.

even though the game is over a decade old it has still aged well and should still be accessible to people who didn't live in the golden age of crpgs.

if you do buy it make sure to read the manual because it is a gem and there is a nice bread recipe in it.
best game of 2001 imo

I was having trouble getting this to run on my PC due to how old the game is, but when I moved it to my Texas Instruments TI-84 Graphing Calculator it actually worked quite well. I did wind up failing Geometry as a result.
love this game

So this game is absolutely awesome so far. There is a continent full of cities to explore. I'm only in the second city, and having spent a few hours just here, I realized this game is huge. The quests are great, the story is great, the combat is great, and the customization is great.

The only issues I had were of the technical nature, it being an old game. It runs okay, sometimes it slows down a bit. When I downloaded a widescreen high res patch it slowed down a lot, but there is a good looking steam guide on how to speed up the game running slow on modern machines that I will try. Save early and often and you should be fine.

Also the save game files are stored in the game's directory folder, not Documents like new games are, so if you reinstall Windows make sure you backup the right folder -- I learned this the hard way but only about 5 hours in thankfully.

If any game deserves a remake it's this game. It's openworld, with a fantastic story line. It's and old school RPG which means it doesn't hold your hand. You are allowed to roam almost anywhere and you can progress the story line in my directions. It's a classic masterpiece. Old school RPGers will appreicate this game.

It's easy to state if a game is terrible, bad, decent, good, or outright genius - much of this will be depending on the opinion of the player on certain types of games.

Let's instead state the issues the game has - and in particular, after you also install the bug-fitched patch.

List of issues:
1: Beauty stat is almost useless. In a game where a lot of possibilities exist, this one could have somehow been given a little more importance, or otherwise at least some extra gameplay options (quests that require high beauty for example).
2: Some spells will pretty much never be used, and are pointless to learn, aside from sometimes you needing them to reach higher in a school of magic.
3: Most follower characters are not voiced - a few key ones are, furtinately - but it could have been easy to have added this for the other roughly 15-20 followers that are now left voiceless.

Yeah... that's pretty much it.

Greatest things on this game though, and I think anyone would agree there:

1: Storyline is awesome, with lots of pun in it too (Gilbert Bates and his competitor who will never invent anything decent, Cedric Appleby both stand out for just char names alone).
2: This game has one of the best and most difficult side-quests of any game ever (Gods quest, or blessing from the gods quest... just try doing this one without looking up online how exactly to do it... will take you ages to figure out and then it STILL would be worth it :))
3: The "discrimination" of races in between eachother is a genius move on how it was implemented.


It's one of my favorite games from years and years ago, and Im happy to see it on Steam. Added it simply because of nostalgia, but this game is more than just that - it really is one of the best games in its genre of all time.

I invite anyone to try it if they have never done so - do install the patch, but don't read up on anything else about it online that provides spoilers about the story or about the quests... let it be as interesting to you as it can possibly be.

Warning: This game needs an unofficial patch and numerous Windows compatibility tweaks to work.  Nothing too intensive, but it's worth it because the end result is magnificent.  Arcanum is a huge open world fantasy and "steampunk" RPG, made by the same brilliant minds who brought us Fallout and Fallout 2.  The amount of role-playing is even comparable to Fallout 2, which has the most of any video game.  

Play as a Human, Dwarf, Elf, Half-Elf, Orc, Half-Orc, Half-Ogre, Gnome, or Halfling.  Use the wonderful classless stat/rule system to build a unique character, defining eight different physical and mental attributes, and choosing either magic or technology or even both (although balance is really geared toward just one or the other). Or perhaps neither? Focus on several different magic schools, or become an expert fighter and maybe smith, or a master archer, or a gunslinger, or an alchemist, or a bomb maker, or a chemical weapons genius, or an electrical or mechanical wizard, or a thief, the choice is yours.

If your Intelligence is too low, you won't be able to speak properly (the entire game is rewritten), people will look down on you and not give you the same opportunities they would a normal person, and you won't ever have any spellcasting ability or technological mastery.  

This game features 16 spell colleges and 5 spells in each for a total of 80 spells, as well as 8 technological disciplines and 7 degrees (each bringing a unique recipe) for each.  4 combat skills, 4 thieving skills, 4 social skills, 4 tech skills.  

A very in-depth, full fledged RPG with a massive 190 page manual.  The rule system is so good, so complete that it seems like it stems from a pen and paper RPG but it doesn't. The same applies to Fallout, these developers (formerly Interplay/Black Isle Studios, before Troika) were just the best at making video game RPGs.

The world building is also so well written that one wouldn't think it is an original video game universe, but it is.  So much detail packed into every town and city, every culture, and all of it is explored better than today's RPGs even dream of (they lack the ambition).  This is a story driven RPG, and the story is intriguing from the start.  It is a story wrapped in thematic material with some social commentary, carefully examining and showing us the dangers and benefits of technological revolution from multiple perspectives.  Characters are written with greater attention to detail than most games by far, although it is not at the very top tier in this regard either.

Arcanum has some of the most brilliant quest design you will find in any RPG.  Again, the level of artistic vision and creativity it exhibits in this regard is not seen in modern RPGs.  No hand holding, your journal (quest log section that is) is written from the perspective of the character, not a narrator or godlike figure.  It doesn't tell you more than you can possibly know, so it tells you what to do but not exactly how to do it.  And if your intelligence is too low, your journal/log will show it.

My favorite example of this is the quest called "Horror Among the Dark Elves" which is an authentic Lovecraftian short story.  As a fan of Lovecraft, the presence of such a quest took me utterly by surprise.  It begins with a book which you find in the game, a book detailing an investigation into disturbing events, gradually becoming more unnerving as you read it.  To continue the quest, you must follow up on leads mentioned in the book; the game doesn't explicitly tell you this, you must use your own common sense and intuition which is now a forbidden approach to mainstream game design.  Some of those leads are names of people, places, and more.  You can ask around, ask people who might have more knowledge than common civilians like the authorities or innkeepers.  Better yet, check the Hall of Records in Tarant.  The point is, you conduct your own logical, authentic investigation into matters, rather than just following an objective marker to a location and killing everything there.  Quest design in Arcanum involves more than just combat, and more than just dialogue too, and they are rewarding for what they add to the story thematically.

Not every quest is excellent of course.  Some side quests involve overly helpless and brainless characters, like most other games and movies.  But the amount of great quests outweighs the amount of generic ones by far.

Arcanum lets you choose real time or turn-based combat.  Since it is an isometric 2.5D game, turn-based is the best choice I think, it lacks the fluidity and precision for real-time.  The camera can interfere with combat at times, all the more reason to go with turn-based.  Combat can range from typical sword and shield or axe and shield melee battles, or twin daggers with stealth, or large two handed melee weapons, to flintlock pistols, revolvers, repeating rifles, even a flamethrower and grenade launcher, to wild technological gizmos like electric staves and clockwork spiders and so much more.  Then there are the 80 spells of course, few of them being useless.  The use of stealth in combat can be greatly improved however, D&D video games do this much better.

You can actually kill anyone and everyone in the game, at will, and it has massive consequences for such. And you can revive them with necromancy.  You may have noticed that much of what I said; the racial variety and the open world free roaming, resembles The Elder Scrolls to some extent.  But unlike The Elder Scrolls, Arcanum has role-playing depth.  It actually REACTS to what you do in realistic ways, it reacts to your character build.  You will encounter racism or favoritism.  If you are a technological expert, you will come into conflict with mages, and vice versa.  So many different ways this game responds, so much dialogue variety, they do not make such great RPGs anymore sadly.

The last portion of the game, after the point of no return, is a disappointment.  This includes the ending.  Troika built up such a grand tale to the point where they were not able to write a satisfying conclusion in the time they were given.  But that's only the last hour of the game or so, at least.  And since people love it so much, any significant action you commit (ones that affect communities but many others) anywhere throughout the game provides a unique ending slide.

For the maximum UK experience, play this game and also watch Barry Lyndon.

How unfortunate this game wasn't optimized for better gameplay. While this was one of my all-time favorite rpgs of the time, especially when most games then were very dry and didn't have much depth - this was one that stuck out. While sure it was buggy, there were so many different things you could do on your adventure that rolling a new character was almost more fun than actually reaching the end with one.

Running with a gaming laptop (GTX1060 and 32gb ram), the game is chopping, lagging, there is no decent point of framerates that don't jump around or get stuck randomly, and it looks ridiculous in its resolution versus my monitor's. This is still a great game, I just wish I had a slower computer to play it on so that it runs the way it did way back in the day.

Oh well, still felt like I had to buy it again, because it was such a great in its day.

Up there with the best of them.

I'd BG 1 and 2 ( as  a single game experience)
Fallout 2
and this, Arcanum,  are all equally amazing.

This is one of my favorite games. As soon as I saw it on steam I bought it again. This game does not have the greatest game play, even for as old as it is. The Graphics arn't great either. But I love the story, the amount of fun I've had playing this game can't be expressed properly. The story is great, and the voice acting is pretty good as well. The magic and tech systems, I'm not a huge fan of. But I really like how they handled charisma and beauty as charactaristcs. Honestly it may be nestalgia or Bias, but I'd give this game a 10/10.

I love this game. This game is worth your time if you like good writing, a well-developed world, and interesting characters.

But I'm going to preface this review with a caveat: You absolutely NEED to install unofficial patches and content to make this a worthwhile game. Troika Games was known for their expansive, well-written games, but eventually went out of business because they were so buggy. You need unofficial patches and mods to make this game the game it could be.

When you do install those? It's a narrative experience like no other. The combat leaves much to be desired, but that's not why you should be playing. You should be playing for the truly open-world experience and clever, interesting dialog.

You will never see everything in this game. It's just not possible without hundreds upon hundreds of hours. But it is worth your time. Play it, please. You won't regret it.

[h1] ‚ÄúHere lies Charles. Had six guns, needed seven. Now he resides in heaven.‚Äù [/h1]

Arcanum represents a role-playing game (RPG) developed by the company Troika Games and published by the company Activision. Troika Games is also responsible for the creation of Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Bloodlines. 

[i] Pro & contra: [/i]

+ Creative concept of a RPG world where followers of magic or technology are fighting against each other for supremacy. It tends to encourage spontaneous role-playing by providing entertaining dialogue options, depending on the race and character statistics, e.g. amount of followers is limited by charisma.

+ Well done manual gives insights regarding gameplay mechanics, and supports immersion into the world of Arcanum.   

o Community patch is recommended, in order to fix some bugs that are not covered by the last official patch. Furthermore, there are some useful Steam guides improving the gameplay, e.g. preventing the occasional slowdowns in cities.

- Without additional patching and customization some gameplay aspects will be rather frustrating. Lack of Interaction between the members of the group. Musical background and sounds are repetitive.

[i] Summary: [/i]

Arcanum has a good and solid gameplay that is held back from being great by various issues. It is directed at old school gamers, who prefer text-based RPGs and are willing to tweak the game with different fan-made patches.  

Recommended for hardcore RPG players. 

[i] Achievements: [/i]

This game has no Steam achievements.
