/TLDR: So is Arcanum a good game? No absolutely not! The gameplay is mostly dusty and old and had a lot of faults even when it came out, BUT: If you can overlook such faults or live with them about 40-100 hours then you can experience a very special handcrafted high-fantasy/steampunk-World with an elaborately told story!
But should you?
Short answer is: No, unless you are an avid reader and the story and atmosphere is atleast two to four times more important to you than gameplay, graphics and a bugfree experience. This game is really just for hardcore classic-isometric-rpg-gamefans(from the 90ties) or bookworms with thick nerves.

Still a better ending than Mass Effect 3! :TLDR/

The game takes itself pretty serious but if you really delve into it you see the budget constraints in every corner, even in areas of story and atmosphere.
-most companions aren't really fleshed out and only a couple have a quest according to them which you could miss doing because you didn't know you had to take that special char with you(but it gives you a reason to play it again, which you shouldn't).
-most subquests are pretty well written but rather short. There are only a handful that take you to more than 1 or 2 locations aside from the mainquestline(which is pretty good).
+The newspaper system is pretty unique and surprisingly well integrated in the game! Why don't we have this in other titles as well?!?
+The writing is superb in almost all aspects! The best part is that even your journal depends on the type of character you have, as in dumb or inteligent).
-The journal and interface are pretty but not handy, there are not enough shortkeys to actions, the journal is a mess to handle and without a manual you can't even look it up on the pc because alt-tabbing doesn't work with the graphicsengine.
-The combat is a joke and either unbeatable or hilariously easy if you don't mind that many companions die in many situations because there is no NPC-AI that works in this game, just play on easy. Even Baldur's Gate had a better combat system(which was horrible).
+Character creation is for one very easy and also very versatile(without a good avatar-customization).
+Choices are mostly open and great incorporated and there are many secrets to uncover, but sadly you are discouraged because of the gameplay.

Protips: 
-Install the Unofficial Patch
-Install the Levelcap remover(don't forget to move a file to arcanums folder, or you get a crash every time you reach level 50/51)
-don't alt-tab or try using windowed mode
-Learn Teleport even if you're a Technofan
-Save alot and look up a guide after you have done a quest to find out if you missed something important which could brake another quest or if you didn't like your choice.
-All Inns have safecontainers afaik. Inventory is a hassle.
-Search for Virgil Cheat

You need the unofficial patch the avoid a lot of buggs, but Arcanum might be one of the few Deeply-flawed masterpieces in gaming. I used to play this a long time ago when it came out on CD-ROM. It's a fantastic game with a unique setting. It has a complex and in-depth story. Its style can easily be compared to the original 2 Fallouts or Baldur's Gate. Lots of choices, lots of different paths to take and lots of way to get yourself into trouble as well. Save often, and having multiple save files is not a bad idea because if things go south on you the game can be a bit unforgiving but it's still a blast to play. 

The character development has tons of different options from how you initially create your character and how you choose to develop them as the game progresses. You will need to make a choice between being technology or magic oriented. It is possible to try a combo of the two, but I never had a ton of success with that others may be able to tell you better formulas for combining them.

Bottom line: If you enjoyed the original Baldur's Gate and/or the original 2 Fallouts, there is a good chance you will like this. It runs in the same 3rd person style RPG and you pick up party members along the way. Just keep in mind that it is not the type of game you want to rush through as making fast, rash decisions can get you into trouble if you choose poorly; besides, there is so much in the game to explore. I definitely recommend this if you have an affinity for the older generation games and the good old days when graphics weren't everything and they could compensate for the graphics with amazing content and story!

[b]NOTE:[/b] I recommend downloading the fan patch and playing the game using turn-based combat for the best experience. 

Arcanum has incredibly reactive world, where technology and magic oppose each other. It features a great character creation system, and progression system. You are not locked into a role, but put your points towards skills and attributes you want to increase such as Firearms, Melee, Speech, Dexterity, etc. Not only might decisions during character creation differ how you play, it will change how you are treated by the world. 

Play a mage? Well, now you can no longer ride the train and you will have difficulty healing more technology-inclined party members. 
Play a low-intelligence character? Everyone will treat you like an idiot, and you will be granted some amusing dialogue and journal updates. 
Play a highly charismatic character? Avoid combat encounters, or if enganged in combat, have your army of followers murder everything as they'll all love you!

You won't be able to experience everything in one playthrough as quests (and their solutions) and followers, among other things, can differ due to your decisions, which is one of the great things about the game. You play a role, and in that role, it has consequences which shape the experience of your playthrough. This allows for a great amount of replayability.

This also enhances the questing experience. While a technological inclined individual might need to follow the footsteps of a murder mystery, if you're a necromancer...just summon his spirit and ask him! The game encourages you to search for possible alternate solutions.

Arcanum also features a soundtrack that is only a string quartet, and it is magnificent. Very melancholic and enhances the adventure.

I personally enjoyed the combat, but there are times where some dungeons drag on and overstay there welcome turning it into a slog. Also, the game has some balancing issues where some builds are flat out superior. 

Overall, I highly recommend Arcanum. It really is truely a unique experience and probably my favorite RPG ever.

This gem is too much underrated. I've never seen game with such great storytelling and atmosphere.
And as a bonus you have steampunk setting which is so rare. Yes, there are games out there with bits and pieces of "steampunkish" visuals. But what other game throws you into the middle of industrial revolution, with quest directly touching the question of coexistence of nature and technology?
Arcanum doesn't limit your path choices in any way. Yo can play mage (destroying enemies with sole sight, traveling among flock of familiars), gun wielding technologist (in steampowered armor with mechanical companions) or anything between. What else do you need.
In character creation you can choose from half-dozen races with tens of different backgrounds which are often mutually exclusive and can completely change the way you experience this wast world.
So why is this game pretty much forgotten? Answer may be hidden in problems it has.
Levels gaining is unbalanced. Depending on your carrier choice you can rocket to the level cap long before half of game or struggle to gain much needed skills.
Related problem is leveling of followers, they doesn't get any experience but level up with PC. If you recruit them too late, they have no chance to reach level cap. That wouldn't be problem, if you had control over their skill distribution - but alas, you don't. This underlines the lack of control over them which is painfully evident especially in combat.
Another big problem may lay in confusing quests. You often can't say what approach is right. Rude answer in one dialog will lead only to escalation to violence, another time it is only way to access much needed options. Only way to find out is Save&Load which somebody may find frustrating. And there are few quest which end without any satisfaction. (What you looked for is revealed as part of bigger scheme - but there is no continuation programmed in for it.)

Is this game really so broken?
If you like straightforward story, where you always can predict what outcome will come from your actions, Arcanum may let you frustrated. But if you like exploring every possibility, and repeating game over and over with new characters to find various endings Arcanum won't let you down.

This is my second attempt at playing Arcanum; the first being about 14-15 years back at Gamestop on a disc copy. I got several hours in and just wasn't feeling it, but got it in a bundle on Steam recently and figured I'd give it another go. Perhaps I simply misjudged it back then when I tired of it? Here are my thoughts, taking into consideration my original efforts and my more recent, brief time with the game.

[h1]Graphics/Art Style[/h1]
Although some of the backgrounds look nice, virtually everything else (the characters/NPCs, items, enemies, user interface, "movies" and enemies) looked very unattractive to me. As an RPG made in the west in that era, this means the game inevitably went for realism in its appearance over art style. I would dare say that except for when anything very steampunk-y is on screen, the game feels quite lacking in visual artistic value. When you're going through a steampunk-meets-fantasy world, you expect some cool visuals and memorable locations, but I rarely encountered anything along those lines, in my opinion. The game doesn't look terrible, but it's just a bit drab and the user interface felt a bit cluttered for me.

[h1]Story/Characters/Lore[/h1]
Despite having played for a good 8 hours or so on the disc version and for a little bit on the Steam version, the story never grabbed me, nor can I even begin to remember it. Normally, plots come rushing back to me when I see a little bit of them again, but not with this one, as its start was uninteresting to me, nor was it fun. That said, I can overlook a story that isn't amazing if the characters are really likable or the lore/setting intrigue me. For instance, Vampire - The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a game this same developer put out 3 years after Arcanum. VtM Bloodlines is my favorite game, but quite frankly, I don't think its story is all that great. However, its cast of characters were more enjoyable for me than any other game I can think of, and the lore enriched everything while the setting positively oozed atmosphere in the best of ways.

Arcanum, on the other hand, has no characters I remember from my original time playing, and no one I liked when I played again briefly more recently. A fantasy/steampunk setting sounds awesome but is woefully under-used in games, but Arcanum's setting never held any atmospheric weight for me. I feel they completely missed the mark on utilizing such a setting to make a game I could find fun and interesting. The only potential saving grace at that point would be phenomenal gameplay, which I will discuss later.

[h1]Locations & Map UI[/h1]
This segment is about both the actual areas you run around in, as well as the maps you can pull up (map user interface) to see where you are in an area. The outdoor areas you run around in are quite large, and will often let you run for a couple of minutes or so in any given direction off the edge of the relevant portions of the map. While it's nice to not get rudely yanked out of an area a la older Final Fantasy games when taking one step too far on the edge of town, having so much "dead space" on maps is an odd choice without any payoff, which only made exploration more unappealing for me when it's normally pretty fun.

What makes matters even worse is that these areas are devoid of anything to do aside from the occasional enemy to kill or one or two points of interest. Searching the map I started on, there is zeppelin wreckage with bodies to loot, but after walking away from that, I explored the map for a bit and about 90% of my time was spent just walking around in a bland area, not fighting, not getting items, not seeing anything neat or mysterious, not meeting characters, and just generally bored and quickly remembering why I never finished the game my first time with it. The map after it is a house with nothing around it, and the one after that is a town with several acres in different directions with nothing to do on them either. Also, to go to the world map, you can't fast travel from a safe/non-combat zone; rather, you have to go to one of these dead zones away from anything relevant, and then go to the world map to select the next area to visit.

Unless your game has high-speed transportation within each map to make up for all the dead space (a la Grand Theft Auto games), then you need to compact your maps the way games like Batman Arkham Asylum, VtM Bloodlines, Deus Ex Games, and others have done. While unrealistic to have so much content so tightly packed together, it makes for a fun experience and at the end of the day, it's a video game, and I believe fun should be top priority above all else.

The user interface of the map you pull up involves clicking destinations on the local map/area you're in, relative to your character. You can click up to three points, then tell your character to go and he/she will travel to them...unless even the slightest obstacle is in the way that you didn't see on the map, in which case your instructions for your character will not be followed. The map just feels clunky to me and lacking details that could be helpful. The entire map system did not appeal to me.

[h1]Spells[/h1]

There are 80 spells for those interested in using them, like I was, but many are either too situational to ever have much use, with a few decent buff spells and about 4 or 5 decent damage-dealing spells (only 9 spells in the game deal damage), and you'll typically spam one spell in an area, giving mages combat that is no more involved than the most basic of melee tank characters in RPGs. Just look at the Wizard in Diablo III to see useful and exciting spell variety.

[h1]Instruction Manual & In-Game Tool-Tips[/h1]
This game's manual lacks a table of contents, so I had to use the search option on the word "fatigue." 102 instances of it in the manual, which took forever and did not have the info I needed. The game and instruction manual does not have details about fatigue regeneration in them, so I had to resort to searching the Steam Forums to find the info I needed. 

A complicated RPG system is okay, as long as the info about the crucial attributes you have to choose between is available to you within the manual or the game itself, and that is not the case with a lot of things in this game. After reading the forum, I discovered that one of the mages I created, which need Fatigue to cast spells, would [i]never[/i] regenerate fatigue because one attribute (not the Fatigue one) was too low...but neither the game's tooltips nor its instruction manual tell you about this at all.

[h1]Real-Time Vs Turn-Based Gameplay[/h1]
This game is designed so you can play it in real-time or have it pause to go into turn-based combat. Unfortunately, it feels very much like this caused problems more than anything. When trying to navigate the world, that's where the zig-zagging movement comes from (hidden grids for the areas), and when fighting in real-time, combat feels too fast. I do recommend skimming other reviews for more about the problems with playing in either mode, because the game has problems either way you do it (i.e. there are slow enemies who are supposed to catch up to ranged players and hit them when turn-based, but you'll simply outrun/kite them and blast/shoot them without any threat in real-time. The developers really needed to spend more time on this game to have its combat feel right, in my opinion.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game undoubtedly has many fans, as the setting is something that sounds like I would love to explore it. I don't recall much about the music, but I do remember a couple of nice songs, and the olde English dialog has charm. However, I simply cannot get into this game as most everything in Arcanum disenchants me with the game. If you really want an atmospheric CRPG that's "old-school," then Fallout 2 or PlaneScape Torment are the way to go, in my opinion. They are games that are a few years older than Arcanum, but are better in virtually every regard, to me.

I played this game to bits back in the glory days of RPGs. It is a lesser known classic up there with Fallout 1,2, Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights. It has a very unique setting and the most beautiful soundtrack I've ever heard in any game. When I noticed that it is available on Steam I immediately bought it (even though I already have it on GoG and physical CD-ROM), it is that good. Arcanum.  Arcanum is a FANTASTIC title and should be sought out by players who enjoy Crpgs. Long story short, did you play Fallout 1 + 2 and really enjoy them, but haven't played Arcanum? Then get Arcanum NOW! Earliest memories of this game was back when I was around 12-13 years old, watching my sister and dad play it, and eventually myself. We each had our own saves and we poured HUNDREDS of hours, easily between the three of us, into this game.

The style of the game, dialogue, lore, the choices you can make, the freedom, and a world that has a growing rift between technology and magic (magick as its referred to) was just so fresh back in the day. A great "classless" leveling system allows you to create a character based on your playstyle, allowing you to progress through the game and interacting with npcs, the way YOU want to. Currently running an Evil Sorcerer (where as I was a goody Holy Knight who fancies a revolver as well) and NPCs react SO much differently than they did in my previous walkthrough, and some merchants comment my magical power...gunsmiths and armorers sometimes REFUSE to give me service, afraid I'm going to blow up their shop and stock! Even story quest NPCs, which some I ended up murdering for being so "out of place". Would that just end the story, NOPE, lets just say...that being a Sorcerer, I can "pull" them back for a bit and get what I need to progress through the story. 

Of course you have various side quests that can have various outcomes as well. I actually read a review stating that you have to "slowly" level to even do the most basic side quests. This claim is false. Yes there are side quests as well as the main story that can be harder to complete at a lower level, but thats how the game is...it gradually increases difficulty. The most "basic" side/main story quests can be completed at low levels...even lvl 1 which you won't be at for long anyway. 

Unfortunately, there are bugs present now given the game is being ran on modern systems, unless you're using a mircrowave pc given today's standards. There are some unofficial fan base patches that are MANDATORY for the game's successful launch on modern pcs. Look up Drog's Unofficial Arcanum Patch, as this is the one you need primarily. If you choose the run the game without mandatory patches, or fail to install them correctly, don't blame the game for having issues running on a modern pc and you being incapable. The game runs, as proven by my 40hrs logged. 

The combat honestly could've been better. Stiff animations and rather dull after awhile. Especially spell casting...you just stand there regardless of the spell. I do enjoy that they have the option for real time or turn base combat. Customization is "great", but visually...not so much. There isn't much depth for visual customization, but there is plenty of character customization.

I play a wide variety of games, but honestly, Arcanum has by far brought me the most enjoyment...solidifying the fact that a great game doesn't need amazing graphics, certain game modes, fuck ton of crazy features, etc etc. Arcanum has just...done it right for me. Sometimes people ask me for my favorite movie, which I answer without hesitation. As for game...I really haven't had an answer for it. Till I found this on Steam and RUSHED right to it, having played through it and just sparking up some really great memories. No other game has really brought me that kind of joy in a long time, if not, ever. The world is immersive and I easily see myself playing it on and off in the future. I finally decided that my favorite game is Arcanum. I actually save old PC boxes from back in the day, well I dug it out, and now have it placed on my wall shelf for display.

Despite some negatives, which are easily overlooked and minor, this game is remarkable for what it is and what it offers the player. Arcanum truely is a fantastic game which deserves a spot in your library

I always loved this second only to the origional Fallout and Baldurs Gate games. Now that players have patched it and fixed the bugs i think it might even be the best RPG ever made.

First, despite the lack of time recorded on the game I did finish the game. I couldn't get the game to run with the launcher, so I ran the game itself and that worked.
Second, it's not a bad game, but I had too many issues with the game. I didn't try any mods. The game has a lot of bugs and glitches and just lack of proper information. I picked a random character and found myself struggling to do anything at the beginning. You must slowly level up before you can even do the most basic of quests. It's hard to tell exactly what you're supposed to do on most quests. The log usually doesn't show any helpful information. You will have to google several things the first time you play the game. A lot of people seem to play the game a second time, probably because you can't actually figure out the game until you've finished the game. Even after finishing the game it is hard to figure out many things. Why does magic healing not work on a technologist, but a fireball does. The stats on weapons are often clear as mud. I wasted a lot of level up points to learn tech, so I could make stuff I'd just find anyway. I think 20 years in game time went by, but my character is still 20 years old and nothing changes with time. There are lots of other small issues I have with the game that I won't get into.
So finally to sum it all up, it's an okay game, lots of potential, but unless they remake the game I just can't recommend this one.

This is the Deus Ex of RPGs (insofar as Deus Ex is not really an RPG). I mean that comparison in a number of ways, including the negative ones: unimpressive (even at the time) graphics, and the unpatched (or even patched) bugginess. But more to the point, Arcanum is reminiscent of DE in terms of the sheer breadth and scope of its ambition, as well as the complexity and [i]honesty[/i] of its mechanics. 

Everything Arcanum does, it does [i]in the gameworld[/i], playing by its own established rules. If there's an item to be recovered for a quest, that item exists in the world, and you can steal it or smash open the container / person holding it, in lieu of any dialog options. If your reward for that quest is a different item, that item [i]also[/i] exists within the game world.  Whatever you trying to accomplish, you can accomplish "as intended" or whichever way you want to, within the rules of the game. 

Let's compare with a recent outstanding RPG - The Witcher 3. If a plague-ridden peasant begs the Witcher to kill him, and you select the "refuse" dialog option, that's it. That's the end of the quest, because you can't actually interact with non-hostile peasants if they don't want to speak to you. Swing your swords, throw bombs around, lure a terrifying monster to the village - everyone will cower briefly, then go about their day. The peasant "NPC" is just scenery - a bit of graphics and voice-acting provided with a few highly limited ways to interact with the gameworld.

But isn't that [i]all[/i] that NPCs ever are? What else could they possibly be? 

Well, they could be fully realized characters (mechanically, not in terms of writing), just as "real" to the game as you or your companions, as all NPCs in Arcanum are. You can steal their clothes and weapons, or give them armor and swords to turn them into warriors. You can dominate just about every NPC into joining your party and - since they are "real" to the game - every misbegotten random passerby can be leveled up and equipped into a blazing god of murder. Alternately, you can play dressup with them by stealing and planting clothes, or plant a poisonous item / stick of dynamite on them just for fun.

[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52_ZyndqeLI]NPCs will react[/url] to your characters race, stats, intelligence, magical / technological inclination, manner of dress,  being invisible, having a summon along... and more. On the other hand, the game features exactly two invulnerable NPCs, and you can finish the game by slaughtering every single person you meet without ever talking to more than then the handful of people who start a conversation on their own.

If you are playing an idiot, you won't just get the occasional "me stupid" dialog option - the entirety of your dialog and journal options will be idiotic "Hulk-speak" ([i]including journal entries for quests you can only undertake as an intelligent character![/i]). The difference between an elven mage, an idiotic half-ogre fighter or a dwarven technologist lies not just in a small number of different dialog choices or the exact flavor of pew-pew they unleash upon the enemy - each of the three is going to have a completely different gameplay experience. The game is just way too vast to experience all of it in one playthrough. Even if you go for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=818649577]mastery of all skills[/url] (a walkthrough already calculated to exploit game mechanics in order to see as much content as possible), you probably won't see more than 80% of what the game has to offer. 

It's really goddamned amazing, and I heartily recommend it.
It is a tragedy that such a great game was released very much undone and didn't get a continuation.

THIS IS AN OLD GAME! Be warned!! I recommend to do a quick Google after buying this game and install some essential mods such as the HD mod and community patch. You will need to do some configuring before this game is playable in this day and age, however it is WELL worth the wait.

PROS:
- Pretty decent story
- Amazing character customisability
- Item-size based inventory management
- Many secrets and side-quests to find
- Real attention to detail
- Freedom in style of play (real time or turn-based, being good/evil and magic/tech minded, almost everything you can imagine!)
- Multiplayer support
- A "quick-travel" kind of option
- Great writing and voice acting (especially for the time)

CONS:
- Even with the latest official and community patches installed, there are many bugs in the game (no "game-breaking" ones though)
- It is difficult to get started in the game; there isn't a tutorial, and due to the sheer customisability it's a bit of a learning curve to understand what works well (but a quick Google can help)
- It is an old game, so the "steam version" is basically unplayable on a modern computer

TLDR:
If you're in the market for a good RPG and you love the steampunk/magic kind of universe, and of course don't mind installing a few quick mods, then THIS GAME IS A MUST-BUY!
One of the best RPGs ever made and with possibly the coolest setting seen in any game. If you liked the classic Fallout games you'll probably love this game.
Great game if you can get it to run smoothly which is impossible. The game has a major memory leak and requires many patches and other work arounds to get it semi-playable up to a point.
Loved this game for years. Very happy that it is finally available through Steam.

This game right here is the classic RPG everyone tells you to buy. And you should. Just be warned beforehand: the combat system is a bit tricky. Never use real time, spare yourself the trouble. 
That being said, the story, writing and sidequests are great. Saving the local bank from being robbed? Recruiting a poor maid into a... cabaret so she'll give you a necklace? Having to whore yourself out for an invitation to the men's club (or killing the disgusting bugger and taking the bloody invitation from his cold corpse)? You can do anything! Enjoy the ride, because it's a great one.

Spend an hour on character creation.  Get beat up by a couple sewer rats.  Back to character creation.

Reminds me of playing Fallout for the first time.  They don't make RPGs like they used to.

Check the modding/configuration guides if you have any issues playing on a modern system.  The guide I followed to fix the slowdown issue is on my favorites list.

Arcanum is a great classic.  Seriously one of the best RPGs of the gold age of RPGs.

The graphics stutter very badly and certain fields on the screen may not update until I mouse over them.  Maybe others are having a better experience on other systems.

I'm going to try to get my old copy running on a WinXP vm.

I loved this game when it came out. and I love it still.

This is essentially a Steampunk Version of Baldur's Gate.  It has a top-down interface, and very similar game mechanics. However, the best part of this game is the crafting. It has most of the same races as D&D(E.G. half-orcs, elves, dwarves). Sadly, there aren't many graphic options for those who choose to play this on a newer system(no anti-aliasing).  I personally played it 3 times when it came out back in 1999. Strongly recommended for anyone who likes late 90s/early 2000s rpgs.

I've played many RPGs in my time; not many of them come near as close to what this is. I've heard of Arcanum in passing before on several video game forums but never garnered enough interest to give it a shot. I'm kind of kicking myself now for not doing so earlier.

     This is more than just a game, it's an experience. An experience that's been holding every hour of my free time in recent days. From the world building to exploration, dialogue to combat, everything has been crafted so well that I was pleasantly surprised once I had the ball rolling. I wasn't expecting much going into it, many games from the early two-thousands aged rather poorly, but this is like a bottle of scotch. It's a fantastic representation of what RPGs once were, when minute detail and thought went into what the player might experience, when cause and effect actually showed results and didn't shoehorn you into one path. If you make a decision in Arcanun, unless you savescum it's permanent. 

     So far I can't honestly think of anything about this game that I would speak negatively about, I haven't experienced any bugs yet, the difficulty has been challenging, I've been more immersed than I have in years; I keep wanting to continue and see where things go. I highly recommend picking this up if you're an RPG fan.
In short, this game is a rare gem that i loved playing when it first came out and i still enjoy it now

I held off on a review 'til a few hours in.  
No bugs (Win7), so my thousands of hours of gameplay over the past fifteen years count toward this review.
I don't agree with the "Steampunk" tag for this game.  Nothing punk about it.  What it is, is classic high fantasy a few hundred years down the road from its usual setting, where the industrial age is just beginning.
The story is engaging at times, full of gaps at others, though personally I think it's much more fleshed out than Baldur's Gate I or II, and the combat is much more rewarding.  Honestly the biggest reason I keep coming back to this game year after year is planning out and building a character based off of a set amount of skill points (the same reason I turn back to Diablo II every couple of years).  If you enjoy character buidling, and are looking for a story that-despite plot holes-can really suck you in at times, give it a try.  I have two copies on CD ROM, and this was still probably the best $3.59 I've spent on Steam this year.  I've hoped and dreamed for a sequel/remake/anything new over the years to bring attention back to this wonderful game.

Edit*
Forgot to mention that this is the only game that comes to mind, where you can create a character so stupid that he can critically fail an attack and chop himself in half.
One of the great RPGs from the 90s. The manual alone is 183 pages! Works fine under Win10, you can even tab out without issues. Steam overlay doesn't work though.
Must have!

A masterpiece of an RPG. I played well over 1000 hours at this game when i was younger and had the CD version of it. Loosing that cd shatered my heart as this is, in my opinion the best RPG ever made according to what i have played so far.

In Arcanum, freedom is the name of the game. Of course it is still a game and is restricted by the amount of content it has but even then, there seems to be an endless stream of it. Make any caracter you want, from a fighter, mage, gunslinger, armorer, archer, thieve, assassin to a diplomat, you can do it. I cannot guaranty your build will pull you out of every situation but nothing ever will eh!

It has its few bugs and old graphs but this doesnt mar the beauty of the game itself, not to speak of the godly steampunk-violin soundtrack wich only helps in keeping you immersed.

Overall, i spent way too much time on this game when i was younger and still spent more recently and i cant seem to get bored.

Worth a big 10/10 to me, worth buying anytime.

while it was fun to play in the past, steam has done nothing to upgrade this for the modern era. Game will not work on widescreen, making it difficult to play. There is a widescreen mod for it, but several people can not get it to function, one being myself. No autosave in the game, so if you play, expect to lose hours at a time on death. Yes you can manualy save of course. 

I played this a ton when it was first released. Beat it several times. The main plot is great. The combat system is best played on turn based, but you do have options for normal time.
This game is amazing, though its old and dated it still tells are great story and gave way to truely amazing RPG elements that we all know and love today.

I know it doesn't say I have many hours in this game. It's because I own it on original CD Rom. But let me tell you, I have poured hours into it. I've beaten it at least half a dozen times.

It was hard to get into the first time I played it. I just didn't understand some of the mechanics, and the enemies were tough for a beginner. I didn't pick it up again for about a year. When I finally did pick it up again, I grew very immersed. The level of impact you have on the world blew my mind. No other game has ever truly captured a character's impact than this game has. The only game since that even came close would be Pillars of Eternity.

You're in this massive world with no knowledge of its workings, other than what a mysterious stranger tells you. In order to truly understand it, you must travel the length and bredth of an entire continent. And huge isn't an overstatement. But it's incredibly fleshed out. Every location has its problems and charms, and everything you do in those locations will have a significant impact on the world. You could kill a seemingly innocent man, but for all you know, he could have been the heir to a kingdom. You'd never know until you've worked out how to put him on the throne. But would he be a good king or a bad one? That's up to you to decide.

Without giving away any spoilers, this game has forever impacted the standard to which I hold every other game after it.

I got excited about this game coming onto Steam, having played BG, BG II, and all that type of crpg. and woo steampunk!

Out of the 4.6 hours I have played, I have spent about 4 hours trying to fix elements of the game to make it playable.

After researching and finding and applying mods (and then fixes/workarounds for running it in Windows 10, or non-800x600 resolution) and then finding the .dll files etc.  I still found that I couldn't even buy things in shops, because the shop scroll arrows are bugged out and I have now given up.

Not just that, but random crashing, the combat system, navigating the separate screens; so much stuff is a royal pain in the proverbials with this game.

Getting it to work feels like work and not play. I have requested my refund.

Notice how a lot of positive reviews have 0.2hours, 0.6 hours.  These people have consumed many Member Berries.

EDIT:
My Steam refund did not get approved as I was over the play time limit.

Now I have played some more of the game and fixed the inventory scrolling problem (I have disabled scrolling and am using my touchpad), I am starting to enjoy it more

It looks complicated, but the game actually plays pretty simply once you figure it out. Story is great, lots of good voice acting, delicious hammy early cgi cutscenes, and a uniquely crafted world by the guys who made Fallout.
Only complaint is that it's buggy. The game also freaks out if you alt tab, so never do it unless you want to risk a corrupted save. I'm sure there's patches out there that fix the game.

The review will be constructed into 5 parts:
1. Game description (from what I‚Äôve seen in the time I‚Äôve played).
2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.
3. Pros/Cons.
4. Final thoughts.
5. Rating

So let's begin...

1. Game description:

A classical RPG with big character development and an isometric view.  It has some steampunk elements thrown in. The gameplay is what you would expect from a game this age, a little clunky by modern standards.

2. Did i finish the game? NO/ Maybe in the future

I like RPG‚Äôs, however the same thing happened when I played for the first time fallout 1 a couple of years ago. The mechanics and graphics where just to outdated for me. Maybe I will finish it someday for the story, but that is very unlikely.

3. Pros/Cons.

PROS:
- Classical RPG ‚Äì big nostalgia value for someone who played it when it was released.
- Nice athosphere

CONS:
- Outdated graphics and controls 

4. Final thoughts:

Bought this with the Sierra Bundle. It wasn't a game i played when i was little so i don't have any emotional atachment to it. If you like classical RPG and aren‚Äôt bothered by the outdated controls, go for it. It just wasn‚Äôt for me‚Ä¶

5. Rating

5/10

Arcanum is a truly unique gem of its time, and is still one of my favorite games to play 10 years later after playing it for the first time. This is one of the first open world games before Oblivion, Fallout III, and GTA III. This is one of the few games that captures the essense of D&D while putting its own twist in the mix without breaking the immersion to the experience. The lore is rich, and the attributes matter. If you only have 1 Charisma you will speak broken English, and the NPCs will riducule you. I can not speak highly enough of this game, and I've spent hundreds of hours playing the disc version. I'm so happy Steam finally added this masterpiece!

This game was one of the highlights of my gaming youth... all of the good gameplay of games like Baldur's Gate - but with a unique and interesting Steampunk theme. I don't know how many hours I spent on this in my teen years, but I know I'll eventually spend a lot more on this new version. 

Only one  complaint: it is impossible at the moment to play this game in a window and with the right resolution without using mods. I personally cant stand using mods, but for some people this might not be a problem. I also hear it doesn't run that great on Windows 10 but since I don't have it, I can only speak for Windows 7 users. 

Definitely worth buying at full price.

10/10

An amazing game!
I have played a LOT of games in my life, but this one is the best in the following categories:

+ best story:
not your average "hero saves the world" thing, includes a lot of twists
+ most interesting world:
magic and technology exist both and oppose each other. both are exciting and awesome! you can discover powerful evil magic or incredible ancient technology in this world! orcs, dwarfs, elfs and humans struggle to find a place in the industrial revolution.
+ i never saw better written dialogs
+ an rpg which actually offers intersting and legit peaceful solutions through persuasion! unique!
+ not the best, but still awesome music!

sadly a few weak points are important to mention too:
- old graphics that become decent with some modding efforts
- boring and rather unbalanced fights
- buggy if you do not mod it, with mods its not bug free but ok

I recommend this game to everyone looking for an RPG which is not focused on fighting!

I have extremely fond memories of playing Arcanum. This is a gem that truly stands the test of time, set in a world where magick and technology coexist. Character progression is very interesting where you are barely limited by your actions. You can be a thief and loot an armor store in the dark of night to obtain better equiptment. Oh but the armor chest is locked? Just pickpocket the key from the owners pockets when he is fast asleep which increases your chances of succeeding! Soundtrack has a nice violin melancholic feel to it, made fitting in a world consumed by an industrial and technological revolution that is hellbent in suppressing magic users. Without giving any spoilers, the main quest is refreshing and the subquests intriguing at best with tons of alternative options to choose from. To top it off, theres a good modding community-following for Arcanum as well by the folks over at Terra-Arcanum who has done some amazing job like unnoficial patches, higher resolution fixes, and others. Highly recommended to check it out!

The main plot line constantly kept me guessing and the various dialogue trees had some poignant, as well as hilarious, options.  Make sure you play through once as a character with low intelligence.

Arcanum is a classic RPG, with excellent writing, and a unique fantasy-steampunk setting where technology and magic clash. The character creation is superb and leaves you with many different ways to play through the game, with such fantastic backgrounds as 'special person', running away with the circus, beat with an ugly stick, charlatans protege, and many more that are quite unique. This all leads up to multiple ways to solve problems, and not everything is accessable with just one character like many RPG's today. If you have played the original Fallout games, and somehow passed over this, then it is worth a look.

That said, it does have its downsides, it was buggy at release, and still has a few today. The combat can be switched from real time to turn based, and as a result can be unbalanced in one or the other in differing situations, and it leaves the animations are a little clunky.

All in all, I wouldn't recommend it to everybody, but if you are down here reading the reviews its worth it to get lost in the world for a few hours. Definitely a memorable experience, and it holds up, despite its flaws.

Ah, Arcanum. Where to begin with this truly unique gem? I bought this game when it first came out and boy did I sink the hours into it! Only thing that would make me happier than seeing it released on steam like it is now is if some kind soul made a sequel or updated the existing version to todays standards of graphics etc

tbh, even when it was first released the graphics were pretty sub-par but didn't matter too much as the actual story itself was very compelling with an astounding variety of ways to play the game all completely viable to finish the game with as most quests give multiple ways of completing them

Want to play a suave half-orc or a grenade throwing psychopath? A classic fireball throwing elf mage or a typical axe wielding dwarf? Rain-man style card counting jerk? the list goes on, thanks to the large array of "backgrounds" you can choose at character creation to help flesh out your character.

The aspects of the game though which I've yet to see in any other which really sets it apart though are the technology/magic alignment meter, which directly affects your aptitude to use certain items or cast spells and vice versa...e.g the mage who tries to use a gun only to find they critically fail more often than not or not able to cast that vital heal on your tech companion as the the gadgets they weild and can create (from steam-powered spider drones to tonics to boost stats to hand cannons etc) will fizzle.

Some companions will not join you if you do not meet a certain level of tech or magic aptitude.

There is also a moral alignment as you progress, adding again to the replayability as some companions you can add to your party will only join if you are of certain alignments and offering differing endings to the game depending on if your good or evil inclined.

The game when it was released though was absolutely riddled with some game-breaking bugs. thankfully though there are some great patches out there from fans, most notably the drog black-tooth patch which can be found here  fixes a large number of them but it is still highly recommended to save often and in multiple slots:

http://terra-arcanum.com/drog/dest/uap.html

The combat pretty basic and I wouldn't advise using "real time", if you're familiar with early fallout (1&2) you'll know what i mean.

Overall a great game, interesting story, unique concept, high replayability. graphics are outdated, combat is bit messed up. corrupted saves suck balls.

8/10

One of the top 10 games ever. Steampunk fantasy Fallout.

I can spend my whole evening listing good things about Arcanum. It's got politics, magic, technology, crafting, quests, sidequests, sidequests, what-happened-after ending slides (consequences), sidequests, gnomish conspiracies, a thick novel full of dialogue, resurrecting of NPCs, racism, talking to ghosts of dead NPCs, memorable followers, good voice acting, unique, excellent soundtrack, idiot playthrough, plot twists, books, newspapers, gossip, shops, vendors, trainers, master trainer quests, free roam, 30 hours of gameplay even if you play it through once, nostalgic value, steampunk, story, backstory, history, philosophy, humor, beauty. There's so much to discover and each new place you'll reach will amaze you once again. You're totally free to design your character and make your choices. Choices that matter. There's lots of content for completionists and the replay value is so high you'll want to go completionist all over again once you finish the first time around. The makers of Arcanum put 10 games worth of brain into it.

Unfortunately, Arcanum was and still is poorly optimized which only hinders this experience for me. Low framerates (despite my  decently powerfulpc wirth a 980ti), simply because it wasn't coded right. Gave me headaches.

I understand why the game recieves amazing reviews on Steam, welcoming Troika's forst game to Steam with open arms. However, these reviews are based on the nostalgic experience of the game and I feel those reviews don't fairly represent this version.

Other problems include the horrible U.I which takes alot of time to get used to and an atrocious waypoint system. The combat is not as great as Fallout or Baldurs Gate either.

Please understand, I'm not trying to bash this game. It's a unique take on the Crpg formula. It has alot to offer and it's beautiful but I must speak out on this dreadful port. It's no wonder the community is asking for a remake. The fact that this version is getting great reviews is pretty ridiculous.... all because people can't take off their nostalgia goggles which are blinding them. If we keep supporting crap ports, we'll only continue to get crap ports.

Don't buy the Steam version. Yes, I know the fanboys will downvote this but it won't change the truth of my review. I'm afraid the facts are real, time to deal.

One of the best classic era RPGs of all times. Endless amounts of Character styles you can choose and the quests always have a "Fuck You" option to just get into a fight with the world. Sometimes force is the best solution afterall to get the things you want in life. right? No hand holding quests like most modern games these days, lots of adventuring to be had to get those quests complete.
Love this game.

Good game, terrible glitches and game breaking bugs. I gave it a go, I enjoyed it. Used latest unofficial patch and kept running into game breaking bugs toward the end. I must hae put a good 100 hours into it, that steam didn't record for whatever reason, must be all the addons. Also used the hi res patch, that's about it. Wish it wouldn't break on me, would have really liked to finish the game.

I have a few words about this game: This is the best game up to date. Just epic.

What else need to be said? I played this game sins the beginning. I wanted this game long before been released (at that time, we readed for the new games in journals) and i was aware, that this is going to be a good game, but not even close to the what comes next. I want Arcanum II. Just because i played this so much, that i know everything, and its not a challenge anymore, but i still played it. Because i love the world, the leveling the choises, the details and mechanics, the NPC, The weapons, quests, story, cityes, secerts... No need to speak more, if you want old but good game (they dont make them anymore like this) and you dont know Arcanum, or didn't play... Now is the time. Don't miss it. The outdated graphic is forgetable in the moment you enter in to the story and listen the soundtrack. I dare you.

An RPG that actually allowed players to resurrect an NPC. The only game I've ever played that had that, which ended up as one of those "Wow!" moments that stuck with me.

Troika will probably always be my all-time favourite developer if for no other reason than their creativity and imagination. Pity that they're long since gone.

All the same. Arcanum on Steam. Woot :)

Had it on disc many years ago, unfortunately I lost it during a move. Definitely one of the greatest RPGs of all time, glad it's on Steam. Only thing I'd recommend is the widescreen mod and a couple of other fixes so it looks good on newer computers, but otherwise there's really nothing that needs to be done to this game.

What can I say: 30 hours of playtime in less than a week!

Got it recently for six bucks to remember the good old days. One of the best RPGs (and one of the best games ever). 

Strongly recommended, even if will be your first time with this gem. Once you get used to the old school graphics: excellent gameplay and tons and tons of high-quality content.

Following the instructions for optimizing the game (community) is a must if you're with Win10. Otherwise performance is crappy.
Once you update the game folder following the instructions it wokrs smoothly.

Oh man. Oh man oh man. What a throwback. What an amazing game. It's surprising the amount of content this little beaut holds. I played this as a kid, and now I'm right back to it. I tried to get it to run about a year ago, but there were too many problems with the compatibility. Whoever thought of putting this on steam was a genius. This game has so much to do and so much character customization. Seems like 89% of modern games out there fall short of this epic; let me remind you it was a game released for PC in 2001. It was released 3 days before Windows XP.

The system is standard with spice. You have your basic stats, 16 schools of magic with 4 spells each, 8 branches of technology with 7 recipes, and 4 branches of skills (combat, thieving, social, and technological), . All use the same points on level-up (you only get 1 a level). You might have a bit of a hard time at the start, so here's a tip- you need 9 Charisma to get Sogg Mead Mug at the Shrouded Hills Inn, otherwise it'll be hard to pass the bridge thieves. That's all you get from me. I toiled at this game a lot back when it came out and any further tips would ruin the experience. I just don't want anyone throwing it aside in the beginning.

For 6 dollars, this is a steal. The amount of gameplay time is staggering. I have a friend who's a downright gamernazi about his games and he's beat this game 6 times with different outcomes. There's more than one main quest and your choices will effect the overall outcome of the game. Remember this when playing - there is no technomagick. You can't be magically adept and wield a gun. It's a disaster if you try. There ARE however techno-staves that hurl electricity. You can fulfill your technomancer dream with that.

Here's a list of pros and cons if you didn't want to read all that:

PROS
- Amazing customization
- Optional turn based or realtime combat at the push of the space bar
- Dozens of hundreds of items
- Optional followers
- Tons of choices in dialogue
- Deep story
- Beautiful world
- Make your own character portraits (google it)
- WHAT'S THAT BETWEEN THE "O" AND THE "U" IN GREY MOUNTAINS?!

CONS
- HUD is clunky and outdated (what did you expect?)
- Some indoor places are barren of decor and some objects/furniture are put in asinine places
- Hope you like critically missing and hitting yourself or party members in combat a lot early on
- Unless you have the resurrect spell, get used to party member permadeath, or reloading
- Autopathing is a bit frustrating
- Guns/bows require point for point ammunition... and has carryweight... per ammo (a pro if you're hardcore)

To sum it all up, this game is a steal for six bucks. Grab it, play it, live it, and die in it. A lot. Don't be a pansy and turn the difficulty down. I know you'll want to.
Steampunk Vs Magic in a lot of depth through the story & character building - Great game

Steam has Arcanum - Steam is now complete.
Best. Game. Ever.
9000/10

The only reason Arcanum isn't well known as the all-time classic that it is, is because it was released right between Diablo 2:Lord Of Destruction, and Baldur's Gate 2:Throne Of Bhaal.
They were massively popular expansions to massively popular games that essentially shared the same general visual style and similar gameplay to Arcanum, a game no one had ever heard of.
Naturally, it went overlooked in favor of the vastly more famous expansions.

Arcanum is an absolute masterpiece.
As much as I LOVE Diablo 2:Lord Of Destruction, I'm NOT sure that it was the best isometric PC game to come out that year.
Arcanum MAY be the better game.

Imagine everything you love about the Fallout games and Elder Scrolls games, and imagine a steampunk version in a DRAMATICALLY more elaborate and interesting world, with more depth, and more customization, but in isometric 2D, like the original Fallout games.
Arcanum was created by the creators of Fallout.
It IS steampunk Fallout.

I'll be real honest, if they told me that a new Fallout or Elder Scrolls game was on the way, I'd shrug.
That's cool.
But if they told me they were making Arcanum 2, I'd be LOSING MY GORRAM MIND waiting day by day for that game to come out. I've been waiting for Arcanum 2 to be announced for like 15 years.
10/10 One of the all time best ever. Its sad to say there has never been a succesor.

A good rpg... That hasn't aged well, oh dear!

Its quite in-depth and loosely Fallout-esque, I used to spend hours on this one.  Its never really had a great big following and I was disappointed it took too long to appear on Steam.  I wouldn't call it "fun" more like "really interesting". If you preferred older pre-Skyrhim RPGs were everything was more DnD traditional style and less "OMG here is something that shoots boom!", then you'll like this more.  If you prefer the modern OTT fantasy style, you might not like this. 

I prefer to play as a high Chrisma and high intelligence character.  Though playing as a dim-witted half-ogre whose dialogue amounts to "he died, him silly!" then it can be funny.  Especially when Gillbert Bates yells about shiny coins at you.  Though I only recommend playing this as an idiot once... The game is harder despite the humour and you get less gold.

Then we get to the "tech versus magic" thing.  Tech stuff is easy to get hold of and doesn't tend to drain your blue bar (forget as I write this what the blue bar means).  While magic is powerful but you have to work it a lot.  Technology is better at fighting magic, but magic has a lot more applications.  In the end you have to make some real choices.

The game used to also wipe out your intelligence points when you got to the panarii (spelling) main building, which was annoying and there was a way around this... Can't remember it.  But you suddenly became stupid.  I do not know if this is the fixed version, haven't got that far.  Also, a tip for people who want to break into higher levels beond the game allowence; level XP requirements are stored on a certain game related document, edit it and you can change when you level and how man times you level.  Its pretty simple cheating there... 

I did like the fat one of the patches pre-steam release did allow followers to level up as they only originally did so when you did. That meant when you hit max, they stopped leveling.  So the devs cared a little about the bugs in-game during its day.   

As for followers... As I said I like to have high chrisma which means I get max.  You need a healer with a large party and a few options exist.  Virgil is one, but he isn't the best at first, though I'd give a spoiler, he can become better later.  You also need a heavy hitter, arly game you can convince the "worlds smartest" orc to join you.  He and Magnus fill the roles between them, the "orc" better.  Later on you'll get even better followers...

Overall, the only thing I miss was the OTT manual that cam with the game... Plus you don't really see the loading screens anymore.

Also, have more then 1 save game file; the game can at times corrupt its save files, don't ask how or why it just does. 

Also, as with the levels a certain file can easily be edited to write your own backgrounds.  Though no maxing out states, the devs managed to cap things there somehow. Actuually, this game is pretty easy to edit details if you know which word file to alter.
One of the greatesr RPGs even created was the begining of an open worlk concept
10/10 one of the best rpgs ever made
One of the best RPGs of all times, with the best character creation and development system ever created. Story wasn't that great tho.

One of the best RPG's I've ever played. I still have my physical copy from way back when, though as soon as I saw this on steam (and especially at such a cheap price!) I instantly picked it up. I'm not sure I've replayed any RPG as much as I have this one. While it's true it has its shortcomings, I think its positives more than make up for them. I dont think I've seen many or any other game(s) with such an immersive and well-designed world/environment. 

Pros:

-Large variety in play-style/character customization, with tons of different specializations available.

-Most major quests have several different ways of being solved (and many of them are quite hard to find, particularly as a rogue-type character). Some might consider this a con, as many times you'll only realize those alternate paths existed long after you decided that certain (more obvious) approaches were the only ways.

-Many unique quests and possibilities depending on the skills you choose and how much you've levelled them, or the choices you make along your path and the people you talk to.

-Fairly large amount of freedom from the beginning, though I believe some parts are relatively linear.

-A very well designed world and environment, with a great deal of immersion.

Cons:

The combat isn't the best, for sure. It feels like the beginning is pretty rough unless you roll a warrior or certain magic schools (though you can almost always talk or sneak your way through situations, or with some lucky/save scummy use of items), and there are certain "linear progression points" that suddenly and drastically increase in difficulty. This has almost always led me to grind out levels to the point where I had most of the core skills I wanted and some pretty hefty combat skills, and even then you can still get utterly rocked. I honestly can't agree with such a design, but oh well. Maybe you're just meant to explore everything as soon as possible in order to gain those levels and better gear, I dont know. 
That being said, it doesnt necessarilly mean the combat is absolutely terrible, just some (imo) poor decisions on design and progression. 

-It didn't happen often, but there were some bugs that could wind up with you walking through a wall, and forcing you to reload/teleport (assuming you actually had the ability to teleport)


All in all, I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a good "open world" RPG. This was the game that got me into the fallout series, and I still don't think any of them came close to comparing. I gladly would have paid 3x the price for this even though I still have the cd's, just to have it on steam.

The narrator calls Arcanum a place of possibility. A place of change. The possibilities are indeed endless in this place, and change is inevitable. How and when said change will occur, however, is completely up to you- the only survivor of the IFS Zephyr crash.

The character system may be overwhelming at first, but it's straighforward enough to build an efficient character, both from a power play and roleplaying perspective. You can be dumb or smart, good or evil, fighter or ranger, charming or repulsive, gambler or trader, spellcaster or technologist, and their combinations. Even the most trivial side quest can have numerous solutions and outcomes depending on your character build and your choices. I especially recommend a persuasion master, and an unintelligent character (IN<5) for their unique dialogue lines.

The only major flaw I can think of is the combat system, which consists of picking your "attack", be it melee, a damage dealing spell, or a ranged weapon, and your target. You don't have to worry about positioning, line of sight, or enemies which require a different approach. Perhaps some tactical depth and higher difficulty could make Arcanum the absolute best isometric RPG. You won't care about light penalties or range penalties after a certain point, and combat will become a chore.

It's still amazing at everything else I can think of, and it totally deserves its praise.

It truly is a flawed gem, with several gamebreaker items, one or two overpowered spells and a handful of general minor issues. But it still is one hell of a gem, few games - and evenv fewer RPGs - gave me as many hours of fun as this one. Definitely a must-play.
It's an incredible game, but you're better off with fixed GOG version.

I've played this game so many times to completion and every time there is still something new.

One of the great classics. It gives you more freedom than hundreds of modern games combined.

Want to be an ogre thief? Go ahead. Want to seduce the skeleton, sure. Want to convince the necromancer to NOT end all life? Its possible.

A legendary RPG with a great setting. Used to play for days 10 years ago. Finally I can buy it in Russia. It works under Windows 10! Still lagging, no matter I have 10x more RAM now..

Positive sides:
1) A very rich world setting. Everything is polished to create a finished picture. Politics, people, books, mysteries - everything is at it's place and very interesting to learn and explore.
2) The plot is also interesting. Large side quests and party stories. 
3) Role Play matters. Persuasion is hard, the dialogs are well-written. Evil and good paths do differ.
4) Relatevely large locations (for 2001).
5) Great actors (however, few persons have actor voices).
6) Legendary music by Ben Houge.
7) Fine art, nice sounds, nice design.

Negative sides:
1) Low resolution. It's almost impossible to play this game today. Wish there would be a remake one day..
2) They had some minor bugs with AI.

This is the best game ever. 

Made by Troika Games, authors of Fallout and another bugged, unbalanced, yet cult game Vampire: Bloodlines.

Arcanum has horrible graphics. It has horrible combat. And its 'balance' is nonexistant. You can literally walk through the entire game by using ONLY one spell. The one you can start with.

Yet still Arcanum is the best game ever. It has one of the most captivating settings. It's a wonderful world, a merger of steampunk science and magic. It has lots of characters and story choices, most of them hidden and not given out in the open like in most modern RPGs. Of course sometimes even in Arcanum you have an option 'you either go here, or go there' but there is always a third way. And a fourth. And in most cases a fifth and a sixth.

Almost all quests in Arcanum have 4 or even more ways to finish them (and several to fail). This brings enormous replayability, and even after years you can find out that some quest could've been completed differently.

Arcanum is offering all of it. The moral dilemma, the ambiguity of your choices, the vastness of the world. If you can tolerate the graphics, clunky combat system and the fact that all skill choices are unbalanced, you're in for a treat. Dumb Half-Ogre? Halfling-thief? Intelligent Half-Orc? Elf-Engineer? Selfless or selfish, savior or villain, or anything inbetween. Possibilities of real roleplay are endless here.

This is and will stay my only review for a game on steam. Just because this one is the one I deeply care about.

And the soundtrack. Best soundtrack for a game ever written.
basically the one great thing to come out of the whole Steampunk subgenre before it was spoiled forever and became about hot gluing gears onto cheap top hats and spray painting Nerf guns gold

Absolutely amazing. Played the original(non-Steam) version(is there even a difference?) a long time ago. Did not end up finishing the game but definitely played a few hundred hours. Will play through it again when I have the time. If you don't already own the CD version there's no reason you shouldn't buy this. This is one of the games everyone should play some time. Take this from someone with over 3000 games...!

[h1] Review - Arcanum of Steamworks and Magick Obscura [/h1]

===

[h1] Rating: 9.0 / 10 - Outstanding Masterpiece of Role-Playing [/h1]

===

[h1] Pros & Cons [/h1]

[b] + Pros + [/b]

+ Deep, meaningful and varied character creation that importantly modifies role-playing experience

+ Immense character development, with loads of spells to learn, blueprints to craft and skills to master

+ Incredibly well-made role-playing interaction between player and NPCs, rivaled only by very few other 
legendary RPGs

+ Huge world to explore, with many secret locations to discover and random encounters

+ Possibility to choose between Real-time or Turn based combat, and switch between them at any time

+ More items to collect, loot, create, salvage and steal than you can ever imagine

+ Incredible variety of enemies, each place you visit will have its own unique ones mostly, rarely you will ever see a recycled model or enemy ever

+ Companions will react to player actions by discussing them, maybe approving them, or leaving the party if excessivley offended, or even try to stop him based on their alignment, character type and situation

+ Excellent AI of NPCs makes stealing, pickpocketing, murdering and generally bad actions much difficult to perform, you will have to find good strategies

+ Very deep and complex main quest that will surely entertain new and veteran players alike

+ Very varied secondary quests, forget all the repetitive stuff you see nowadays iN RPGs, this is the stuff of old and legend, this is the real deal

+ Drastic level of difficulty (played on Hard mode) ensures constant challenge even for experienced RPG players

+ Beautiful setting and lore, expanded by many documents you can read and stories you can hear about the world


[b] - Cons - [/b]

- Combat system is clunky and quite messy: companion AI cannot be configured, and they cannot be controlled in any way, this resulting in many combat failures and gruesome deaths for the player

- Game itself needs lots of unofficial patches and commands to be fixed and run properly on modern systems

- Biggest issue in my opinion: World exploration is boring: exploring the world is done via a 2D geographical map, the player represented by a red dot. You have the possibility to plot a course and explore the world, but locations are very sparse and many do not have any indication of their wereabouts. This results in you, looking at a moving dot for hours, just to find a random dungeon on the world map. Also, a location is detected only if the player goes really close to it on the map, and the map is HUGE, so yeah, it's very boring after some hours.

- No fast travel, regularly. You may either take the train or be a powerful mage and use the teleport which IS fast travel. This wouldn't be a bad thing if not for the really ugly exploration part of the game as i said above.

- Cannot Alt-Tab the game properly: it still stays on screen, forcing players to close it if they need to do something else on the desktop, if they do not have multi-monitor setup

===

One of the best game in it's time. After this game came out in 2001 I still play it from time to time. Try out almost every background, every build I can imagine and still discover something new in every playthrough. 

It's a shame that this game did not have enough support as it should, even with the official patch there are still a lot of bugs. So you may have to rely on unofficial patches to make it better. 

Definitely worth the price.

I played and replayed different characters constently in this game as a child. Revisiting this game now, years later, I realize now that what I was really attracted to was the setting, and the reason I kept restarting was because the gameplay didn't support the story. 

The world is brilliantly devised and executed, with wonderful art and music that really enhance the sense of playing in an alternate reality late-19th century infused with magic. Playing for a few minutes, I recall what held it back. Although the storytelling and game choices encourage you role play a number of really interesting roles, from tinkerer to illusionist to socialite and more, the game *mechanics* highly reward brute-force methods, rewarding *hits* on the enemy and offering very clunky combat options. Berserkers and Death Mages will have fun steamrolling this game, watching the story go by largely inconsequentially, while pickpockets and sharpshooters will struggle to progress, wondering why they spend so much time gathering resources that will do very little to open up interesting storylines or progress past combat obstacles the devolve into tit-for-tat hits.

Disappointing that such a richly developed world was stuck with such poor combat mechanics, the central gameplay element outside of the story.

Edit: commentators point out that there are some mods/patches that alleviate some issues.

A review I wrote back in 2001:

The last division of Dragon Knights has arrived. Thousands of men in shiny armour, mounted on the best horses Arcanum has ever seen, the pride of Cumbria, are waiting for their commander to issue the melee command. They are about to fight the battle of all battles and show the Tarantian technologists why steel and magick are superior over gunpowder and machines! Nothing can compare with bravery of Dragon Knights and might of their swords. The atmosphere is tense; everyone is waiting for that final command. ‚ÄúMelee!‚Äù ‚Äì Screamed Obsidur as the river of knights started to flow down the hill. Capturing the land, meter by meter, the knights were amazed by the reaction of Tarantian soldiers. They didn‚Äôt move one bit! They were waiting‚Ä¶ This just didn‚Äôt seem right, and fear strengthened among the Cumbrians. They never fought against guns, but their leaders can‚Äôt be wrong ‚Äì the guns must be weak! They just must!

They were wrong. As knights closed in, Tarantian riflemen fired hundreds of bullets while huge machines nullified Cumbrian wizards at the back. What a massacre! Cumbria lost its complete army. Glorious Dragon Knights are no more and Tarant is about to become Aracnum‚Äôs most powerful nation. The age of technology is ahead‚Ä¶

Okay, I may not be the best writer in the world, but I just had to show you how magick (note, it‚Äôs magic with k at the end) and tech both exist in the same time in Arcanum. The best way to describe it actually is to say that it‚Äôs a real nice, well-balanced mixture of Baldur‚Äôs Gate and Fallout. Arcanum is populated by Tolkienesque characters that include humans, dwarves, elves, gnomes, orcs and ogres (plus half elves, half ogres and half orcs), but as the game was made by the team responsible for Fallout, it leans toward avantgarde and introduces the industrial revolution to the world of magic!

You start the game as a sole survivor of a zeppelin crash. Actually, there was one more survivor who, just before he died, gave you some mystic ring and asked you to ‚Äúdeliver it to the boy as he‚Äôll know what to do with it‚Äù. From this moment on, you will be under attack of many assassins and involve yourself into a huge story that will have more twists than you could ever imagine.

First of all you need to create your character. You can actually pick one of the offered, pre-made chars but what fun is that? You will be able to choose any of the usual RPG races such as human, elf, dwarf, half-orc, half-ogre, the gender and other usual stuff. The ‚Äúunusual‚Äù options are those that take care of your ‚Äúalignment‚Äú. There are three tabs that list various skills, tech knowledge and magick abilities. There are almost hundred things in you can specialize so I suggest you to pick one or maybe two things and try to become an expert in that. But we‚Äôll talk about that later. At the end of character creation, you will be able to pick one of the offered character backgrounds. There are about 50 of those and they directly affect you in many ways. For example, you can pick ‚Äúraised by orcs‚Äù background that will make you very strong, but less appealing and of low intelligence. On the other hand you can pick to be ‚Äúborn under a sign‚Äù and cause less critical hits and misses, but whenever they occur ‚Äì they will be spectacular (I managed to cut off my leg by one critical miss!).

I can tell you, the character sheet of this game is the most detailed piece of information I have ever seen in any game! Each time you advance a level, you will be given an extra point to distribute into any skill or characteristic you want (unless a skill is influenced by a characteristic; such as: level 4 alchemist requires intelligence of 14 or so). The best thing to do is to carefuly decide what you want to be at the beginning. There are about 30 ‚Äúprofessions‚Äù to chose from and if you tend to be a little bit of everything, you will have a hard time going through the game. To give you a sight into what you can be I will list you a few professions: thief, alchemist, herbalist, inventor, bomber, gunman, water mage, fire mage, illusionist, swordfighter, knife thrower‚Ä¶ Intriguing? No, fascinating!

As you travel through the land of Steamworks and Magick, you will encounter thousands of NPCs, dozens of cities, ruins, dungeons, ancient graves, temples, altars‚Ä¶ You will also meet people who might join you in your quest and be valuable companions throughout the game. One such person is Virgil who will meet you at the very start. He‚Äôs a healer wizard that can become a skilled fighter and will probably stay with you ‚Äòtil the very end (plus, he‚Äôs a very interesting person and will‚Ä¶ nah, I can‚Äôt tell you! I don‚Äôt want to give out a spoiler!). Unlike in Baldur‚Äôs Gate, you can‚Äôt control other characters as you might wish to, but it‚Äôs still better than Fallout as you can issue commands and trade with them easily.
Arcanum offers literally hundreds of quests. Most of them are optional, of course, and if you tend to complete as much as possible, I can guarantee you to have at least 80 hours of active game play. Pretty much, wouldn‚Äôt you say? What‚Äôs even better is the fact that with all those possible professions, you will be unable to accept certain quests, as you will not be able to complete them. You simply cannot go through a LOT of Thieves Guild quests unless you have a high lockpicking and pick pocketing skill; if your persuasion is low, you will have to use force a lot and that might not be the best solution and so on. And for all of us who hate the FedEx quests (go somewhere, fetch an item and bring it back) ‚Äì good news! There are only a few such missions, and even they include a lot of bashing.

There are a lot of innovations concerning the items as well. Aside from the usual ‚Äúnormal‚Äù and magical items, Arcanum offers a variety of tech items. Mechanized axe or gauntlets for example. There are also a lot of guns, ranging from flintlock pistols and revolvers to shotguns and automatic weapons. Heck, you can even find schematics throughout the world, learn them and make new items by combining various items! By using those schematics, you can create such things as Molotov cocktails, spike guns or even the incredible automatons and arachnids (spider-like fighting robots!).

Overall, this game is definitely the best thing that has happened since the last Baldur‚Äôs Gate. Great gameplay, incredible character detail, superb story and great possibilities make Arcanum a fantastic game.

this game is poorly optimized but it is arcanum... one of the best rpgs where you rather discuss political and racial matter rather than just go rampage(what you can do if you want)

it is not just because of a nostalgia factor why this game is good, if you can get into it it is still a very great game compared to most garbage that is released nowadays

This is one of the best RPGs ever made. It's clunky, no doubt about that, but power through it and you're in for a hell of a great story. Once upon a time there was a fullscreen mode online that cleared up the interface a lot. If I find it I'll update this with a link.

Definately worth a playthrough if you're into old school cRPG's. You cannot beat Arcanum for the steampunk-fantasy genre. After 15 hours of play, I can comfirm that this appears to be the same original disc version. Definately worth installing the unofficial patch and high res patch from terra-arcanum (Google it.)

There is still a semi-uncommon bug with combat that freezes the game, just press space twice to toggle realtime combat on and off to bypass it.

Playing on Windows 7 Ultimate, no problems.

This Game is my all time favourite rpg its a 10 out of 10 the only one downside is quite a few gliches but this is made up for by everything else i have played this games through severall times and everytime loved it. save often and enjoy.

Textbook definition of a flawed gem. Horrible combat and clunky mechanics. On the other hand, incredible worldbuilding, setting, soundtrack, amazing writing and quests. The game world truly responds to your character development in rich and surprising ways. Immense replay value due to the sheer amount of variety in quests, locations, followers based on things like your race, gender, abilities, alignment etc.
